fr:mainmatter.fr:p: My name is 黄栩 (Huang Xu), but I go by the name Trebor online. I’m interested in (homotopy) type theory, category theory and jazz.
This is my forest. Forests are a way of organizing notes, and here is a list of other websites organized as forests. Some of the contents here:

fr:ul.fr:li: Algebraic geometry (Under namespace algm, not organized)
On ghost and phantom maps

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: On a computer, you can press Ctrl–K to search for trees. You can also visit my contributor page to see a list of my trees.
I try to adhere to several principles when composing trees.

fr:ul.fr:li: If a definition or a lemma would present itself during a proof attempt, then do not introduce it until that part of the proof. The nature of forests makes this kind of organization more viable, as each definition is a tree by itself.
If a part of a proof has an easy constructive phrasing, use it and avoid classical reasoning. But if it requires some complication, then the classical way is used.

Avoid abstraction leaks. Even if A is defined as B, do not use them interchangeably. For instance, an ideal is defined as a subset of a ring satisfying certain conditions. But we will insist on writing ideals as numbers, for example saying \mathfrak {a} \mid x instead of x \in \mathfrak {a}. This is not too heretic, since algebraic number theory already uses this kind of notation. Similarly, although prime ideals correspond to points in \operatorname {Spec}(A), we do not identify them.
Apply unbiased terminology and negative thinking.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any language \mathcal {L} \subseteq \Sigma ^*, the Myhill–Nerode automaton of \mathcal {L} is a deterministic automata (possibly with infinitely many states) that recognizes \mathcal {L}. The language \mathcal {L} is regular iff there are only finitely many Nerode congruence classes of \mathcal {L}. In this case, the automaton is the unique minimal DFA for \mathcal {L}.

We define the states of the automaton be the Nerode congruence classes. For each letter a \in \Sigma , we add a transition between the congruence classes [x] and [xa]. This is well-defined and deterministic by definition of the congruence. It is also obvious that a DFA for \mathcal {L} cannot have less states.
Given a language \mathcal {L} over the alphabet \Sigma , two words x, y \in \Sigma ^* are Nerode congruent if for any word z, xz \in \mathcal {L} iff yz \in \mathcal {L}.
Random distribution of conway signatures
discussion of cyclic signatures and their fractal structure
signature finder
Induction of reversible languages
Turning into nondet transducer, and executing

A deterministic automaton is bideterministic if it has only one accepting state, and if reversing all transitions and swapping the starting and accepting state produces another deterministic automaton.

Consider the alphabet \Delta where each symbol is either of the form (\text {tile label }t, \text {edge label of }t), (\text {tile label }t, \text {subtile label of }t). We define a language \mathcal {L} on \Delta \times \Delta , representing a binary relation on \Delta ^* between words of the same length. Let \Sigma = t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} \cdots \xrightarrow {s_n} t_n be a finite Conway signature and \epsilon be an edge label of the corresponding tile. We regard this as a word (t_0, \epsilon )(t_1, s_1) \cdots (t_n, s_n) over the alphabet \Delta . Suppose the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma _1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma _2, \epsilon _2), then the two corresponding words can be zipped together to form a word over \Delta \times \Delta . We define the set of all such words as the language of neighborhood relation \mathcal {L}.

Furthermore, consider the set of tile labels \mathrm {T}. We define another language \mathcal {L}^+, called the augmented language of neighborhood relation, over the alphabet (\Delta \times \Delta ) \sqcup \mathrm {T}. Notice that if the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma _1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma _2, \epsilon _2), the two signatures always share the last prototile label t_n. We append the symbol t_n to the corresponding word in \mathcal {L}, and define \mathcal {L}^+ to be all the words of this form.

Given an alphabet \Sigma and a language \mathcal {L} \subseteq \Sigma ^*, its limit is an \omega -language \lim \mathcal {L} \subseteq \Sigma ^\omega containing the words w such that all finite prefixes of w can be extended to a word in \mathcal {L}.

fr:title.text: Limits of regular languages are deterministic Büchi recognizable

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits of regular languages are deterministic Büchi recognizable

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a regular language \mathcal {L}, its limit \lim \mathcal {L} can be recognized by a deterministic Büchi automaton, by simply regarding a DFA for \mathcal {L} as a Büchi automaton. In fact, every deterministic Büchi recognizable \omega -language is of this form.
For any substitution system, the language of neighborhood relation is regular.
A regular language is reversible if it can be recognized by a bideterministic DFA, which is equivalent to requiring the Myhill–Nerode automaton to be bideterministic.
Note that there are stronger and weaker notions of reversible regular languages in the literature, with inconsistent names.

fr:title.text: The augmented language of neighborhood relation is reversible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The augmented language of neighborhood relation is reversible

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given any substitution system, the augmented language of neighborhood relation \mathcal {L}^+ is reversible.
It is straightforward to write down a recursive algorithm for calculating neighborhood Conway signatures. It has an elegantly symmetric structure.

Suppose we have a substitution system. Given the Conway signature of a tile t and an edge label \epsilon of that tile, we can calculate the signature of the neighboring tile t' and the edge label \epsilon ' of t' that coincides with \epsilon . This is implemented by mutual recursion with another auxiliary function. Given the signature of a tile and a subedge of that tile under deflation, it calculates the signature of the subtile t' we will arrive in if we cross the subedge inwards, and the edge label of t' corresponding to the input subedge.
This second function is non-trivial, because for some substitution systems, crossing inwards through a subedge may lead us immediately out through another subedge, if they are pinched together. See .

The neighborhood function is as follows. Suppose we have a Conway signature t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and an edge \epsilon _0 of the tile t_0. We consult the pairing of edges as specified in the substitution system. This has two cases.

fr:ul.fr:li: Suppose the edge \epsilon _0 (of the subtile labelled s_1) is paired with another edge \epsilon '_0 of the subtile numbered s'_1. Then since these two subtiles are neighbors already, we can directly output the signature t'_0 \xrightarrow {s'_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and the edge label \epsilon '_0, where t'_0 is the prototile type of the s'_1 subtile in t_1.

Suppose the edge is paired with a subedge \sigma _1 of an edge \epsilon _1 in the tile t_1. Then we need to exit the tile t_1 through this edge. We recursively call this function on the Conway signature t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} \cdots and the edge label \epsilon _1. Suppose the algorithm determines that its neighbor has the Conway signature \Delta and the edge label \epsilon '_1. We then invoke the auxiliary function to calculate the subtile we would obtain if we enter \Delta from the subedge \sigma _1 of its edge \epsilon '_1, and we can return its output, tail-recursively.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the auxiliary function, suppose again we have a signature \Sigma = t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and we have specified an edge \epsilon _0 of the tile t_0, together with one of its subedges \sigma _0. Again, we look up what is paired, in the substitution of t_0, with the subedge \sigma _0.

fr:ul.fr:li: Suppose the result is an edge \epsilon _{-1} in the subtile s_0 of t_0. Then we can output t_{-1} \xrightarrow {s_{0}} t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \longrightarrow \cdots and the edge label \epsilon _{-1}, where t_{-1} is the prototile label corresponding to the subtile s_0.

Suppose the result is another subedge \sigma '_0 of the edge \epsilon '_0. Then we call the neighborhood function on the Conway signature \Sigma and the edge label \epsilon '_0. Let the result be the signature \Delta and the edge \epsilon ''_0. Now we just need to call the auxiliary function on \Delta with the subedge \sigma '_0 of \epsilon ''_0, and return its result.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If we are dealing with finite Conway signatures, then the algorithm should raise an exception if at any point the path is too short. This signals that it has reached the boundary of the finite patch of tiles. Otherwise, the neighborhood function should always output a Conway path of equal length.

With this algorithm, we can generate any patch of tiling by repeatedly asking the program what the neighbor of each tile is, until the generated tiles fill the area, like growing a crystal. We just need a Conway signature to begin with. Some methods to create this initial seed are discussed in (...), each designed for a different purpose.

Unfortunately, this recursive algorithm actually doesn’t generate all the possible tilings in our substitution system. This is surprising, because it seems that Conway signatures uniquely determines the arrangement of tiles we are in, if we suppose inflation is always unique. However, the definition of substitution tilings has a secret catch.

Given a set \mathscr {S} of (possibly incomplete) tilings of the plane, its hull \overline {\mathscr {S}} is the set of complete tilings T, such that given an arbitrarily large disk D \subseteq \mathbb {R}^2, the patch of tiles in T intersecting D appears inside a tiling T' \in \mathscr {S}, up to translation.

When we talk about the set of, say, Penrose tilings, we are actually referring to the hull of all the iterated deflations of a single tile. Each of those iterated deflations only cover a finite portion of the plane, and an actual tiling completely covers the plane in a way that any finite portion of it can be found in one of those deflations.

In our , we are assuming the entire tiling comes from a single iterated deflation, so when we attempt to calculate the neighbor of a tile, we first repeatedly inflate the tiles so that both of them are contained in one giant tile, and then deflate back down. However, an actual tiling may only look like an iterated deflation on each finite patch, so it may be the case that no amount of inflation brings the neighbor into the same supertile.

Consider the substitution system of Penrose rhombs. Take the cyclic Conway signature \Sigma _0 = \text {Thin} \xrightarrow {\text {left}} \text {Thin} \xrightarrow {\text {left}} \cdots This repeatedly selects the thin 36\degree subtile on the left. No matter how many times we use the substitution rules, the selected thin rhomb will not have a neighbor.
(To do: reproduce the image here)

However, after any finite length of this Conway signature, we can replace the rest of the signature with \cdots \text {Thin} \xrightarrow {\text {top}} \text {Thick} \xrightarrow {\text {left}} \text {Thick}\xrightarrow {\text {left}} \text {Thick}\xrightarrow {\text {left}} \cdots and this will cover the whole neighborhood. Therefore, for any finite radius, there is a patch of tiling that looks like it can be described by \Sigma _0 in that radius. As the radius tends to infinity, these patches converge to a single complete tiling whose center tile has Conway signature \Sigma _0, which is therefore in the hull of Penrose tilings.

As an analogy, the neighborhood algorithm behaves like the algorithm adding 1 to an integer in decimal notation. Suppose it encounters \cdots 999 + 1, then it will scan forwards until it reads a digit d that is not 9. Then it performs the carry and outputs [d+1]00\cdots 00. However, the tilings are only required to locally look like iterated deflations. In this analogy, we have numbers that only locally look like an “actual” integer, so it is possible to have infinitely many digit 9s. On the other hand, we don’t actually need to read ahead: as soon as we see a 9, we can go ahead and output a 0, since that is the only possible result! In , we shall make this precise, in the context of Conway signatures.

fr:title.text: The structure of neighbor Conway signatures

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The structure of neighbor Conway signatures

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The recursive neighborhood algorithm computes neighboring tiles in some iterated deflation of a supertile, and we wish to extend this function to work with the hull of these deflations, i.e. the full set of possible Penrose tilings. It is first useful to consider a binary relation, instead of a function, between Conway signatures.

Given a substitution system, two infinite Conway signatures \Sigma _1, \Sigma _2, and an edge label \epsilon _1, \epsilon _2 for each signature, we define a neighborhood relation, denoted as \Sigma _1 \xrightleftharpoons [\epsilon _2]{\epsilon _1} \Sigma _2. It holds if and only if, for every natural number n, there exists finite signatures \Sigma '_1, \Sigma '_2 that agree with \Sigma _1 and \Sigma _2 at the first n places, and the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma '_1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma '_2, \epsilon _2).
Note that this relation is not necessarily symmetric, total or functional.

Essentially the definition says that, if you look at a finite patch of tiles, it is always plausible that this can (hence the \exists quantifier, not \forall ) be extended to a larger patch where they are neighbors in an iterated deflation of one single tile. This also leaves open the possibility that there may be multiple different possible Conway signatures for a neighbor, which is why we opted to consider a binary relation, instead of a function.
Next, we need some general theory relating these infinite objects to finite ones. For this we make some definitions.

Consider the alphabet \Delta where each symbol is either of the form (\text {tile label }t, \text {edge label of }t), (\text {tile label }t, \text {subtile label of }t). We define a language \mathcal {L} on \Delta \times \Delta , representing a binary relation on \Delta ^* between words of the same length. Let \Sigma = t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} \cdots \xrightarrow {s_n} t_n be a finite Conway signature and \epsilon be an edge label of the corresponding tile. We regard this as a word (t_0, \epsilon )(t_1, s_1) \cdots (t_n, s_n) over the alphabet \Delta . Suppose the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma _1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma _2, \epsilon _2), then the two corresponding words can be zipped together to form a word over \Delta \times \Delta . We define the set of all such words as the language of neighborhood relation \mathcal {L}.

Furthermore, consider the set of tile labels \mathrm {T}. We define another language \mathcal {L}^+, called the augmented language of neighborhood relation, over the alphabet (\Delta \times \Delta ) \sqcup \mathrm {T}. Notice that if the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma _1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma _2, \epsilon _2), the two signatures always share the last prototile label t_n. We append the symbol t_n to the corresponding word in \mathcal {L}, and define \mathcal {L}^+ to be all the words of this form.

We define the augmented language in this way because it has a very important property, which will be useful later. With this definition in hand, we see that is actually a well-known construction in \omega -languages, i.e. languages with infinitely long words.

Given an alphabet \Sigma and a language \mathcal {L} \subseteq \Sigma ^*, its limit is an \omega -language \lim \mathcal {L} \subseteq \Sigma ^\omega containing the words w such that all finite prefixes of w can be extended to a word in \mathcal {L}.

Obviously, we have \lim \mathcal {L} = \lim \mathcal {L}^+ since a terminating symbol can’t affect the limit. Limits are nice because they can be recognized by deterministic finite state machines (also known as deterministic Büchi machines, to emphasize they are for \omega -languages).

fr:title.text: Limits of regular languages are deterministic Büchi recognizable

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits of regular languages are deterministic Büchi recognizable

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a regular language \mathcal {L}, its limit \lim \mathcal {L} can be recognized by a deterministic Büchi automaton, by simply regarding a DFA for \mathcal {L} as a Büchi automaton. In fact, every deterministic Büchi recognizable \omega -language is of this form.

Now, there is one single hypothesis that I am not able to get rid of. It doesn’t even need a constructive proof, as we will later give a construction that provably satisfies the hypothesis given that it is true.
For any substitution system, the language of neighborhood relation is regular.
As promised, we reveal the special property that \mathcal {L}^+ enjoys.

A deterministic automaton is bideterministic if it has only one accepting state, and if reversing all transitions and swapping the starting and accepting state produces another deterministic automaton.
A regular language is reversible if it can be recognized by a bideterministic DFA, which is equivalent to requiring the Myhill–Nerode automaton to be bideterministic.
Note that there are stronger and weaker notions of reversible regular languages in the literature, with inconsistent names.

Given a set \mathscr {S} of (possibly incomplete) tilings of the plane, its hull \overline {\mathscr {S}} is the set of complete tilings T, such that given an arbitrarily large disk D \subseteq \mathbb {R}^2, the patch of tiles in T intersecting D appears inside a tiling T' \in \mathscr {S}, up to translation.

Consider the substitution system of Penrose rhombs. Take the cyclic Conway signature \Sigma _0 = \text {Thin} \xrightarrow {\text {left}} \text {Thin} \xrightarrow {\text {left}} \cdots This repeatedly selects the thin 36\degree subtile on the left. No matter how many times we use the substitution rules, the selected thin rhomb will not have a neighbor.
(To do: reproduce the image here)

However, after any finite length of this Conway signature, we can replace the rest of the signature with \cdots \text {Thin} \xrightarrow {\text {top}} \text {Thick} \xrightarrow {\text {left}} \text {Thick}\xrightarrow {\text {left}} \text {Thick}\xrightarrow {\text {left}} \cdots and this will cover the whole neighborhood. Therefore, for any finite radius, there is a patch of tiling that looks like it can be described by \Sigma _0 in that radius. As the radius tends to infinity, these patches converge to a single complete tiling whose center tile has Conway signature \Sigma _0, which is therefore in the hull of Penrose tilings.

Given a substitution system, two infinite Conway signatures \Sigma _1, \Sigma _2, and an edge label \epsilon _1, \epsilon _2 for each signature, we define a neighborhood relation, denoted as \Sigma _1 \xrightleftharpoons [\epsilon _2]{\epsilon _1} \Sigma _2. It holds if and only if, for every natural number n, there exists finite signatures \Sigma '_1, \Sigma '_2 that agree with \Sigma _1 and \Sigma _2 at the first n places, and the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma '_1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma '_2, \epsilon _2).
Note that this relation is not necessarily symmetric, total or functional.
We specify the combinatorial data required to define a substitution tile system.

We define a (two-dimensional, simple) tile system as a collection of finitely many polygons, called tiles, with colored edges, such that the colors come in pairs written as +c, -c. A tiling of the tile system is a tessellation of the plane by these tiles, such that tiles can only touch by sharing entire edges, such that the colors on those edges are in pairs. In principle, a tiling only allows translations of tiles, but in implementation it is convenient to have a finite set of rotations (and possibly reflections), as it reduces code duplication.

Sometimes, to disambiguate between a type of tiles (of which there are only finitely many) and one instance of such a tile in a tiling (which can occur infinitely many times), we refer to the former as a prototile. Every edge of a tile is given a unique number, which we refer to as edge labels.

Given a tile system, a substitution system is a map from each prototile to a patch of tiles, such that when we replace each tile in a tiling with the substitution, the resulting patches of tiles can fit together in the same way, forming another tiling. This process is called deflation, while the inverse process, if it exists, is called inflation. We usually only consider substitution systems where inflation exists and is unique.

More precisely, given a prototile t, we assign a list of deflated tiles t_i. Each edge of t will be subdivided into several subedges (with their own colors), such that the subdivision only depends on the color, and edges of opposite colors are divided in a way such that the resulting subedges match. For the data of how the deflated tiles glue together, we have a perfect pairing on the set \{\text {subedges of $t$}\} \sqcup \coprod _i \{\text {edges of $t_i$}\} such that the paired edges are compatible. Specifically, if two edges of deflated tiles, or two subedges of t are matched, they must be of opposite colors; if an edge of a deflated tile is matched with a subedge, they must share colors.
In addition to this, the subdivision must also match geometrically, but we shall not give its full definition here, as it suffices to recognize this intuitively.

For convenience, if two edges \epsilon and \epsilon ' have opposite colors, we use the same label for their subedges in a substitution. This simplifies the presentation since we avoid using a conversion look-up table, but requires us to be somewhat careful in assigning labels. In general, we can assign the subedge labels counterclockwise for edges with positive colors, and clockwise for negative colors.

On a first read, the definition of a substitution system may seem to contain some surprising cases. Why is it possible to have subedges paired against each other? This is because there are examples where this occurs. Even though we can often transform our substitution systems to avoid this, it allows for very economic presentations, and thus more efficient algorithms. In addition, accounting for these cases reveals some symmetry in the recursive structure of our programs.
Now we have enough terminology to define the fundamental object in our algorithms, the Conway signature.

Assume we have a substitution system with unique inflation. For a tile t in a tiling, we can inflate the tiling to find t as a subtile in an inflated tile t_1. If we give a unique number to each subtile in a substitution system, we can write this as t \xrightarrow {n_1} t_1, meaning t is the n_1-th subtile. This process can be repeated, generating an infinite path \Sigma = t \xrightarrow {n_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {n_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots where t, t_1, t_2, \dots are prototile labels, and n_i are subtile labels. This path \Sigma is called the Conway signature of the tile. We will also consider the case of a finite patch of tiling, in which case the Conway signature will be a finite path.

Computationally, this can be regarded as an infinite stream of data. In lazy languages like Haskell, we can directly implement this as an infinite list. Notice that there will be a lot of sharing as the signature of different tiles will often share a tail. So if your language does not have lazy functional data structures, you need to make sure sharing has a low cost.

Assume we have a substitution system with unique inflation. For a tile t in a tiling, we can inflate the tiling to find t as a subtile in an inflated tile t_1. If we give a unique number to each subtile in a substitution system, we can write this as t \xrightarrow {n_1} t_1, meaning t is the n_1-th subtile. This process can be repeated, generating an infinite path \Sigma = t \xrightarrow {n_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {n_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots where t, t_1, t_2, \dots are prototile labels, and n_i are subtile labels. This path \Sigma is called the Conway signature of the tile. We will also consider the case of a finite patch of tiling, in which case the Conway signature will be a finite path.

Suppose we have a substitution system. Given the Conway signature of a tile t and an edge label \epsilon of that tile, we can calculate the signature of the neighboring tile t' and the edge label \epsilon ' of t' that coincides with \epsilon . This is implemented by mutual recursion with another auxiliary function. Given the signature of a tile and a subedge of that tile under deflation, it calculates the signature of the subtile t' we will arrive in if we cross the subedge inwards, and the edge label of t' corresponding to the input subedge.
This second function is non-trivial, because for some substitution systems, crossing inwards through a subedge may lead us immediately out through another subedge, if they are pinched together. See .

The neighborhood function is as follows. Suppose we have a Conway signature t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and an edge \epsilon _0 of the tile t_0. We consult the pairing of edges as specified in the substitution system. This has two cases.

fr:ul.fr:li: Suppose the edge \epsilon _0 (of the subtile labelled s_1) is paired with another edge \epsilon '_0 of the subtile numbered s'_1. Then since these two subtiles are neighbors already, we can directly output the signature t'_0 \xrightarrow {s'_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and the edge label \epsilon '_0, where t'_0 is the prototile type of the s'_1 subtile in t_1.

Suppose the edge is paired with a subedge \sigma _1 of an edge \epsilon _1 in the tile t_1. Then we need to exit the tile t_1 through this edge. We recursively call this function on the Conway signature t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} \cdots and the edge label \epsilon _1. Suppose the algorithm determines that its neighbor has the Conway signature \Delta and the edge label \epsilon '_1. We then invoke the auxiliary function to calculate the subtile we would obtain if we enter \Delta from the subedge \sigma _1 of its edge \epsilon '_1, and we can return its output, tail-recursively.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the auxiliary function, suppose again we have a signature \Sigma = t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and we have specified an edge \epsilon _0 of the tile t_0, together with one of its subedges \sigma _0. Again, we look up what is paired, in the substitution of t_0, with the subedge \sigma _0.

fr:ul.fr:li: Suppose the result is an edge \epsilon _{-1} in the subtile s_0 of t_0. Then we can output t_{-1} \xrightarrow {s_{0}} t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \longrightarrow \cdots and the edge label \epsilon _{-1}, where t_{-1} is the prototile label corresponding to the subtile s_0.

Suppose the result is another subedge \sigma '_0 of the edge \epsilon '_0. Then we call the neighborhood function on the Conway signature \Sigma and the edge label \epsilon '_0. Let the result be the signature \Delta and the edge \epsilon ''_0. Now we just need to call the auxiliary function on \Delta with the subedge \sigma '_0 of \epsilon ''_0, and return its result.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If we are dealing with finite Conway signatures, then the algorithm should raise an exception if at any point the path is too short. This signals that it has reached the boundary of the finite patch of tiles. Otherwise, the neighborhood function should always output a Conway path of equal length.

To generate a tiling, we need to determine what kind of information the computer needs. This can be divided into two parts. The geometric information records the shape of each tile, and the combinatorial information records the matching rules and combinatorial data of the substitution rules. Given some combinatorial data, we can algorithmically produce the neighbor structure of each tile, which can then be easily graphically displayed by suitably translating and rotating the tiles using the geometric information. Note that producing the neighbor is non-trivial, since naïvely attempting every possible tile under the matching rules require arbitrarily far backtracking.

We will first construct a recursive neighborhood algorithm, which computes the neighbor tile when we specify a tile and one of its edges. This is already enough if you want to display random patches of the tiling, but there are cases with zero probability where the program will hang. However, these cases often contain interesting features, such as a high degree of symmetry, or fractal structures. So we will construct another transductive neighborhood algorithm, depending on the recursive one, that allows us to handle those inputs by producing partial outputs as soon as they can be determined.

There is still a smaller set of input that cannot be handled. The situation is not unlike attempting to calculate 0.9999\cdots + 0.0000\cdots , with the algorithm forever unable to determine if it should output 1.00\cdots or 0.99\cdots , because it is unsure whether it will encounter a digit less than 9 in the first summand, or a non-zero digit in the second summand. This is obviously impossible to solve, unless we have more information. For example, if we know beforehand that the first summand is indeed 0.9\overline {9}, then we can safely output 1. as the first digit. This also applies to our tiling algorithm. We will be able to classify all the failure cases, and if we know beforehand the input falls in one of those cases, then we can bypass the problem in an ad hoc way.

The Penrose rhombs form a tile system. It consists of two prototiles, the thick and thin rhombuses. They have the same side length, and has an internal angle of 2\pi / 5 and \pi / 5, respectively. The colors of the edges are ±c_1, ±c_2 as drawn below.
This comes with a substitution system, depicted as follows.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs} \usetikzlibrary{decorations.pathreplacing}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Notice that ±c_1 edges always split into two subedges, and ±c_2 edges three. They are separated by the four vertices drawn as black dots. However, these subedges may be pinched together, creating zero-width “spurs” protruding from the tiling. They are to be read as two subedges, first going out from the tilings and turning back. This is necessary to uniformly define how the tiles fit together after the substitution.

Given a tile system, a substitution system is a map from each prototile to a patch of tiles, such that when we replace each tile in a tiling with the substitution, the resulting patches of tiles can fit together in the same way, forming another tiling. This process is called deflation, while the inverse process, if it exists, is called inflation. We usually only consider substitution systems where inflation exists and is unique.

More precisely, given a prototile t, we assign a list of deflated tiles t_i. Each edge of t will be subdivided into several subedges (with their own colors), such that the subdivision only depends on the color, and edges of opposite colors are divided in a way such that the resulting subedges match. For the data of how the deflated tiles glue together, we have a perfect pairing on the set \{\text {subedges of $t$}\} \sqcup \coprod _i \{\text {edges of $t_i$}\} such that the paired edges are compatible. Specifically, if two edges of deflated tiles, or two subedges of t are matched, they must be of opposite colors; if an edge of a deflated tile is matched with a subedge, they must share colors.
In addition to this, the subdivision must also match geometrically, but we shall not give its full definition here, as it suffices to recognize this intuitively.

For convenience, if two edges \epsilon and \epsilon ' have opposite colors, we use the same label for their subedges in a substitution. This simplifies the presentation since we avoid using a conversion look-up table, but requires us to be somewhat careful in assigning labels. In general, we can assign the subedge labels counterclockwise for edges with positive colors, and clockwise for negative colors.

We define a (two-dimensional, simple) tile system as a collection of finitely many polygons, called tiles, with colored edges, such that the colors come in pairs written as +c, -c. A tiling of the tile system is a tessellation of the plane by these tiles, such that tiles can only touch by sharing entire edges, such that the colors on those edges are in pairs. In principle, a tiling only allows translations of tiles, but in implementation it is convenient to have a finite set of rotations (and possibly reflections), as it reduces code duplication.

Sometimes, to disambiguate between a type of tiles (of which there are only finitely many) and one instance of such a tile in a tiling (which can occur infinitely many times), we refer to the former as a prototile. Every edge of a tile is given a unique number, which we refer to as edge labels.

fr:title.text: Generating aperiodic tilings with substitution systems

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Generating aperiodic tilings with substitution systems

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: I assume familiarity with aperiodic tilings and substitution systems. It is already possible, via naïve use of the substitution system, to construct algorithms that generate arbitrarily large patches of the tilings. However, the collection of algorithms persented here has several advantages.

fr:ul.fr:li: It can incrementally generate patches arbitrarily far away from the starting point, without needing to specify the size up front.
It is very efficient, both in time and in space, as it only generates tiles on demand, as they enter the viewport.
For each concrete tiling system, it requires minimal manual input, automatically constructing almost the entire algorithm.
The generation itself does not depend on the geometric information! This avoids difficult calculations with arbitrary-precision numbers.
The algorithm elegantly handles very problematic situations such as substitutions with disjoint tiles, or zero-width spurs.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These materials essentially come from a four part series in Tatham’s blog. I strongly recommend reading through them first. In my own writeup, I removed the intermediate algorithms that are later replaced with better ones, and gave some more precise definitions and proofs.

To generate a tiling, we need to determine what kind of information the computer needs. This can be divided into two parts. The geometric information records the shape of each tile, and the combinatorial information records the matching rules and combinatorial data of the substitution rules. Given some combinatorial data, we can algorithmically produce the neighbor structure of each tile, which can then be easily graphically displayed by suitably translating and rotating the tiles using the geometric information. Note that producing the neighbor is non-trivial, since naïvely attempting every possible tile under the matching rules require arbitrarily far backtracking.

We will first construct a recursive neighborhood algorithm, which computes the neighbor tile when we specify a tile and one of its edges. This is already enough if you want to display random patches of the tiling, but there are cases with zero probability where the program will hang. However, these cases often contain interesting features, such as a high degree of symmetry, or fractal structures. So we will construct another transductive neighborhood algorithm, depending on the recursive one, that allows us to handle those inputs by producing partial outputs as soon as they can be determined.

There is still a smaller set of input that cannot be handled. The situation is not unlike attempting to calculate 0.9999\cdots + 0.0000\cdots , with the algorithm forever unable to determine if it should output 1.00\cdots or 0.99\cdots , because it is unsure whether it will encounter a digit less than 9 in the first summand, or a non-zero digit in the second summand. This is obviously impossible to solve, unless we have more information. For example, if we know beforehand that the first summand is indeed 0.9\overline {9}, then we can safely output 1. as the first digit. This also applies to our tiling algorithm. We will be able to classify all the failure cases, and if we know beforehand the input falls in one of those cases, then we can bypass the problem in an ad hoc way.
We specify the combinatorial data required to define a substitution tile system.

We define a (two-dimensional, simple) tile system as a collection of finitely many polygons, called tiles, with colored edges, such that the colors come in pairs written as +c, -c. A tiling of the tile system is a tessellation of the plane by these tiles, such that tiles can only touch by sharing entire edges, such that the colors on those edges are in pairs. In principle, a tiling only allows translations of tiles, but in implementation it is convenient to have a finite set of rotations (and possibly reflections), as it reduces code duplication.

Sometimes, to disambiguate between a type of tiles (of which there are only finitely many) and one instance of such a tile in a tiling (which can occur infinitely many times), we refer to the former as a prototile. Every edge of a tile is given a unique number, which we refer to as edge labels.

Given a tile system, a substitution system is a map from each prototile to a patch of tiles, such that when we replace each tile in a tiling with the substitution, the resulting patches of tiles can fit together in the same way, forming another tiling. This process is called deflation, while the inverse process, if it exists, is called inflation. We usually only consider substitution systems where inflation exists and is unique.

More precisely, given a prototile t, we assign a list of deflated tiles t_i. Each edge of t will be subdivided into several subedges (with their own colors), such that the subdivision only depends on the color, and edges of opposite colors are divided in a way such that the resulting subedges match. For the data of how the deflated tiles glue together, we have a perfect pairing on the set \{\text {subedges of $t$}\} \sqcup \coprod _i \{\text {edges of $t_i$}\} such that the paired edges are compatible. Specifically, if two edges of deflated tiles, or two subedges of t are matched, they must be of opposite colors; if an edge of a deflated tile is matched with a subedge, they must share colors.
In addition to this, the subdivision must also match geometrically, but we shall not give its full definition here, as it suffices to recognize this intuitively.

For convenience, if two edges \epsilon and \epsilon ' have opposite colors, we use the same label for their subedges in a substitution. This simplifies the presentation since we avoid using a conversion look-up table, but requires us to be somewhat careful in assigning labels. In general, we can assign the subedge labels counterclockwise for edges with positive colors, and clockwise for negative colors.

On a first read, the definition of a substitution system may seem to contain some surprising cases. Why is it possible to have subedges paired against each other? This is because there are examples where this occurs. Even though we can often transform our substitution systems to avoid this, it allows for very economic presentations, and thus more efficient algorithms. In addition, accounting for these cases reveals some symmetry in the recursive structure of our programs.
Now we have enough terminology to define the fundamental object in our algorithms, the Conway signature.

Assume we have a substitution system with unique inflation. For a tile t in a tiling, we can inflate the tiling to find t as a subtile in an inflated tile t_1. If we give a unique number to each subtile in a substitution system, we can write this as t \xrightarrow {n_1} t_1, meaning t is the n_1-th subtile. This process can be repeated, generating an infinite path \Sigma = t \xrightarrow {n_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {n_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots where t, t_1, t_2, \dots are prototile labels, and n_i are subtile labels. This path \Sigma is called the Conway signature of the tile. We will also consider the case of a finite patch of tiling, in which case the Conway signature will be a finite path.

Computationally, this can be regarded as an infinite stream of data. In lazy languages like Haskell, we can directly implement this as an infinite list. Notice that there will be a lot of sharing as the signature of different tiles will often share a tail. So if your language does not have lazy functional data structures, you need to make sure sharing has a low cost.
It is straightforward to write down a recursive algorithm for calculating neighborhood Conway signatures. It has an elegantly symmetric structure.

Suppose we have a substitution system. Given the Conway signature of a tile t and an edge label \epsilon of that tile, we can calculate the signature of the neighboring tile t' and the edge label \epsilon ' of t' that coincides with \epsilon . This is implemented by mutual recursion with another auxiliary function. Given the signature of a tile and a subedge of that tile under deflation, it calculates the signature of the subtile t' we will arrive in if we cross the subedge inwards, and the edge label of t' corresponding to the input subedge.
This second function is non-trivial, because for some substitution systems, crossing inwards through a subedge may lead us immediately out through another subedge, if they are pinched together. See .

The neighborhood function is as follows. Suppose we have a Conway signature t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and an edge \epsilon _0 of the tile t_0. We consult the pairing of edges as specified in the substitution system. This has two cases.

fr:ul.fr:li: Suppose the edge \epsilon _0 (of the subtile labelled s_1) is paired with another edge \epsilon '_0 of the subtile numbered s'_1. Then since these two subtiles are neighbors already, we can directly output the signature t'_0 \xrightarrow {s'_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and the edge label \epsilon '_0, where t'_0 is the prototile type of the s'_1 subtile in t_1.

Suppose the edge is paired with a subedge \sigma _1 of an edge \epsilon _1 in the tile t_1. Then we need to exit the tile t_1 through this edge. We recursively call this function on the Conway signature t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} \cdots and the edge label \epsilon _1. Suppose the algorithm determines that its neighbor has the Conway signature \Delta and the edge label \epsilon '_1. We then invoke the auxiliary function to calculate the subtile we would obtain if we enter \Delta from the subedge \sigma _1 of its edge \epsilon '_1, and we can return its output, tail-recursively.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the auxiliary function, suppose again we have a signature \Sigma = t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and we have specified an edge \epsilon _0 of the tile t_0, together with one of its subedges \sigma _0. Again, we look up what is paired, in the substitution of t_0, with the subedge \sigma _0.

fr:ul.fr:li: Suppose the result is an edge \epsilon _{-1} in the subtile s_0 of t_0. Then we can output t_{-1} \xrightarrow {s_{0}} t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \longrightarrow \cdots and the edge label \epsilon _{-1}, where t_{-1} is the prototile label corresponding to the subtile s_0.

Suppose the result is another subedge \sigma '_0 of the edge \epsilon '_0. Then we call the neighborhood function on the Conway signature \Sigma and the edge label \epsilon '_0. Let the result be the signature \Delta and the edge \epsilon ''_0. Now we just need to call the auxiliary function on \Delta with the subedge \sigma '_0 of \epsilon ''_0, and return its result.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If we are dealing with finite Conway signatures, then the algorithm should raise an exception if at any point the path is too short. This signals that it has reached the boundary of the finite patch of tiles. Otherwise, the neighborhood function should always output a Conway path of equal length.

With this algorithm, we can generate any patch of tiling by repeatedly asking the program what the neighbor of each tile is, until the generated tiles fill the area, like growing a crystal. We just need a Conway signature to begin with. Some methods to create this initial seed are discussed in (...), each designed for a different purpose.

Unfortunately, this recursive algorithm actually doesn’t generate all the possible tilings in our substitution system. This is surprising, because it seems that Conway signatures uniquely determines the arrangement of tiles we are in, if we suppose inflation is always unique. However, the definition of substitution tilings has a secret catch.

Given a set \mathscr {S} of (possibly incomplete) tilings of the plane, its hull \overline {\mathscr {S}} is the set of complete tilings T, such that given an arbitrarily large disk D \subseteq \mathbb {R}^2, the patch of tiles in T intersecting D appears inside a tiling T' \in \mathscr {S}, up to translation.

When we talk about the set of, say, Penrose tilings, we are actually referring to the hull of all the iterated deflations of a single tile. Each of those iterated deflations only cover a finite portion of the plane, and an actual tiling completely covers the plane in a way that any finite portion of it can be found in one of those deflations.

In our , we are assuming the entire tiling comes from a single iterated deflation, so when we attempt to calculate the neighbor of a tile, we first repeatedly inflate the tiles so that both of them are contained in one giant tile, and then deflate back down. However, an actual tiling may only look like an iterated deflation on each finite patch, so it may be the case that no amount of inflation brings the neighbor into the same supertile.

Consider the substitution system of Penrose rhombs. Take the cyclic Conway signature \Sigma _0 = \text {Thin} \xrightarrow {\text {left}} \text {Thin} \xrightarrow {\text {left}} \cdots This repeatedly selects the thin 36\degree subtile on the left. No matter how many times we use the substitution rules, the selected thin rhomb will not have a neighbor.
(To do: reproduce the image here)

However, after any finite length of this Conway signature, we can replace the rest of the signature with \cdots \text {Thin} \xrightarrow {\text {top}} \text {Thick} \xrightarrow {\text {left}} \text {Thick}\xrightarrow {\text {left}} \text {Thick}\xrightarrow {\text {left}} \cdots and this will cover the whole neighborhood. Therefore, for any finite radius, there is a patch of tiling that looks like it can be described by \Sigma _0 in that radius. As the radius tends to infinity, these patches converge to a single complete tiling whose center tile has Conway signature \Sigma _0, which is therefore in the hull of Penrose tilings.

As an analogy, the neighborhood algorithm behaves like the algorithm adding 1 to an integer in decimal notation. Suppose it encounters \cdots 999 + 1, then it will scan forwards until it reads a digit d that is not 9. Then it performs the carry and outputs [d+1]00\cdots 00. However, the tilings are only required to locally look like iterated deflations. In this analogy, we have numbers that only locally look like an “actual” integer, so it is possible to have infinitely many digit 9s. On the other hand, we don’t actually need to read ahead: as soon as we see a 9, we can go ahead and output a 0, since that is the only possible result! In , we shall make this precise, in the context of Conway signatures.

fr:title.text: The structure of neighbor Conway signatures

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The structure of neighbor Conway signatures

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The recursive neighborhood algorithm computes neighboring tiles in some iterated deflation of a supertile, and we wish to extend this function to work with the hull of these deflations, i.e. the full set of possible Penrose tilings. It is first useful to consider a binary relation, instead of a function, between Conway signatures.

Given a substitution system, two infinite Conway signatures \Sigma _1, \Sigma _2, and an edge label \epsilon _1, \epsilon _2 for each signature, we define a neighborhood relation, denoted as \Sigma _1 \xrightleftharpoons [\epsilon _2]{\epsilon _1} \Sigma _2. It holds if and only if, for every natural number n, there exists finite signatures \Sigma '_1, \Sigma '_2 that agree with \Sigma _1 and \Sigma _2 at the first n places, and the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma '_1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma '_2, \epsilon _2).
Note that this relation is not necessarily symmetric, total or functional.

Essentially the definition says that, if you look at a finite patch of tiles, it is always plausible that this can (hence the \exists quantifier, not \forall ) be extended to a larger patch where they are neighbors in an iterated deflation of one single tile. This also leaves open the possibility that there may be multiple different possible Conway signatures for a neighbor, which is why we opted to consider a binary relation, instead of a function.
Next, we need some general theory relating these infinite objects to finite ones. For this we make some definitions.

Consider the alphabet \Delta where each symbol is either of the form (\text {tile label }t, \text {edge label of }t), (\text {tile label }t, \text {subtile label of }t). We define a language \mathcal {L} on \Delta \times \Delta , representing a binary relation on \Delta ^* between words of the same length. Let \Sigma = t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} \cdots \xrightarrow {s_n} t_n be a finite Conway signature and \epsilon be an edge label of the corresponding tile. We regard this as a word (t_0, \epsilon )(t_1, s_1) \cdots (t_n, s_n) over the alphabet \Delta . Suppose the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma _1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma _2, \epsilon _2), then the two corresponding words can be zipped together to form a word over \Delta \times \Delta . We define the set of all such words as the language of neighborhood relation \mathcal {L}.

Furthermore, consider the set of tile labels \mathrm {T}. We define another language \mathcal {L}^+, called the augmented language of neighborhood relation, over the alphabet (\Delta \times \Delta ) \sqcup \mathrm {T}. Notice that if the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma _1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma _2, \epsilon _2), the two signatures always share the last prototile label t_n. We append the symbol t_n to the corresponding word in \mathcal {L}, and define \mathcal {L}^+ to be all the words of this form.

We define the augmented language in this way because it has a very important property, which will be useful later. With this definition in hand, we see that is actually a well-known construction in \omega -languages, i.e. languages with infinitely long words.

Given an alphabet \Sigma and a language \mathcal {L} \subseteq \Sigma ^*, its limit is an \omega -language \lim \mathcal {L} \subseteq \Sigma ^\omega containing the words w such that all finite prefixes of w can be extended to a word in \mathcal {L}.

Obviously, we have \lim \mathcal {L} = \lim \mathcal {L}^+ since a terminating symbol can’t affect the limit. Limits are nice because they can be recognized by deterministic finite state machines (also known as deterministic Büchi machines, to emphasize they are for \omega -languages).

fr:title.text: Limits of regular languages are deterministic Büchi recognizable

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits of regular languages are deterministic Büchi recognizable

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a regular language \mathcal {L}, its limit \lim \mathcal {L} can be recognized by a deterministic Büchi automaton, by simply regarding a DFA for \mathcal {L} as a Büchi automaton. In fact, every deterministic Büchi recognizable \omega -language is of this form.

Now, there is one single hypothesis that I am not able to get rid of. It doesn’t even need a constructive proof, as we will later give a construction that provably satisfies the hypothesis given that it is true.
For any substitution system, the language of neighborhood relation is regular.
As promised, we reveal the special property that \mathcal {L}^+ enjoys.

A deterministic automaton is bideterministic if it has only one accepting state, and if reversing all transitions and swapping the starting and accepting state produces another deterministic automaton.
A regular language is reversible if it can be recognized by a bideterministic DFA, which is equivalent to requiring the Myhill–Nerode automaton to be bideterministic.
Note that there are stronger and weaker notions of reversible regular languages in the literature, with inconsistent names.
Induction of reversible languages
