fr:title.text: Quasi-isomorphism between projective complexes is homotopy equivalence

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quasi-isomorphism between projective complexes is homotopy equivalence

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given two chain complexes C_\bullet , D_\bullet and a quasi-isomorphism f : C_\bullet \to D_\bullet , if all the objects involved are projective, then f has a homotopy inverse.

Consider the mapping cone \operatorname {Cone}(f), whose objects are given by \operatorname {Cone}_n (f) = C_{n-1} \oplus D_n. Since direct sums of projective objects are still projective, \operatorname {Cone}(f) is also a chain complex of projective objects. We have a short exact sequence of chain complexes 0 \to D_\bullet \to \operatorname {Cone}_\bullet (f) \to C_{\bullet - 1} \to 0, which induces a long exact sequence of homologies, in which the boundary maps H_n (C) \to H_n (D) are given by f.
Curiously, there is an extra equation here, showing that h^{CD} is not a chain map and giving the exact deviation.

fr:title.text: A superphantom map KU H Z

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A superphantom map KU \to \Sigma H \mathbb Z

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the complex K-theory spectrum KU, the integral homology is given by H_{2n} (K U) = \mathbb {Q}, and the odd degrees are zero. Therefore H^1 (KU) = \operatorname {Ext}(\mathbb {Q}, \mathbb {Z}) by the universal coefficient theorem. Pick a non-zero map \theta : KU \to \Sigma H \mathbb {Z}. We claim it is a cohomology superphantom map.

Consider any space X. Cohomology classes \omega \in KU(X) correspond to (formal sums of) vector bundles on X, and the image in H^1 (X; \mathbb {Z}) assigns a characteristic class \theta (\omega ) for each vector bundle. Consider the universal example, the tautological bundle \tau on BU(n). All vector bundles come from the pullback of a map f : X \to BU(n), and the characteristic class will also come from the pullback f^* \theta (\tau ) of the universal characteristic class. However, H^1 (BU(n)) = 0, so this cohomology operation vanishes on all spaces.

There are a few different concepts of ghosts and phantoms in homotopy theory.
In the unstable world, a ghost map f : X \to Y between CW-complexes is a non-zero map that cannot be detected via homotopy groups (or more generally finite CW-complexes), i.e. all compositions Z \to X \to Y with Z finite are null-homotopic.
In the stable case, a map between spectra is a (co)homology phantom if all the induced maps on the (co)homology of finite CW-complexes is zero.
A stronger condition is given by requiring the induced maps on the (co)homology of all spaces (equivalently, all suspension spectra, possibly with some desuspensions) are zero. This is called a superphantom map.
We can have an even stronger condition, requiring triviality on all spectra. Let’s temporarily call this a (co)homology ultraphantom map.

Obviously, when we pass to the stable world, ghost maps becomes cohomology phantom maps. By Spanier–Whitehead duality, we can replace finite CW-complexes with their duals, thus establishing that the cohomology and homology phantom maps are identical. On the other hand, it is impossible to have a cohomology ultraphantom map f : X \to Y, since the identity cohomology class \iota : X \to X will be sent to zero, meaning f itself is null-homotopic. Similarly, a ghost map cannot give a cohomology superphantom map.

Since homology preserves filtered colimits, every homology superphantom map comes from a phantom map, and vice versa. Similarly, we can extend this to ultraphantom maps. Therefore these three concepts collapse into one, and the phrases phantom maps and superphantom maps suffices to unambiguously refer to all of these concepts.

fr:title.text: Phantom maps K({Q}, n) K({Z}, n+1)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Phantom maps K(\mathbb {Q}, n) \to K(\mathbb {Z}, n+1)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By construction, the homotopy classes of maps f : K(\mathbb {Q}, n) \to K(\mathbb {Z}, n+1) corresponds to elements \operatorname {Ext}(\mathbb {Q}, \mathbb {Z}). However, any map from a finite CW-complex into K(\mathbb {Q}, n) lifts to K(A, n) where A \subseteq \mathbb {Q} is finitely generated. But \operatorname {Ext}(A, \mathbb {Z}) = 0. This means f is a ghost, and consequently a phantom H \mathbb {Q} \to \Sigma H \mathbb {Z}.

fr:title.text: A superphantom map KU H Z

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A superphantom map KU \to \Sigma H \mathbb Z

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the complex K-theory spectrum KU, the integral homology is given by H_{2n} (K U) = \mathbb {Q}, and the odd degrees are zero. Therefore H^1 (KU) = \operatorname {Ext}(\mathbb {Q}, \mathbb {Z}) by the universal coefficient theorem. Pick a non-zero map \theta : KU \to \Sigma H \mathbb {Z}. We claim it is a cohomology superphantom map.

Consider any space X. Cohomology classes \omega \in KU(X) correspond to (formal sums of) vector bundles on X, and the image in H^1 (X; \mathbb {Z}) assigns a characteristic class \theta (\omega ) for each vector bundle. Consider the universal example, the tautological bundle \tau on BU(n). All vector bundles come from the pullback of a map f : X \to BU(n), and the characteristic class will also come from the pullback f^* \theta (\tau ) of the universal characteristic class. However, H^1 (BU(n)) = 0, so this cohomology operation vanishes on all spaces.

fr:title.text: Phantom maps K({Q}, n) K({Z}, n+1)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Phantom maps K(\mathbb {Q}, n) \to K(\mathbb {Z}, n+1)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By construction, the homotopy classes of maps f : K(\mathbb {Q}, n) \to K(\mathbb {Z}, n+1) corresponds to elements \operatorname {Ext}(\mathbb {Q}, \mathbb {Z}). However, any map from a finite CW-complex into K(\mathbb {Q}, n) lifts to K(A, n) where A \subseteq \mathbb {Q} is finitely generated. But \operatorname {Ext}(A, \mathbb {Z}) = 0. This means f is a ghost, and consequently a phantom H \mathbb {Q} \to \Sigma H \mathbb {Z}.

Given a locally small category \mathcal {C}, the yoneda embedding \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathcal {C} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) has four consecutive left adjoints iff \mathcal {C} is equivalent to \mathsf {Set}. See and for examples with one and two left adjoints, and for the four consecutive left adjoint over \mathsf {Set}.
In a total category, we can freely compose waves with arrows or other waves associatively.

Let us use f, g, h etc. for arrows, and u, v, w for waves. The composition f \mathbin {\circ } w \mathbin {\circ } g and its associativity is given by functoriality of waves. We define the composition of two waves by w \mathbin {\circ } v = \bar {w} \mathbin {\circ } v = w \mathbin {\circ } \bar {v}, which we can verify are equal by a calculation. Then u \mathbin {\circ } v \mathbin {\circ } w = \bar {u} \mathbin {\circ } v \mathbin {\circ } \bar {w} is associative.

Given a total category \mathcal {C}, it is a totally distributive category, iff the wave functor \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \dashv \operatorname {?} with an obvious counit \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \to \textrm {Id}, and iff the natural transform \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \to \textrm {Id} is invertible (the inverse will be the unit of the adjunction). In this case, the composition operator \int ^B \operatorname {wave}(B, C) \times \operatorname {wave}(A, B) \to \operatorname {wave}(A, C) of waves is invertible, up to sliding B around with arrows.
The category of small sets \mathsf {Set} is a total category, and so is \mathsf {Set}^\textrm {op}.

The first claim is a special case of . For the second claim, we use the limit characterization of cototality. Given a functor F : \mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Set}, we need to show the existence of \lim (\pi _F : \int F \to \mathsf {Set}). We claim that this is a subset of \mathcal {P}(F(\mathcal {P}(1))), i.e. we need to show that all the other components of an element in the limit are determined by the F(\mathcal {P}(1)) component. This is true because \mathcal {P}(1) is a cogenerator of \mathsf {Set}.

fr:title.text: Presheaf category over a small category is totally distributive

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Presheaf category over a small category is totally distributive

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A presheaf category over a small categroy \mathcal {C} is not only a total category, as proven in , but also a totally distributive category. This is because \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* has a left adjoint \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}_! a.k.a. the left Kan extension. We need to be careful because \mathsf {Psh}^2 (\mathcal {C}) is not locally small. The colimit formula for (pointwise) left Kan extensions is \operatorname {Lan}_{\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}} F(G) = \operatorname *{colim}_{p : \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X) \leftarrow G} F(X) where F, G \in \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) and X ranges over \mathcal {C}. (The reversal of arrow comes from the contravariance of presheaves.) This is still a small limit, so it is fine.

For the special case of \mathcal {C} = 1, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* : \mathsf {Psh}(\mathsf {Set}) \to \mathsf {Set} evaluates at 1. We get \operatorname {Lan}_{1} F(G) = \operatorname *{colim}_{1 \leftarrow G} F = F where F, G are sets. So the left adjoint is the constant functor functor \Delta , such that \Delta (X)(Y) = X.

The yoneda embedding \mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathsf {Set}) has a chain of four left adjoints 0_!\dashv \operatorname {ev}_0\dashv \Delta \dashv \operatorname {ev}_1\dashv \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} where 0_! (X)(Y) = X \times \hom (Y, 0).

The first three functors appear in and . The next adjoint \operatorname {ev}_0\dashv \Delta is dual to \Delta \dashv \operatorname {ev}_1, and it is also not hard to see manually. Finally, a natural transform 0_! (X) \to F consists of a single map X \to F(0), since all the other components are empty functions, hence trivial. Moreover, 0_! does not preserve products, so no more left adjoints are possible.

For a total category \mathcal {C}, we can define a functor \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathcal {C} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) that will serve as the double left adjoint of \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} iff the category is actually a totally distributive category. Since \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)(Y) = \hom (Y, X), we similarly define \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)(Y) = \operatorname {wave}(Y, X), and call the elements waves.

A wave w : Y \rightsquigarrow X is defined by a family of maps \hom (X, \operatorname {?} F) \to F(Y) natural in the presheaf F, where \operatorname {?} \dashv \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}. This is intuitively a categorification of the “way way below” relation Y \lll X in posets. If we take F = \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X), then we get an actual arrow \bar {w} : Y \to X. This defines a natural transform \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \to \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}, or equivalently \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \to \textrm {Id}.

fr:title.text: Presheaf category over a small category is total

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Presheaf category over a small category is total

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a small category \mathcal {C}, the locally small category \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) is a total category. In fact, the left adjoint to \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) \to \mathsf {Psh}^2(\mathcal {C}) is given by \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^*, i.e. the map that sends the double presheaf R to the presheaf X \mapsto R(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)).

To see this, we compute \hom _{\mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C})}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* R, F) to be the set of natural transforms that assign an arrow R(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)) \to F(X) for every object X. On the other hand, \hom _{\mathsf {Psh}^2(\mathcal {C})}(R, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} F) assigns an arrow R(G) \to \hom (G, F) for every presheaf G. The latter obviously have a map to the former, and we need to prove that any map in the former uniquely extends to the latter. G is a colimit of representables, so we can decompose \hom (G, F) into a limit of F(X). The naturality requirement then forces a unique value for each component.

In particular, if \mathcal {C} = 0, we get a left adjoint for the yoneda embedding \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathsf {Psh}(0) = 1 \to \mathsf {Psh}(1) = \mathsf {Set}. In this case \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} is essentially picking out the terminal object, and \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* is the unique functor. We can also take \mathcal {C} = 1, then \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathsf {Set}), and the left adjoint is F \mapsto F(1), evaluating the presheaf at the singleton set. It is also possible to calculate this directly via the colimit characterization of total cocompleteness.

fr:title.text: A total category is cocomplete and complete

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A total category is cocomplete and complete

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A total category is (small) cocomplete and complete. This shows totality is a strong form of cocompleteness, strong enough to behave like cocompleteness in posets, which also guarantees completeness.

Using the colimit characterization of totality, given a small diagram D : I \to \mathcal {C}, we can attempt to construct a presheaf F assigning F(X) the set of all objects in I mapped to X, and require that F(f) sends the object i \in I to j \in I if there is an arrow in the colimit diagram going from j to i that is mapped to f (multiple of the same arrow appearing in the colimit diagram doesn’t matter). But this leaves many functoriality requirements unsatisfied, so we freely add elements to F for them. This will create additional arrows in the corresponding colimit diagram that end at existing objects, so the colimit is still unaffected.

It is nice to have a more uniform description of this. If we have a single object A in the diagram, then the resulting presheaf will be exactly \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A). For a general diagram, we need a colimit to glue all the \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)’s together, and it’s not hard to see the required colimit is exactly \operatorname *{colim} \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} \mathbin {\circ } D, where D is the diagram functor.

For completeness, we use the same technique in proving cocomplete posets are complete: we can define \sup U as \inf \{x \mid x \ge U\}. In the same spirit, given a diagram U : I \to \mathcal {C}, we consider a locally small category whose objects are (X, F) where X \in \mathcal {C} and F : \operatorname {const}(X) \to U, and the morphisms are obvious. This is equivalently the comma category \operatorname {const} \downarrow U. The limit is then the same as the colimit of the functor (X, F) \mapsto X. But this functor can be constructed as \pi _G : \int G \to \mathcal {C} for some presheaf G, namely G(Y) = \hom (\operatorname {const}(Y), U). Therefore the argument goes through despite involving large colimits.

fr:title.text: Adjoint functor theorem for total categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoint functor theorem for total categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given any cocontinuous functor F from a total category \mathcal {C} to a locally small category \mathcal {D}, it has a right adjoint without additional assumptions.

The idea of the adjoint functor theorem is to construct the large colimit G(X) = \operatorname *{colim}_{FY \to X} Y. But this is exactly the kind of colimits mentioned in . We can construct the right adjoint by letting G(X) = \operatorname {?}(F^* \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)).
A total category is cartesian closed iff the left adjoint \operatorname {?} preserves binary products.

If the total category \mathcal {C} is cartesian closed, then \hom (F, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A^B)) = \hom (\operatorname {?}(F), A^B) = \hom (\operatorname {?}(F) \times B, A). On the other hand, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} preserves exponentials, and therefore \begin {aligned} \hom (F, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A^B)) &= \hom (F, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)^{\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B)}) \\ &= \hom (F \times \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B), \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)) \\ &= \hom (\operatorname {?}(F \times \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B)), A). \end {aligned} Hence we need the canonical map \operatorname {?}(F \times \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B)) \to \operatorname {?}(F) \times \operatorname {?}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B)) \to \operatorname {?}(F) \times B to be an isomorphism. But the counit \operatorname {?}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B)) \to B is already an isomorphism since \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} is a fully faithful right adjoint. Therefore this happens iff \operatorname {?}(F \times G) \to \operatorname {?}(F) \times \operatorname {?}(G) is an isomorphism for all representable presheaves G. Now presheaves are (large) colimits of representables, and being left adjoints, both \operatorname {?} and binary products preserve all colimits whatsoever. So we can extend this to all presheaves G.

On the other hand, if \operatorname {?} preserves binary products, then (A \times -) must be cocontinuous: Every small colimit diagram D : I \to \mathcal {C} can be equivalently represented as a presheaf F = \operatorname *{colim}_{i \in I} \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} D(i) with colimit \operatorname {?}(F). The presheaf for the product diagram A \times D(i) is \operatorname *{colim}_{i \in I} \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A \times D(i)), which is equivalent to F \times \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A), since \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} preserves product and product is cocontinuous in presheaves. (A naive way to construct the presheaf for the product diagram is F \mathbin {\circ } (A \times -), but this doesn’t quite work because of contravariance.) We have \operatorname {?}(F \times \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)) = \operatorname {?}(F) \times A, showing cocontinuity. Therefore by the adjoint functor theorem for total categories, we know exponentials must exist.

Given a locally small category \mathcal {C}, if the Yoneda embedding \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathcal {C} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) has a left adjoint \operatorname {?}, then we say teh category is total, or totally cocomplete. This is equivalent to requiring the colimit of \pi _F : \int F \to \mathcal {C} to exist for every presheaf F, which is the value of L(F). Notice that \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} being fully faithful implies the counit \operatorname {?}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)) \to A is an isomorphism.

The universal property of the colimit says \hom (\operatorname *{colim} \pi _F, X) \cong \lim _{(Y, p)} \hom (Y, X). Using the characterization of limits in \mathsf {Set}, an element in this set maps F(Y) to \hom (Y, X) for each Y naturally, which is exactly \hom (F, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)).

Given a total category, if the left adjoint \operatorname {?} has a further left adjoint, then it preserves all limits. Since \operatorname {?} is a kind of colimit operator, this condition is a strong version of complete distributivity. Therefore we call the category totally distributive.

fr:title.text: Sheafification as a higher inductive type

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sheafification as a higher inductive type

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator, we can define sheafification, and more generally \infty -sheafification, as a higher inductive type. Intuitively, it can be thought of as extending a monad on propositions to arbitrary types. The sheafification X^{++} of X is generated by an inclusion map \eta : X \to X^{++}, a free extension of the bind operator \beta : \forall (p : \Omega ), j(p) \to (p \to X^{++}) \to X^{++} and the only relevant monad law \beta (u, \lambda \_. v) = v. We can equivalently state this as g = \beta (-, f) being the unique function satisfying \forall (\star : p), g(\eta (\star )) = f(\star ), which is closer to the usual sheaf requirement.

As we said, (-)^{++} is a monad with the unit given by \eta . The binding operator is implemented by \begin {aligned} \beta (\eta (x), f) &= f(x) \\ \beta (\beta (\star , g), f) &= \beta (\star , \lambda x. \beta (g(x), f)) \end {aligned} where we used the same name \beta for all the bind operators.

Given a locale X, if we have a map f : Y \to X such that the preimage of every sublocale is closed, and every map g : Z \to X satisfying the same property factors through f uniquely, then we say Y is the dissolution of X.

We can give a concrete construction of the dissolution locale. Given a locale X, we define a new locale X_d whose poset of closeds is the poset of sublocales of X. Given a sublocale \alpha of X, we write V(\alpha ) for the corresponding closed in X_d. The structure map \iota : X_d \to X is given by sending every closed to the corresponding closed sublocale.

We prove the universal property of dissolution. Suppose there is another map f : Y \to X such that the preimage of sublocales are closed. We can define a map \pi : Y \to X_d by letting it send V(\alpha ) to the preimage of \alpha under f, considered as a closed. This map is unique since the preimage of every closed is fixed by the commutativity requirement.
Classically, for every locale X, the dissolution locale X_d has the same points as X.

We want to prove the canonical map \hom (1, X_d) \to \hom (1, X) is a bijection. All the sublocales of 1 are closed since there are only two of them. Therefore for every map 1 \to X, the preimage of every sublocale is trivially closed, and therefore it factors through X_d \to X uniquely. This implies the desired bijection.

A ribbon Hopf algebra is defined as a braided Hopf algebra H together with an element v of the algebra, such that \begin {aligned} \epsilon (v) &= 1 \\ \Delta (v) &= (\tau (R) R)^{-1} (v \otimes v) \\ S(v) &= v. \end {aligned}

The antipode of a Hopf algebra provides us with the structure to define dual representations. Given a representation V of H, we can define an action on V^* by (h \cdot f)(v) = f(S(h) \cdot v). This works out because the antipode is an anti-homomorphism. This induces a contravariant functor on the category of representations.

Categorically speaking, for V to have a right dual structure on V^*, we need structure maps 1 \to V \otimes V^* and V^* \otimes V \to 1. This requires V to be finite dimensional. In this case, we need to verify the obvious map from linear algebra is indeed a module homomorphism. This essentially follows from x_{(1)} \cdot S(x_{(2)}) = \epsilon (x) = S(x_{(1)}) \cdot x_{(2)}.

However, this module structure on V^* cannot be taken as the left dual of V! The reason is the evaluation map v \otimes f \mapsto f(v) doesn’t respect multiplication, since S(x_{(2)}) x_{(1)} is not necessarily equal to S(x_{(1)}) \cdot x_{(2)}. Instead we need another module structure on the same vector space, using S^{-1} in place of S. Let this representation be denoted as {^{\vee }V}, and for clarity we denote the right dual module as V^{\vee }.

Hopf algebras already have the concept of dual modules, and for finite dimensional modules, the dual is a categorical dual. For a braided Hopf algebra, the modules further form a braided monoidal category. Hence to form ribbon categories, we only need to implement the twisting natural isomorphism \theta .

Similar to the discussion in , we attempt to represent this isomorphism via an invertible element v. For it to commute with every module homomorphism, this element needs to be in the center of the algebra. The equation \theta _1 = \textrm {id} translates to \epsilon (v) = 1. For \theta _{X^{\vee }} = (\theta _X)^{\vee }, we need S(v) = v. Finally we have the equation \beta _{Y, X} \mathbin {\circ } \beta _{X, Y} \mathbin {\circ } \theta _{X \otimes Y} = \theta _X \otimes \theta _Y, which translates to \Delta (v) = (\tau (R) R)^{-1} (v \otimes v). This defines ribbon Hopf algebras.

A ribbon Hopf algebra is defined as a braided Hopf algebra H together with an element v of the algebra, such that \begin {aligned} \epsilon (v) &= 1 \\ \Delta (v) &= (\tau (R) R)^{-1} (v \otimes v) \\ S(v) &= v. \end {aligned}

Given a Hopf algebra H with invertible antipode, we construct another Hopf algebra D(H) on the vector space (H^\textrm {op})^\circ \otimes H, where H^\textrm {op} is the opposite Hopf algebra, and H^\circ is the Sweedler dual. We define the unit to be 1 \otimes 1, the counit as \epsilon (f \otimes a) = \epsilon (a) \cdot f(1), and the antipode S^D(f \otimes a) = S^\circ (f) \otimes S(a). The comultiplication \Delta ^D (f \otimes a) = \sum _{i j} (g_i \otimes b_j) \otimes (h_i \otimes c_j) where \Delta ^\circ (f) = \sum _i g_i \otimes h_i, and \Delta (a) = \sum _j b_j \otimes c_j. We let (f \otimes a) \cdot (g \otimes b) = f \cdot (x \mapsto g(S^{-1}(a_{(3)}) x a_{(1)})) \otimes a_{(2)} b. We can regard (H^\textrm {op})^\circ as a subalgebra of D(H) via f \mapsto f \otimes 1, and similarly for H with a \mapsto 1 \otimes a. Then we can write f a = f \otimes a, and the algebra structure is given by the straightening formula a f = (x \mapsto f(S^{-1}(a_{(3)})x a_{(1)})) a_{(2)}. This is the Drinfeld double of H.

For a finite dimensional Hopf algebra H, the double D(H) is braided, with the universal R-matrix given by R = \sum _{i} (1 \otimes e_i) \otimes (e^i \otimes 1) where e_i is a set of basis of H, and e^i is the dual basis in H^\circ .

Given a vector space V, we can equip V with the structure of an associative algebra, given by multilinear maps V^{\otimes m} \to V, usually written as juxtaposition. We can also equip V with the structure of an coassociative coalgebra, given by maps V \to V^{\otimes m}. We write the comultiplication as \Delta : V \to V \otimes V, and the counit \epsilon : V \to \Bbbk . When multiplication and comultiplication distribute over each other, we call the structure a bialgebra.

In this case, we can write linear maps in a seemingly non-linear fashion, by using the comultiplication to duplicate variables. For example f(x) = x_{(1)} x_{(2)} stands for the composition of \Delta : V \to V \otimes V and the multiplication map V \otimes V \to V. Note that the duplicated variables needs to be numbered when the comultiplication is not cocommutative. This is called Sweedler’s notation.

Furthermore, suppose there is a map S : V \to V called the antipode such that f(x) = x_{(1)} S(x_{(2)}) and g(x) = S(x_{(1)}) x_{(2)} are equal to the map h(x) = \epsilon (x) \cdot 1. We also write the antipode as x^{-1} where x \in V. But note that if f : V \to V is a linear map, the notation f^{-1} instead stands for the usual set-theoretic inverse map.

Given a Hopf algebra, the antipode is unique, essentially by the same argument for the uniqueness of inverses in group theory. It is also injective, which means for a finite dimensional algebra, it is automatically invertible as a linear map. However, this is not necessarily the case for infinite dimensional Hopf algebras.

The obvious candidate for the inverse, S^{-1} = S, is not necessarily valid. The usual group theoretic proof that the inverse is an involution requires either swapping the label of duplicated variables, or swapping the left and right terms of a multiplication. This means (x^{-1})^{-1} = x holds only for cocommutative or commutative Hopf algebras.

Given an arbitrary Hopf algebra H, the monoidal category of its representations may not have a braiding. The obvious braiding \tau that simply swaps the two factors works for cocommutative Hopf algebras only. Therefore we need to add suitable structures on H so that we can select an appropriate map V \otimes W \to W \otimes V between representations that commute with the H-action.

Since the twisting map \tau : V \otimes W \to W \otimes V does not work, without loss of generality we could consider modifying it by precomposing an automorphism V \otimes W \to V \otimes W. (We can also consider a postcomposition, which is equivalent.) But we need to specify such an automorphism for every representation V, W. So the simplest way to achieve this is to select an invertible element R \in H \otimes H, and demand that the automorphism is given by left multiplication by this element. This has the added benefit that naturality is now automatic, since homomorphisms are required to commute with left multiplication.

Let R = \sum _i r_i \otimes s_i, then the automorphism is given by v \otimes w \mapsto R\cdot (v \otimes w) = \sum _i \rho _V (r_i) v \otimes \rho _V (s_i) w. For this to create a braiding homomorphism, we need \rho _{W \otimes V}(a) \tau (R \cdot (v \otimes w)) = \tau (R \cdot \rho _{V \otimes W}(a) (v \otimes w)). Let \Delta (a) = \sum _j a_j \otimes b_j, then this equation expands to \sum _{i,j} \rho _W (a_j s_i) w \otimes \rho _V (b_j r_i) v = \sum _{i,j} \rho _W (s_i b_j) w \otimes \rho _V (r_i a_j) v. Since this needs to hold for all V and W, we can conclude that \sum _{i,j} a_j s_i \otimes b_j r_i = \sum _{i,j} s_i b_j \otimes r_i a_j. We can write this more succinctly if we write the natural algebra structure on H \otimes H as juxtaposition: \Delta (a) \tau (R) = \tau (R \Delta (a)). Since \tau is an involution as a linear map, and R is an invertible element of H \otimes H, we can rewrite this as \tau (\Delta (a)) = R\Delta (a) R^{-1}.

We also need to satisfy the equation for braiding. This basically says that for V \otimes (W_1 \otimes \cdots \otimes W_n), braiding V to the right in one step is equal to composing the braiding for V and W_i for each i, up to suitable associators. The same for braiding to the left. Abstract nonsense tells us it suffices to verify n = 2. We can perform a calculation similar to what we did above, and it results in the equation (\textrm {id} \otimes \Delta )(R) = R_{13} R_{12} where \textrm {id} \otimes \Delta : H \otimes H \to H \otimes (H \otimes H) applies the comultiplication to the second factor, and R_{12} : H^{\otimes 3} is the identity on the third factor, only acting on the first two factors. Braiding in the other direction amounts to (\Delta \otimes \textrm {id})(R) = R_{13} R_{23}. We have now arrived at the definition of a braided Hopf algebra.

The antipode of a Hopf algebra provides us with the structure to define dual representations. Given a representation V of H, we can define an action on V^* by (h \cdot f)(v) = f(S(h) \cdot v). This works out because the antipode is an anti-homomorphism. This induces a contravariant functor on the category of representations.

Categorically speaking, for V to have a right dual structure on V^*, we need structure maps 1 \to V \otimes V^* and V^* \otimes V \to 1. This requires V to be finite dimensional. In this case, we need to verify the obvious map from linear algebra is indeed a module homomorphism. This essentially follows from x_{(1)} \cdot S(x_{(2)}) = \epsilon (x) = S(x_{(1)}) \cdot x_{(2)}.

However, this module structure on V^* cannot be taken as the left dual of V! The reason is the evaluation map v \otimes f \mapsto f(v) doesn’t respect multiplication, since S(x_{(2)}) x_{(1)} is not necessarily equal to S(x_{(1)}) \cdot x_{(2)}. Instead we need another module structure on the same vector space, using S^{-1} in place of S. Let this representation be denoted as {^{\vee }V}, and for clarity we denote the right dual module as V^{\vee }.

Given an coalgebra A, the linear dual A^* consists of linear maps A \to \Bbbk . The coalgebra structure becomes a algebra structure on the dual: suppose \Delta (a) = \sum _i b_i \otimes c_i, then (f \cdot g)(a) = \sum _i f(b_i) g(c_i). However, it is not clear how we can take the dual coalgebra of an algebra, unless the algebra is finite dimensional.

Suppose we have a algebra A, we can take a subspace A^\circ \subseteq A^* consisting of functionals f such that a \otimes b \mapsto f(a b) decomposes as a finite sum of terms of the form g_i (a) h_i (b). This is called the Sweedler dual, or restricted dual. Now we can define comultiplication \Delta ^\circ by \sum _i g_i \otimes h_i. This doesn’t depend on the choice of g_i and h_i by bilinearity.

Furthermore, if A has an antipode S : A \to A making it a Hopf algebra, this automatically induces S^* : A^* \to A^* by S^* (f)(a) = f(S(a)). And suppose f \in A^\circ , then f(S(a b)) = f(S(b) S(a)), and we can verify S^*(f) is also in A^\circ . This provides an antipode to A^\circ too, which is invertible if S is invertible.

Given a Hopf algebra H with invertible antipode, we can replace the comultiplication \Delta by \tau \mathbin {\circ } \Delta , where \tau switches the two factors of tensor product, and the antipode by its inverse. This produces another Hopf algebra called its opposite.
Alternatively, we can replace the multiplication instead. We can also simultaneously replace the multiplication and comultiplication but not the antipode. This forms a square of opposition.

fr:title.text: Symmetric monoidal product on representations of cocommutative Hopf algebras

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Symmetric monoidal product on representations of cocommutative Hopf algebras

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose a Hopf algebra H is cocommutative, i.e. \Delta (a) \in H \otimes H is invariant under swapping the two factors, then the monoidal structure of H-representations defined in is actually symmetric. The braiding is simply given by the braiding of vector space tensor products, and we only need to show that it is a homomorphism of representations. This immediately follows from the definition.

fr:title.text: Tensor product and dual of Hopf algebra representations

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Tensor product and dual of Hopf algebra representations

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a Hopf algebra H, its representations (i.e. left modules of H considered as an associative algebra) have a monoidal structure. The underlying vector space is given by the tensor product of vector spaces, and the module structure \rho _{V_1 \otimes V_2} : H \otimes (V_1 \otimes V_2) \to V_1 \otimes V_2 is given by the comultiplication: Suppose \Delta (a) = \sum _i b_i \otimes c_i, then \rho _{V_1 \otimes V_2} (a) (x \otimes y) = \sum _i \rho _{V_1}(b_i) x \otimes \rho _{V_2}(c_i) y. Or in Sweedler’s notation, \rho _{V_1} (a_{(1)}) x \otimes \rho _{V_2} (a_{(2)}) x. Similarly, the antipode provides a module structure on the dual vector space: (\rho _{V^*} (a) \alpha )(x) = \alpha (\rho _V (a^{-1}) x). Hence the category of H-representations is monoidal closed.
A bounded holomorphic function f defined on the entire complex plane must be constant.

Consider the integral formulas for derivatives in f'(z) = \frac {1}{2 \pi i} \int _\gamma \frac {f(w)}{(w - z)^2} \operatorname {d}\mathclose {w}, where \gamma is some circle of radius r enclosing z. Since f(w) is bounded, the integrand is bounded by C r^{-2} for some constant C. But this means the derivative is bounded by O(r^{-1}). Since the function is holomorphic on the entire plane, r can be arbitrary large, which means f'(z) = 0.
When f is not defined on the entire plane, this method still gives an upper bound on the magnitude of the derivative |f^{(n)} (z)| \le M n! \cdot r^{-n}. This is known as the Cauchy estimate.

Given a holomorphic function f on an open set, it has derivatives of arbitrarily high order, given by the explicit formula f^{(n)}(z) = \frac {n!}{2 \pi i} \int _\gamma \frac {f(w)}{(w - z)^{n + 1}} \operatorname {d}\mathclose {w}, where \gamma is a circle around z contained in the open set.

Given a holomorphic function f, and a point a such that a disk containing a lies within the domain of f, we have f(a) = \frac {1}{2 \pi i} \int _{\gamma } \frac {f(z)}{z - a} \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}, where \gamma is the boundary of the disk.
Separating the two terms in the integral, we are left to prove \int _\gamma \frac {\operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}}{z - a} = 2 \pi i. This can be done by looking up integral tables.

From the definition of a holomorphic function, we can immediately start exploring some of its consequences. It turns out that complex differentiability is much stronger than real differentiability, and the following theorem gives a first glimpse.

Intuitively, for a function f to be complex differentiable, we need (f(z + \epsilon ) - f(z)) / \epsilon to converge to the same value for both real and imaginary \epsilon . The real and imaginary parts of this equality correspond to the two Cauchy–Riemann equations.
We can write these equations formally in a more suggestive way.

Considering \mathbb {C} as a two dimensional real space, the tangent space at a point (take zero as an example) is \mathbb {R}^2. It comes equipped with a complex structure J sending \partial _x \mapsto \partial _y and \partial _y \mapsto -\partial _x, acting as multiplication by i. A (real) smooth function \mathbb {C} \to \mathbb {C} then has a Jacobian at each point, which is a 2 \times 2 matrix M. The Cauchy–Riemann equations then imposes a condition on this matrix, which can be written as J M = M J.

It is sometimes convenient to complexify this vector space \mathbb {R}^2 \otimes \mathbb {C} = \mathbb {C}^2. This corresponds to formally allowing the x and y components to be complex-valued. This is because we often want to view a complex function as a scalar field on a two dimensional (real) manifold, but the scalar can be complex. So to do calculus with these scalars, naturally the associated tangent and cotangent spaces needs to be complexified. J now has two eigenvalues i and -i, corresponding to the holomorphic and antiholomorphic subspaces.

Of course this only happens in the tangent space, and the coordinate functions cannot be extended to complex domains. The Jacobian then extends to the complexified tangent space. This space has an alternative basis \partial _z = \frac {1}{2}(\partial _x - i \partial _y) \quad \text {and}\quad \partial _{\bar {z}} = \frac {1}{2}(\partial _x + i \partial _y). This has the dual basis on 1-forms, given by \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} = \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} + i \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y} and \operatorname {d}\mathclose {\bar {z}} = \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} - i \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y}. In this basis, the Cauchy–Riemann equation can be written as \partial _{\bar {z}} f = 0.
This gives a heuristic procedure for finding the harmonic conjugate of a function.

fr:title.text: Formal method to calculate the harmonic conjugate

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Formal method to calculate the harmonic conjugate

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose u is the real part of some holomorphic function f. Then we have 2 u(x, y) = f(x + i y) + \overline {f(x + i y)}. If we could extend the coordinates x and y to complex numbers, then similar to what happens in the tangent space, we have a (z, \bar {z}) coordinate system with z = x + i y and \bar {z} = x - i y acting as independent variables in \mathbb {C}^2.

By the Cauchy–Riemann equations, f(x + i y) should only depend on z and \overline {f(x + i y)} should only depend on \bar {z}. So we can write the latter as another function g(\bar {z}). Since 2 u = f(z) + g(\bar {z}), we can look at the value at the point (z, \bar {z}) = (\alpha , 0) where \alpha \in \mathbb {C}, which corresponds to x = \alpha / 2 and y = - i \alpha / 2. Hence 2 u(\alpha / 2, - i \alpha / 2) = f(\alpha ) + g(0), which determines f up to some constant. This method requires an analytic expression of u(x, y), so it makes sense to plug in complex numbers into x and y.
The Cauchy–Riemann equations is very suggestive of the assumption in Green’s theorem in (real) multi-variable calculus. This prompts us to define notions of line integrals on the complex plane.

Given a complex function f and a piecewise differentiable curve \gamma : [a, b] \to \mathbb {C}, we can define a few different kinds of line integrals along \gamma . The first is the naive line integral, given by directly integrating \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. But this depends on the parametrization of the curve.

We can also define the complex line integral, which is independent of parametrization: \int _\gamma f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} = \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \gamma '(t) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. Following the convention of complexifying the (co)tangent space, we can write \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} = \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} + i \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y}. This leads to the evident definition of integrating against \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x}, given by \int _\gamma f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} = \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \operatorname {Re}\gamma '(t) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. And \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y} is defined similarly.

Finally, there is also the arc length integral, which is given by \int _\gamma f(z) \left |\operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}\right | = \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \left |\gamma '(t)\right | \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. In particular, integrating the constant function 1 gives the length of the curve.

fr:title.text: Integral of holomorphic function does not depend on path

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Integral of holomorphic function does not depend on path

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a holomorphic function f on an open set U, the complex line integral of f along two homotopic paths are equal. This is a direct consequence of the Cauchy–Riemann equations and Green’s theorem. However, we need to be careful with the hypotheses when we have low differentiability.

We can write down the idea more succinctly using the notation of \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} and \operatorname {d}\mathclose {\bar {z}}. We are integrating along f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}, but this is an closed differential, since \operatorname {d} (f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}) = - \partial _{\bar {z}} f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} \wedge \operatorname {d}\mathclose {\bar {z}} = 0. This shows the power of complexifying the tangent space.

This applies when f is complex differentiable at every point, since complex differentiability implies (real) Fréchet differentiability (i.e. f can be approximated by a linear map at each point), which suffices for Green’s theorem to apply. It also suffices that f is the derivative of another holomorphic function, and it is Riemann integrable. In this case we can simply apply the fundamental theorem of calculus.

In fact, is still applicable when the function f is holomorphic except at isolated points z_i, but f(z) is o(|z - z_i|^{-1}). This can be seen by making the curve loop around a small disk of radius r around these bad points. The loop integral goes to zero as O(r) o(r^{-1}) = o(1), and so does not affect the result. This is important because there is a function in the definition of complex differentiability, namely g(z) = \frac {f(z) - f(a)}{z - a}. And so the integral of g(z) along a circle around a must be zero. Now we can separate out the second term f(a) \cdot \int _\gamma 1/(z - a) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}. This can be directly computed to be 2 \pi i f(a). This proves the following formula.

Given a holomorphic function f, and a point a such that a disk containing a lies within the domain of f, we have f(a) = \frac {1}{2 \pi i} \int _{\gamma } \frac {f(z)}{z - a} \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}, where \gamma is the boundary of the disk.
Separating the two terms in the integral, we are left to prove \int _\gamma \frac {\operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}}{z - a} = 2 \pi i. This can be done by looking up integral tables.
The integral of 1/(z-a) can in fact be computed more generally. This also means we can use more general closed curves in , which will be useful in calculations.
Given a piecewise differentiable closed curve \gamma not passing through a, the complex line integral \int _\gamma \frac {1}{z - a} \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} is always a multiple of 2 \pi i.

Intuitively, 1/(z-a) is the derivative of the function \log (z - a). But formalizing this is difficult, since logarithms are not single-valued, so what happens near the branch cuts is not clear. However, we can avoid this by considering the inverse function \exp instead.

Let the path be parametrized by the interval [0,1] for convenience. Consider the function g(t) = \int _0^t \frac {\gamma '(t)}{\gamma (t) - a} \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. By the intuition above, we expect g(t) \xlongequal {?} \log (\gamma (t) - a) + C. So we instead consider h(t) = \exp (g(t))/(\gamma (t) - a) and prove it is a constant. This can be verified by differentiation, using the chain rule and the fundamental theorem of calculus.

Of course, \gamma is only piecewise differentiable. So h(t) is only constant on each piece. But in addition, h(t) is continuous on the entire curve, so it must be globally constant. Moreover, since \gamma is a loop, we have \gamma (0) = \gamma (1), and since h(0) = h(1), we can deduce 1 = \exp (g(0)) = \exp (g(1)), which means the integral g(1) is a multiple of 2 \pi i as desired.

fr:title.text: Integral of holomorphic function does not depend on path

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Integral of holomorphic function does not depend on path

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a holomorphic function f on an open set U, the complex line integral of f along two homotopic paths are equal. This is a direct consequence of the Cauchy–Riemann equations and Green’s theorem. However, we need to be careful with the hypotheses when we have low differentiability.

Given a complex function f and a piecewise differentiable curve \gamma : [a, b] \to \mathbb {C}, we can define a few different kinds of line integrals along \gamma . The first is the naive line integral, given by directly integrating \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. But this depends on the parametrization of the curve.

We can also define the complex line integral, which is independent of parametrization: \int _\gamma f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} = \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \gamma '(t) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. Following the convention of complexifying the (co)tangent space, we can write \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} = \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} + i \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y}. This leads to the evident definition of integrating against \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x}, given by \int _\gamma f(z) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} = \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \operatorname {Re}\gamma '(t) \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. And \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y} is defined similarly.

Finally, there is also the arc length integral, which is given by \int _\gamma f(z) \left |\operatorname {d}\mathclose {z}\right | = \int _a^b f(\gamma (t)) \left |\gamma '(t)\right | \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. In particular, integrating the constant function 1 gives the length of the curve.

Intuitively, for a function f to be complex differentiable, we need (f(z + \epsilon ) - f(z)) / \epsilon to converge to the same value for both real and imaginary \epsilon . The real and imaginary parts of this equality correspond to the two Cauchy–Riemann equations.

Considering \mathbb {C} as a two dimensional real space, the tangent space at a point (take zero as an example) is \mathbb {R}^2. It comes equipped with a complex structure J sending \partial _x \mapsto \partial _y and \partial _y \mapsto -\partial _x, acting as multiplication by i. A (real) smooth function \mathbb {C} \to \mathbb {C} then has a Jacobian at each point, which is a 2 \times 2 matrix M. The Cauchy–Riemann equations then imposes a condition on this matrix, which can be written as J M = M J.

It is sometimes convenient to complexify this vector space \mathbb {R}^2 \otimes \mathbb {C} = \mathbb {C}^2. This corresponds to formally allowing the x and y components to be complex-valued. This is because we often want to view a complex function as a scalar field on a two dimensional (real) manifold, but the scalar can be complex. So to do calculus with these scalars, naturally the associated tangent and cotangent spaces needs to be complexified. J now has two eigenvalues i and -i, corresponding to the holomorphic and antiholomorphic subspaces.

Of course this only happens in the tangent space, and the coordinate functions cannot be extended to complex domains. The Jacobian then extends to the complexified tangent space. This space has an alternative basis \partial _z = \frac {1}{2}(\partial _x - i \partial _y) \quad \text {and}\quad \partial _{\bar {z}} = \frac {1}{2}(\partial _x + i \partial _y). This has the dual basis on 1-forms, given by \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} = \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} + i \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y} and \operatorname {d}\mathclose {\bar {z}} = \operatorname {d}\mathclose {x} - i \operatorname {d}\mathclose {y}. In this basis, the Cauchy–Riemann equation can be written as \partial _{\bar {z}} f = 0.
This gives a heuristic procedure for finding the harmonic conjugate of a function.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Formal method to calculate the harmonic conjugate

fr:title.text: Formal method to calculate the harmonic conjugate

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Formal method to calculate the harmonic conjugate

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose u is the real part of some holomorphic function f. Then we have 2 u(x, y) = f(x + i y) + \overline {f(x + i y)}. If we could extend the coordinates x and y to complex numbers, then similar to what happens in the tangent space, we have a (z, \bar {z}) coordinate system with z = x + i y and \bar {z} = x - i y acting as independent variables in \mathbb {C}^2.

By the Cauchy–Riemann equations, f(x + i y) should only depend on z and \overline {f(x + i y)} should only depend on \bar {z}. So we can write the latter as another function g(\bar {z}). Since 2 u = f(z) + g(\bar {z}), we can look at the value at the point (z, \bar {z}) = (\alpha , 0) where \alpha \in \mathbb {C}, which corresponds to x = \alpha / 2 and y = - i \alpha / 2. Given a Riemannian manifold M with metric g, if the sectional curvature at a point \operatorname {sec}(v, w) is bounded between \kappa _1 and \kappa _2, we can make some bounds on the curvature tensor, essentially by linear algebra. This is discussed in section 6 from Sur quelques variétés riemanniennes suffisamment pincées.

Take an orthonormal set of vectors X_i, X_j, X_k, X_l. The sectional curvature is given by \operatorname {sec}(X_i, X_j) = R(X_i, X_j, X_j, X_i). Let a^2 + b^2 = c^2 + d^2 = 1, then we can generate a family of inequalities \kappa _1 < \operatorname {sec}(a X_i + b X_j, c X_k + d X_l) < \kappa _2. Let us write \operatorname {sec}_{i j} for \operatorname {sec}(X_i, X_j). Then we can expand the definition to get \begin {aligned} \kappa _1 &< a^2 c^2 \operatorname {sec}_{ik} &&+ 2 a^2 c d R_{ikli} &&+ a^2 d^2 \operatorname {sec}_{il} \\ &+ 2 a b c^2 R_{ikkj} &&+ 2 a b c d (R_{iklj} + R_{ilkj}) &&+ 2 a b d^2 R_{illj} \\ &+ b^2 c^2 \operatorname {sec}_{jk} &&+ 2 b^2 c d R_{jklj} &&+ b^2 d^2 \operatorname {sec}_{jl} &< \kappa _2. \end {aligned}

In the case (c, d) = (1, 0), the inequality expands to \kappa _1 < a^2 \operatorname {sec}_{i k} + 2 a b R_{ikkj} + b^2 \operatorname {sec}_{j k} < \kappa _2. From the AM–GM inequality, we can take the appropriate signs for a and b to get |R_{ikkj}| < \sqrt {(\operatorname {sec}_{i k} - \kappa _1)(\operatorname {sec}_{j k} - \kappa _1)} and |R_{ikkj}| < \sqrt {(\operatorname {sec}_{i k} - \kappa _2)(\operatorname {sec}_{j k} - \kappa _2)}. We can also just take a = b = \pm 1/\sqrt {2} to get coarser bounds.

Now for the general case. Taking b = ±b', d = ±d' and summing the two inequalities, we cancel out four of the terms. Now take a \mapsto -a and permute (j, k, l) \mapsto (l, j, k) to get a new inequality. Taking the sum we now have \begin {aligned} 2\kappa _1 <&\quad a^2 c^2 (\operatorname {sec}_{ik} + \operatorname {sec}_{ij}) + a^2 d^2 (\operatorname {sec}_{il} + \operatorname {sec}_{ik}) & \\ & + b^2 c^2 (\operatorname {sec}_{jk} + \operatorname {sec}_{lj}) + b^2 d^2 (\operatorname {sec}_{jl} + \operatorname {sec}_{lk}) & \\ & + 2 a b c d (R_{iklj} + R_{ilkj} - R_{ijkl} - R_{ikjl}) & < 2\kappa _2. \end {aligned} The last term can be reduced to -6 abcd R_{ljki} by the symmetries of the curvature tensor. AM–GM inequality now gives a rich set of bounds. Finally, we take a = b = c = d = 1/\sqrt {2} up to a sign. Let S be the sum of all the sectional curvatures involved. Then we have 2\kappa _1 < 2 S ± \frac {3}{2} |R_{ljki}| < 2\kappa _2. Therefore we have |R_{ljki}| < \frac {2}{3} (\kappa _2 - \kappa _1). And of course, if we start with non-strict pinching, we get analogous non-strict bounds.

fr:title.text: Alternative presentation of the localic spectrum of a commutative ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Alternative presentation of the localic spectrum of a commutative ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can give a presentation of the localic spectrum of a commutative ring via posites. The locale \operatorname {Spec} R is generated by symbols D(f), where f \in R. We write D(f) \subseteq D(g) if g \mid f^n for some n. We also require that, given D(f_i) \subseteq D(g), if g^n = \sum _i c_i f_i for some coefficients c_i, then \bigcup _i D(f_i) = D(g).

Given a Grothendieck coverage on \mathcal {C}, we can induce a coverage on any subcategory \mathcal {D} by restricting the covering sieves to the subcategory. It is dense iff every object in \mathcal {C} can be covered by morphisms from objects in \mathcal {D}, and for every morphism f : X \to Y in \mathcal {C} such that X, Y are in \mathcal {D}, we can cover X in \mathcal {D} such that the compositions with f are still in \mathcal {D}.

We can define sheaves on dense subsites, and they uniquely extend to the entire site. This induces an equivalence of sheaf categories. For locales with the canonical coverage, full dense subsites are exactly topological bases.

Given a scheme S, the underlying locale (equipped with the canonical coverage) has a dense subsite whose objects are affine opens, and morphisms are distinguished open subspaces. Note that this isn’t a full subcategory, since there exist affine open subspaces that are not distinguished.

Since schemes are covered by affine schemes, and distinguished opens form a basis in the localic spectrum of a commutative ring, every open in S is covered by affine opens. On the other hand, Nike’s trick guarantees the condition on morphisms for dense subsites.

Consider the affine scheme X = \operatorname {Spec} \mathbb {C}[x, y]/(y^2 - x^3) \simeq \operatorname {Spec} \mathbb {C}[t^2, t^3], which is a degenerate cubic curve. We can remove the point (1,1), giving the open U = D(x-1) \cup D(y-1). We claim that U is an affine subscheme but it is not of the form D(f).

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs} \usetikzlibrary{decorations.pathreplacing}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We first prove it is not distinguished. Suppose U = D(f), we can choose a representative of f in \mathbb {C}[x, y]. Now substituting x \mapsto t^2, y \mapsto t^3, we need f(t^2, t^3) to vanish only at t = 1. Hence this is a polynomial \lambda (t - 1)^n. But this is impossible since it has a linear term, which cannot be produced by t^2 and t^3.

Now we need to show U is affine. The coordinate ring is actually given by the subring R of \mathbb {C}[t, (t-1)^{-1}] such that the derivative at zero is zero, which can be verified by gluing. By we have a canonical map U \to \operatorname {Spec} R. Now restricting to the open D(t^2 - 1) and D(t^3 - 1) respectively, the two schemes are affine. By verifying the isomorphism of global sections, we see that they are isomorphic. Note that (t^3 - 1) \cdot \frac {t^2}{t - 1} - (t^2 - 1) \cdot \left (\frac {t^3}{t - 1} + 1\right ) = 1. So these cover \operatorname {Spec} R (this is where it differs from ), and we have our isomorphism.
The open subscheme of \mathbb {A}_{\mathbb {C}}^2 = \operatorname {Spec} \mathbb {C}[x, y] given by removing the origin, or equivalently the open D(x) \cup D(y), is not affine.

We just need to prove the affinification is not an isomorphism. Consider the global sections of the structure sheaf, which comes from the pullback of \mathbb {C}[x, y, x^{-1}] and \mathbb {C}[x, y, y^{-1}] over \mathbb {C}[x, y, x^{-1}, y^{-1}]. The result is simply \mathbb {C}[x, y]. We can compute that the affinification map is the inclusion map into \mathbb {A}_{\mathbb {C}}^2. This cannot be an isomorphism because the underlying space is different.

Given a scheme S, we can produce a best affine approximation S \to S' for it. This serves as the adjoint unit of the adjunction of global section and \operatorname {Spec}. Here we give a construction from the ground up.

We define S' = \operatorname {Spec} \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X). For the map S \to S', we define the preimage of the distinguished open D(f) to be the non-vanishing open of f \in \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X), which is defined on each affine subscheme as the distinguished open of f. This is obviously continuous. We can then pull back a section f/g by considering them as an element of \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X) and restricting them.
A scheme is affine iff the affinification is an isomorphism. This is a formal consequence that affine schemes form a full subcategory of schemes.

Connective spectra can be thought of as \infty -groups that are maximally commutative, within the confines of operadic algebras. This manifests as the little cubes operad, being able to freely move around in high dimensional space.

However, H \mathbb {Z}-modules can be seen as even more commutative. Consider the equation x + x = x + x swapping the two arguments. It is impossible to talk about the behavior of this path because in operads variables cannot repeat. Hence this might not be homotopic to the trivial path, and indeed it is not in the sphere spectrum \mathbb {S} — this path is given by the non-trivial element in the second stable homotopy group \mathbb Z / 2 \mathbb Z. H \mathbb {Z}-modules requires further that given n identical elements, the space of different possible sums is contractible.

fr:title.text: Additive functor is faithful iff it reflects exactness

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive functor is faithful iff it reflects exactness

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An additive functor is faithful iff it reflects exactness.

This implies that faithful additive functors reflects kernels, cokernels, etc. Note that faithful functors need not preserve kernels or cokernels. This is because we can take the direct sum of a faithful functor with an arbitrary additive functor and the result is still faithful. The second summand can behave badly.

We first prove the forward implication. Given a sequence X \xrightarrow {f} Y \xrightarrow {g} Z whose image under F is exact, by faithfulness F(g \mathbin {\circ } f) = 0 implies g \mathbin {\circ } f = 0. Now we wish to prove the composite \ker g \to Y \to \operatorname {coker} f is zero. We can decompose its image under F as F(\ker g) \to \ker Fg \to FY \to \operatorname {coker} Ff \to F(\operatorname {coker} f). But the inner two morphisms compose to zero, so by faithfulness we get our result.

On the other hand, suppose F reflects exactness. Given a morphism f : X \to Y, suppose Ff = 0, then FX \xrightarrow {\textrm {id}} FX \xrightarrow {Ff} FY is exact. Hence X \xrightarrow {\textrm {id}} X \xrightarrow {f} Y is also exact, so f = 0 too.

Homology H_\bullet as a functor from the category of chain complexes (bounded from below) of \mathcal {A} to \mathcal {A} is a homological universal \delta -functor. Dually, cohomology is a cohomological universal \delta -functor.

Every chain complex injects into its cone, whose cohomology is zero. So cohomology is effaceable. Dually every chain complex is a quotient of its cocone, hence homology is coeffaceable. Therefore by we finish the proof.

Given a cohomological \delta -functor T^\bullet , if each T^n for n > 0 is effaceable, then it is a universal \delta -functor. Dually, if a homological \delta -functor is coeffaceable, then it is universal.

Given an object X, consider the exact sequence given by effaceability 0 \longrightarrow X \longrightarrow I \longrightarrow Y \longrightarrow 0. Then we have a long exact sequence 0 \to T^0 X \to T^0 I \to T^0 Y \xrightarrow {\delta } T^1 X \xrightarrow {0} T^1 I. and the rest breaks into infinitely many short exact sequences 0 \to T^{n+1} I \to T^{n+1} Y \to T^{n+2} X \to 0.

For independence, we first prove that if two effacements X \to I, X \to I' are connected by a morphism I \to I', then the resulting transformations are equal. This is essentially the same as the proof of naturality, except \varphi is replaced with \textrm {id}. Now any two effacements are connected by a zigzag, since we can take the diagonal X \to I \times I' and project out.

An additive functor F : \mathcal {A} \to \mathcal {B} is effaceable iff for each object X in \mathcal {A}, there exists a monomorphism X \to I whose image under F is zero. Dually, it is coeffaceable iff for each object X there exists an epimorphism P \to X whose image under F is zero.
An abelian category has enough injectives if every object has a monomorphism into an injective. Dually, it has enough projectives if every object is a quotient of a projective.

Given a pointed space (X, x_0), the James construction J X is the homotopy coherent version of a free monoid (a.k.a. the type of lists or strings), such that the point acts as the neutral element. The space is constructed inductively from a point [] \in JX. For each point y \in X and \vec {x} \in JX, we have another point y \mathbin {::} \vec {x} \in JX. And finally for \vec {x} \in JX we adjoin a path from x_0 \mathbin {::} \vec {x} to \vec {x}.
There is a map X \to JX given by x \mapsto x \mathbin {::} [], written as [x] for short.

fr:title.text: Synthetic characterization of the James construction

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Synthetic characterization of the James construction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The James construction JX of a connected pointed space X is equivalent to the space \Omega \Sigma X, which is very intriguing considering that \Omega \Sigma X actually has a group structure up to homotopy. Its synthetic proof is enlightening.

Since X is connected, for each x there exists a path back to the point x_0. (x_0 \mathbin {::} -) = \textrm {id} is an auto-equivalence on JX, so noting that being an equivalence is a proposition, (x \mathbin {::} -) is too, for all x.

Now consider a family of spaces indexed by \Sigma X. For the north and south pole we assign the space JX, and for each path between the poles induced by an element x \in X, we assign the equivalence (x \mathbin {::} -), which by univalence induces a path. The total space of this kind of families is characterized by the flattening lemma, in Section 6.12 of the HoTT book. In this case, we have two copies of JX such that for each x \in X, \vec {x} \in JX we connect \vec {x} in the former copy to x \mathbin {::} \vec {x} in the latter with a path.

The total space is in fact contractible. Take the center to be [] in the north copy of JX. For any other point \vec {x} in the north copy, we can move to the south copy via the neutral element (x_0 \mathbin {::} -), go along the path (x_0 \mathbin {::} -) = \textrm {id} in the south copy, and go back to the north copy removing the first entry. This allows us to recursively reach the empty list. For an element in the south copy, we can similarly move through (x_0 \mathbin {::} -) to the north copy and continue there.

We still need to arrange for the contraction of the paths. This can be easily seen by drawing a diagram of all the boundaries, though tedious to completely write down. This then establishes that we have a fiber sequence JX \to 1 \to \Sigma X, where the middle term is the total space constructed above, and JX is the fiber on top of the north pole of \Sigma X. Hence JX must be equivalent to the loop space \Omega \Sigma X.

fr:title.text: Right adjoint of exact functor preserves injectives

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoint of exact functor preserves injectives

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose F \dashv R, F is exact and I is an injective, then R(I) is also an injective. Dually, if L \dashv F, F is exact and P is a projective, then L(P) is also a projective.

Notice that the right adjoint preserves products, and so is additive. We need to show that \hom (-, R(I)) is exact, which amounts to saying the composition of F and \hom (-, I) is exact, which is true because both are exact.

fr:title.text: Abelian groups are injective iff divisible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Abelian groups are injective iff divisible

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An abelian group G is injective iff it is divisible, i.e. for element g \in G and positive integer n, there exists a (non-unique) solution of nx = g.

In one direction, suppose the group is injective, then the map \mathbb {Z} \to G defined by k \mapsto k g can be extended along the monomorphism (n \times -) : \mathbb {Z} \to \mathbb {Z}. This provides the division.

On the other hand, suppose divisibility holds. Given a morphism f : A \to G and an injection A \hookrightarrow B, we extend f to B by Zorn's lemma. Consider the poset of homomorphisms extending f to some subgroup of B. Given a chain in this poset, we can take the union to create an upper bound. And it is non-empty since f is an element. Hence it has a maximal element \phi . Suppose it is defined on B' \subsetneq B, then there is an element b \in B not in B'. Suppose n b \notin B' for all non-zero integers n, then we can define a larger homomorphism on B + \mathbb {Z} b, contradicting the maximality. Suppose there is some n b \in B', then by divisibility we can assign \phi (b) a division of \phi (n b) by n. This too contradicts maximality.

A homological \delta -functor is a sequence of additive functors T_n : \mathcal {A} \to \mathcal {B} between abelian categories, with the convention that T_n = 0 for n < 0. For every short exact sequence 0 \to X \to Y \to Z \to 0 in \mathcal {A}, we have a connecting map \delta _n : T_n(Z) \to T_{n-1}(X), such that this assignment is natural in the exact sequence.

Similarly, a cohomological \delta -functor can be defined with \delta ^n : T^n(Z) \to T^{n+1}(X). Notice that cohomology does not imply contravariance here. These also have contravariant versions, by replacing \mathcal {A} with \mathcal {A}^\textrm {op}.

The \delta -functors between two abelian categories form a displayed category over the category of additive functors (or we can restrict it to right exact functors for homological \delta -functors). Under this setup, the definition of a universal \delta -functor can be expressed abstractly as a “relative” kind of terminal object or initial object. It is an object X displayed over x such that \hom _f (Y, X) = 1 for every Y and f.
Given two \delta -functors, a morphism between them is given by a sequence of natural transformations f_n : T_n \to S_n that additionally commutes with \delta .

Given a homological \delta -functor T_n, it is universal if given any other \delta -functor S_n and a natural transformation S_0 \to T_0 at degree 0, it can be uniquely extended to a morphism of \delta -functors. Dually, we can reverse the arrows to get the definition of a universal cohomological \delta -functor.
In an abelian category, an object I is injective iff every morphism B \to I can be extended along monomorphisms B \rightarrowtail A. Equivalently, it is a projective object in the dual category.

fr:title.text: Projective modules are direct summands of free modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Projective modules are direct summands of free modules

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the abelian category of modules over a ring R, the projective object modules are exactly the modules that appear as a direct summand of some free module P \oplus Q = R^{\oplus n}.
A free module evidently projective. If P is a direct summand of a projective module Q, then we can extend any map P \to B to Q by zero. Then the projectivity of Q implies that of P.

On the other hand, suppose P is projective, then we have an epimorphism R^{\oplus |P|} \twoheadrightarrow P. The identity map P \to P lifts against this epimorphism to a splitting of it, hence P is its direct summand.

Since \hom (P, -) preserves limits, by it is left exact. Similarly \hom (-, I) is right exact. Therefore we naturally want to find out when \hom (P, -) is right exact. We only need to guarantee that \hom (P, -) preserves epimorphisms. This can be unpackaged to the following definition.

In an abelian category, an object P is projective iff for every morphism P \to B can be lifted through an epimorphism A \twoheadrightarrow B, i.e. there exists a (non-unique) morphism P \to A making the triangle commute.

Projective objects are defined to capture a key property of free objects. For an arbitrary abelian group P, lifting a map P \to B through an epimorphism requires us to pick a lifting for every generator, such that the relations between the generators still hold after lifting. If such a thing can always be done, then we may say that the relations, or tangling between generators are practically non-existent. A projective object can thus be reguarded as generated by some elements with zero or undetectable “tangling”.
As an example, consider the projective objects in the category of modules. We can give a nice characterization of projective modules.

fr:title.text: Projective modules are direct summands of free modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Projective modules are direct summands of free modules

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the abelian category of modules over a ring R, the projective object modules are exactly the modules that appear as a direct summand of some free module P \oplus Q = R^{\oplus n}.
A free module evidently projective. If P is a direct summand of a projective module Q, then we can extend any map P \to B to Q by zero. Then the projectivity of Q implies that of P.

On the other hand, suppose P is projective, then we have an epimorphism R^{\oplus |P|} \twoheadrightarrow P. The identity map P \to P lifts against this epimorphism to a splitting of it, hence P is its direct summand.
Dually, we have the definition of injective objects, which make \hom (-, I) exact.
In an abelian category, an object I is injective iff every morphism B \to I can be extended along monomorphisms B \rightarrowtail A. Equivalently, it is a projective object in the dual category.
As an example, we characterize injective abelian groups. Similar characterizations can be done for modules over principal ideal domains.

fr:title.text: Abelian groups are injective iff divisible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Abelian groups are injective iff divisible

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An abelian group G is injective iff it is divisible, i.e. for element g \in G and positive integer n, there exists a (non-unique) solution of nx = g.

In one direction, suppose the group is injective, then the map \mathbb {Z} \to G defined by k \mapsto k g can be extended along the monomorphism (n \times -) : \mathbb {Z} \to \mathbb {Z}. This provides the division.

On the other hand, suppose divisibility holds. Given a morphism f : A \to G and an injection A \hookrightarrow B, we extend f to B by Zorn's lemma. Consider the poset of homomorphisms extending f to some subgroup of B. Given a chain in this poset, we can take the union to create an upper bound. And it is non-empty since f is an element. Hence it has a maximal element \phi . Suppose it is defined on B' \subsetneq B, then there is an element b \in B not in B'. Suppose n b \notin B' for all non-zero integers n, then we can define a larger homomorphism on B + \mathbb {Z} b, contradicting the maximality. Suppose there is some n b \in B', then by divisibility we can assign \phi (b) a division of \phi (n b) by n. This too contradicts maximality.
Given a ring R, a \mathbb {Z}-grading on R is the same as a \mathbf {G}_{m}-action on \operatorname {Spec} R, where \mathbf {G}_{m} is the scheme of invertible elements.

A morphism \rho : \mathbf {G}_{m} \times \operatorname {Spec} R \to \operatorname {Spec} R is given by a ring homomorphism R \to \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \otimes R \cong R[x, x^{-1}]. Composing with the identity 1 \to \mathbf {G}_{m}, we are required that R \xrightarrow {\rho } R[x, x^{-1}] \xrightarrow {x \mapsto 1} R is the identity.

We can regard R[x, x^{-1}] as generated by (n, r) \in \mathbb {Z} \times R, where the first number is the degree of x and the second number is the coefficient. So they are under the relations (n, r) + (n, r') = (n, r + r'), and (n, r) \cdot (m, r') = (n + m, r r'). \rho (r) is a sum of finitely many (n, r_n), and the identity law requires the sum of r_n is r again. This decomposes r into its components in each degree.

Next, the associativity law essentially requires that, if (n, r_n) is a summand of some \rho (r), then \rho (r_n) = (n, r_n). So this is indeed a well-defined decomposition. Furthermore, \rho being a ring homomorphism guarantees that the grading respects multiplication and addition.

We define the scheme \mathbf {G}_{m} as \operatorname {Spec} \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}]. It can be characterized by the points \hom (\mathbf {G}_{m}, \operatorname {Spec} R) = R^\times being the units of R. This scheme has a group structure. Since it is affine, 1 \to \mathbf {G}_{m} is given by the ring homomorphism \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \to \mathbb Z sending x to 1. The product map is given by a ring homomorphism \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \otimes \mathbb {Z}[y, y^{-1}] \to \mathbb {Z}[z, z^{-1}] (where we renamed the variables for clarity) sending x \otimes y to z. The inverse map \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \to \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] sends x to x^{-1}.

fr:title.text: Coalgebra structure on algebraic cellular complexes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coalgebra structure on algebraic cellular complexes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: There is a natural (differential graded) coalgebra structure on algebraic cellular complexes. Recall that the tensor unit is \mathbb {Z} concentrated at degree 0. The counit map sends every 0-dimensional cell to 1, and everything else to zero. The comultiplication is induced by the composition (... need simplicial?)

fr:title.text: Abelian group structure on the W-bar construction

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Abelian group structure on the W-bar construction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose the simplicial group G is abelian, then the W-bar construction still has an abelian group structure, by multiplication element-wise.

The associated simplicial fiber bundle of twisted products admits a simpler description. Suppose we have simplicial sets F, B, a simplicial group G with an action G \times F \to F and a twisting function \tau on B. The associated twisted product B \times _\tau F is defined exactly the same as twisted products, except we replace the factor G with F. This still makes sense, because we can interpret the multiplication \tau (b) \cdot \partial _n f as the G-action.

In particular, if we consider G as a simplicial set with a G-action on the left via multiplication, then the associated twisted product B \times _\tau G is exactly the same as the twisted product B \times _\tau G, which explains our identical notation.

Given a simplicial principal fiber bundle p : E \to B with simplicial group G, and a simplicial set F with a group action G \times F \to F, we can construct a fiber bundle with fiber F, such that the twisting behaviour is described by the principal bundle p.

We consider a group action on E \times F, by g \cdot (e, f) = (e \cdot g^{-1}, g \cdot f). This action is clearly free. Suppose the quotient simplicial set is E', then we have a simplicial fiber bundle p' : E' \to B induced from p. There is a G-action on the fibers, by acting on the F factor.

Given a simplicial set B, a simplicial group G with a twisting function \tau , the twisted product is the pullback B \times _{\bar {W} G} W G with the W-bar construction. We write B \times _\tau G so as to make explicit the twisting function. This is a simplicial principal fiber bundle.

More explicitly, we define B \times _\tau G to be the same as the Cartesian product B \times G, but with one face map altered. The pair (b, g) represents the element in B \times _{\bar {W} G} W G whose first component is b \in B, and the second component is (g_0, \dots , g_n) \in W G, where each element is an iterated product \begin {aligned} g_n &= g \\ g_{k-1} &= \tau (\partial _{k+1} \cdots \partial _n b) \cdot (\partial _{k} g_{k}). \end {aligned} This forces the last face map to be \partial _n (b, g) = (\partial _n b, \tau (b) \cdot \partial _n g), and the other face and degeneracy maps are unchanged.

Given a simplicial group G, a twisting function on a simplicial set B is a simplicial map B \to \bar {W} G to the W-bar construction. It represents a cocycle valued in G. Recall that (\bar {W} G)_n = G_0 \times \cdots \times G_{n-1}. Taking the face map \partial _{n} reveals that all but the last component of the map B_n \to (\bar {W} G)_n are determined by the lower dimension maps. Hence we can obtain a more minimalistic combinatorial description.

Given a simplicial fiber bundle p : E \to B, it is a Kan fibration iff the fiber F is a Kan complex. Hence we call it a Kan fiber bundle. The proof yields an effective Kan fibration if all the inputs are effective.

Given a horn \Lambda ^n_k \to E and a compatible simplex \Delta ^n \to B, by the definition of simplicial fiber bundles, we may trivialize the bundle on the simplex locally. But since F is Kan, obviously F \times \Delta ^n \to \Delta ^n is also Kan. Hence we may select the required filling.

An effective Kan fibration is a Kan fibration of effective simplicial sets equipped with a computable choice of horn-filling. Note that it is different from algebraic Kan fibrations, because morphisms are not required to preserve the choice.

A (strict) simplicial fiber bundle p : E \to B with fiber F is a simplicial map p such that for every simplex \Delta ^n \to B, the pullback of p along the simplex is isomorphic to \Delta ^n \times F \to \Delta ^n.
Given a simplicial group G, a fiber bundle p : E \to B is principal if G acts on the fibers freely and transitively on the right. This condition can be checked in each dimension separately.
We have a chain reduction C_* (X \times Y) \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow C_* (X) \otimes C_* (Y).

For every product of simplices \Delta ^p \times \Delta ^q, we put on the discrete vector field on \Delta ^p \times \Delta ^q. This DVF is admissible because the time a path stays in \Delta ^p \times \Delta ^q is bounded by a function of p and q. Then it is sent to a boundary cell.

Using , we get the required chain reduction. This is identical to the Eilenberg–Zilber reduction in literature, but the proof requires some combinatorics, and can be seen in Section 5.13 of Discrete Vector Fields and Fundamental Algebraic Topology. However, this formulation gives a much better computational performance.
