Given a simplicial group, we can define a model of its universal principal bundle \mathbf {E} G \to \mathbf {B} G as simplicial sets W G \to \bar {W} G. This is a generalization of the bar construction, if we consider a group G as a discrete simplicial set. It classifies principal G-bundles in the sense of Theorem 21.13 in Simplicial objects in algebraic topology.

We define the n-simplices of W G to be (W G)_n = G_0 \times G_1 \times \cdots \times G_n so that G_n acts on (W G)_n by taking the face map that discards the last k vertices for each k, and then acting on the appropriate factor on the right. This forces the face maps and degeneracy maps to be \begin {aligned} \partial _k (g_0, \dots , g_n) &= (g_0, \dots , g_{k-1}, \partial _k g_{k+1}, \dots , \partial _k g_n), \\ \sigma _k (g_0, \dots , g_n) &= (g_0, \dots , g_{k}, \sigma _k g_{k}, \dots , \sigma _k g_n). \end {aligned} We define \bar {W} G to be W G quotiented by the action of G. This can be represented as (\bar {W} G)_n = G_0 \times \cdots \times G_{n-1}, with the quotient map (W G)_n \twoheadrightarrow (\bar {W} G)_n given by (g_0, \dots , g_n) \mapsto (g_0 (\partial _1 g_1)^{-1}, \dots , g_{n-1} (\partial _n g_n)^{-1}). The face and degeneracy maps can then be computed to be \begin {aligned} \partial _k (g_0, \dots , g_{n-1}) &= (g_0, g_1, \dots , g_{k-1} \cdot \partial _k g_k, \partial _k g_{k+1}, \dots , \partial _k g_{n-1}), \\ \partial _n (g_0, \dots , g_{n-1}) &= (g_0, g_1, \dots , g_{n-2}) \\ \sigma _k (g_0, \dots , g_{n-1}) &= (g_0, g_1, \dots , g_{k-1}, 1, \sigma _k g_{k}, \dots , \sigma _k g_{n-1}). \end {aligned} A quick computation shows that this indeed produces a simplicial principal fiber bundle with fiber G.
Given the monotone surjection \{0, \dots , n+1\} \to \{0, \dots , n\} with multiplicity at k, we write the corresponding degeneracy map of a simplicial set as s_k.

We construct a discrete vector field on the reduced ACC of \Delta ^p \times \Delta ^q whose critical cells are given by its boundary and one additional cell (0,0) < (1,0) < \cdots < (p,0) < (p,1) < \cdots < (p,q), in the representation scheme of . In particular, this gives rise to a chain reduction C_*(\Delta ^p \times \Delta ^q) \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow C_*(\Delta ^p) \otimes C_*(\Delta ^q).

Regarding the geometric simplices as paths in a p \times q grid as specified in , we assign a (p+q)-simplex as a target cell if it contains a shape \Rsh . (The shape must go exactly one step up and one step to the right, since it is not possible otherwise in a geometric (p+q)-simplex.) To get its source cell, replace the last occurrence of this shape with \nearrow .

The naturality of the reduction in Eilenberg–Zilber theorem is not obvious. This is because maps sending geometric simplices to degenerate ones does not respect the vector field. We would need additional properties on the maps to guarantee naturality.

The geometric n-simplices of the product simplicial set \Delta ^p \times \Delta ^q are given by a sequence (u_0, v_0) < (u_1, v_1) < \dots < (u_n, v_n) of elements in \{0, \dots , p\} \times \{0, \dots , q\} endowed with the product partial order. Among these, the interior simplices, i.e. non-boundary simplices are given by sequences such that u_i ranges over all \{0, \dots , p\} and v_i ranges over \{0, \dots , q\}.

We can graphically represent this as a path that only travels upwards and/or rightwards every step in a p \times q grid. Face maps are given by removing the corresponding vertex in the path, and directly connecting the surrounding two. But notice that a segment can skip through a grid point, such as going from (0,0) to (2,2), skipping through (1,1).

fr:title.text: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field reduces an ACC (C_k, d) to a smaller one, which can be explicitly described. Its cells are the critical cells in C_k. For the faces of a cell \sigma , we start with the faces d(\sigma ) in the original ACC. Then we move every non-critical cell down along the discrete field lines, up to some sign flips, until we get to a critical cell.

Note that the field lines alternate between n- and (n+1)-dimensional cells, and we count the movement n – (n+1) – n as a single step. Also, discrete field lines can branch and merge, and the cells need to duplicate and move down every branch.

The sphere \mathbb {S}^n can be constructed as an effective simplicial set with exactly two geometric simplices: a zero-dimensional point, and an n-dimensional surface. All the faces of the surface are degenerate and comes from the point.
The associated reduced ACC is \mathbb {Z} at degree 0 and n and zero elsewhere. The map d is constant zero.

Given any group G, we can construct a model of the first Eilenberg–MacLane space K(G, 1) as a simplicial set \bar {W}(G). Consider the contractible simplicial set W(G) whose set of n-simplices is given by G^{n+1}. This has a natural free G-action given by multiplying every entry on the left. \bar {W}(G) is constructed by the quotient of the G-action.

More concretely, the n-simplices are given by n-tuples, representing the quotient of consecutive elements in the (n+1)-tuple in the unquotiented simplicial set above. This is traditionally written as a bracketed sequence of elements separated by bars, [g_1 \mid g_2 \mid \dots \mid g_n], hence we name it the bar construction. Face maps are given by removing the corresponding bars so the elements multiply together. Degeneracy maps are given by inserting the identity elements.
If the group has decidable equality and multiplication, then the simplicial set is also effective. If further more the group is computably finite, then it is of finite type.

fr:title.text: Reduction from K({Z}, 1) to the circle

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Reduction from K(\mathbb {Z}, 1) to the circle

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: There is a chain reduction from the bar construction \bar {W}(G) of a group regarded as its reduced algebraic cellular complex, to the circle \mathbb {S}^1.

By construction, the geometric simplices of K(\mathbb {Z}, 1) are lists [a_1 \mid a_2 \mid \cdots \mid a_n] of non-zero integers. We construct an admissible discrete vector field and use the reduction it generates. We assign a cell [a_1 \mid \cdots ] as a source if a_1 \ne 1. If a_1 \le 0, then we assign its target cell to be [1 \mid a_1 \mid \cdots ]; otherwise we assign [1 \mid a_1 - 1 \mid \cdots ]. Hence, the critical cells are [] and [1].

fr:title.text: Algebraic cellular complexes associated with a simplicial set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic cellular complexes associated with a simplicial set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an (effective) simplicial set X, there are two major algebraic cellular complexes (or chain complexes) we can associate to it. We can consider the free abelian group generated by \Gamma (\Delta ^n, X) at degree n, where the boundary map is given by an alternating sum of face maps: d_n = \sum _{i=0}^n (-1)^{i} \partial _i. This satisfies d^2 = 0 by the simplicial identities. Alternatively, we can consider only the geometric simplices, regarding degenerate ones are zero. More formally, we quotient out the previous chain complex by the subgroups generated by degenerate simplicies. They are both obviously effective by construction.

The first chain complex is called the non-reduced complex, while the second one is the reduced complex. By the two chain complexes are related by a chain reduction. So we will write C_* X for the reduced complex, leaving no notation for the non-reduced one unless otherwise stated.

An effective simplicial set consists of a sequence of types \operatorname {Geom}_n(X) with decidable equality, representing the geometric, a.k.a. non-degenerate, simplices. The full set of simplices, written \Gamma (\Delta ^n, X) or more simply X_n, is given by a geometric simplex g \in \operatorname {Geom}_k(X) for some k together with a degeneracy symbol, defined as a surjection \eta : [n+1] \twoheadrightarrow [k+1], formally representing the degeneracy map that brought g up to dimension n, written as \eta ^* g. The effective simplicial set is also required to have computable face maps \partial _i : \operatorname {Geom}_{n+1}(X) \to \Gamma (\Delta ^n, X) for 0 \le i \le n+1, so that the usual simplicial identities hold. The simplicial set is of finite type if each \operatorname {Geom}_n(X) is computably finite.

Alternatively, we can make a definition that more closely follows the traditional one, requiring a sequence of types with decidable equality representing all simplices instead of geometric ones. We then need to impose an additional requirement that the degeneracy of a simplex is decidable. The equivalence of the two definitions is given by the Eilenberg–Zilber lemma.

fr:title.text: Reduction from the non-reduced chain complex to the reduced chain complex

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Reduction from the non-reduced chain complex to the reduced chain complex

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We construct a chain reduction from the non-reduced chain complex to the reduced chain complex in , by constructing a discrete vector field and using .

We consider placing vectors on degenerate simplicies, so that all degenerate simplices are sources or targets. For each non-trivial degeneracy symbol, if the first degeneration has even multiplicity, we assign it to be a source, with the corresponding target to have one more multiplicity at the place, and vice versa. For example, the degeneracy symbol [6] \twoheadrightarrow [4] given by the table of values (0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4) is a source, whose target is (0, 1, 1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4) : [7] \twoheadrightarrow [4].

To verify this indeed gives a discrete vector field, we need to show that the source is a regular face of the target. This is true since an odd consective sum of (-1)^{i} gives \pm 1. Furthermore, we need to show the admissibility of the vector field. I claim that length of the field lines originating from one cell is bounded by two times the geometric dimension (i.e. the dimension of the associated geometric simplex). On one hand, the geometric dimensions of the target and the source are the same. On the other hand, moving from the target to the next source cell requires us to pick a regular face that does not point back to the target. This is equivalent to picking a place in the degeneracy symbol with no multiplicity. Hence the geometric dimension will decrease by one.
Let G : \mathcal {D} \to \mathcal {C} be a functor with a left adjoint F. G is monadic iff G creates coequalizers whose image under G is split.
For necessity, using , we only need to verify that a monad M preserves the relevant coequalizers, which is true since they are absolute.

For sufficiency, we observe the proof of . Notice that the coequalizers involved are of the form F\alpha , \epsilon : FGFA \rightrightarrows FA. The images of these under G are indeed split by \eta : GFA \to GFGFA and \eta : A \to GFA. Therefore we just have to show G reflects isomorphisms. Given an isomorphism Gf : GA \cong GB, we have a split coequalizer GA \rightrightarrows GB \to GA where the two maps on the left are Gf, and the map on the right is its inverse. This creates a map g : B \to A which is the coequalizer of f with itself. So this map must be an isomorphism. We then consider the coequalizer GB \rightrightarrows GA \to GB, where the two maps on the left are Gg and the map on the right is Gf. Since G reflects this limit, f must also be an isomorphism.

fr:title.text: Complete Boolean algebra not isomorphic to a powerset

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complete Boolean algebra not isomorphic to a powerset

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider the Lebesgue measurable sets on the interval [0,1] quotiented by measure-zero sets. This is a complete Boolean algebra, but it is not a powerset, showing the necessity of complete distributivity in .

This is indeed a Boolean algebra since measure-zero sets form a Boolean ideal of the Lebesgue \sigma -algebra. So we just need to show the existence of arbitrary joins. Given a family X_\alpha of measurable sets, we inductively construct a countable union. On each step, consider the area of each set outside of the current union. Select a set such that this excess area is within \frac 12 of the supremum. Since \mu ([0,1]) = 1, such a process must lead to an excess area converging to zero.

By construction, every set X_\alpha has zero area outside of this countable union, so they are under the union in the Boolean algebra. And the countable union \bigcup _{k=1}^\infty X_{\alpha _k} is the join of X_{\alpha _k} in the algebra, since a countable union of neglegible set is still neglegible. Hence by chasing elements, it must be the join of the entire family X_\alpha .
A completely distributive complete Boolean algebra is a Boolean algebra with arbitrary join and meet that distribute over each other.

fr:title.text: Completely distributive complete Boolean algebras are powersets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Completely distributive complete Boolean algebras are powersets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every completely distributive complete Boolean algebra is isomorphic to the set algebra of a powerset, and homomorphisms are given by inverse image map. In other words, the category of CDCBA is isomorphic to \mathsf {Set}^{\textrm {op}} and the forgetful functor is given by the powerset \mathcal {P}(X) = 2^X.

Consider the set of atoms A, defined as minimal non-bottom elements. It suffices to prove the algebra is atomic, i.e. every non-bottom element has an atom below it. This is because we can remove all the atoms that an element contains, and the result must be \bot . So every element is given by a join of atoms. Such a join must be unique, since the intersection of different atoms is empty, so given two ways to write an element as a join of atoms, we take the intersection and see that they must agree. This shows that the elements are in bijection with \mathcal {P}(A), with joins, meets and complements given by unions, intersections and complements, respectively.

To show atomicity, consider 	op =  igwedge _{b \in B} (b \lor 
eg b) =  igvee _{S \subseteq B} \left [  igwedge _{b \in S} b \wedge  igwedge _{b 
otin S} 
eg b ight ]. Consider the disjunctive clauses in here not equal to  ot (which must exist unless 	op =  ot which trivially satisfies the requirements). They must be atoms because any element x strictly below them must be below all the conjunctive items, so either x < x or x < 
eg x. The former is absurd and the latter implies x =  ot .

Taking the meet of the equation with an arbitrary element x gives x = \bigvee _{S \subseteq B} \left [x \wedge \bigwedge _{b \in S} b \wedge \bigwedge _{b \notin S} \neg b \right ]. If there are no atoms a \le x, then all the clauses must be \bot meaning x = \bot . This finishes the proof.

fr:title.text: Free completely distributive complete Boolean algebras

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Free completely distributive complete Boolean algebras

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An element of a free CDCBA over the set X is an expression made out of joins, meets and negation, with literals from X. We can push the negation in and use distributivity to put the expression into disjunctive normal form. The clauses can be represented by functions X \to \{\top , \bot , ?\} representing a literal appearing positively, negatively or not appearing in the conjunction.

If a literal b does not appear in a clause, we can take its conjunction with \top = b \lor \neg b and expand using distributivity. This ensures every literal appears either positively or negatively, so the expressions are now represented by a double powerset of X, where the inner powerset records which literals appear positively in a clause, and the outer powerset represents the set of clauses.

In fact, such a representation is unique. We just need to show that the double powerset forms a CDCBA. Disjunction is simply a union. Negation is given by the complement. Conjunction is given by an intersection. We can verify that the required identities all hold. Hence the monad for CDCBAs is the double powerset monad, corresponding to the adjunction \mathcal {P}^{\textrm {op}} \dashv \mathcal {P} via .

fr:title.text: Limits and colimits created by a monadic functor

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits and colimits created by a monadic functor

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A monadic functor creates all limits. It also creates all colimits preserved by the monad.

By definition, we just need to prove the functor \mathcal {C}^M \to \mathcal {C} creates these limits and colimits. Given a diagram (M X_i \xrightarrow {\alpha _i} X_i) in \mathcal {C}^M, we can simply define an M-algebra structure on \lim X_i by assigning M(\lim X_i) \to \lim X_i the obvious map. This is the limit of the original diagram by a simple diagram chase, hence it is lifted. The cones over the diagram are determined by their image under the forgetful functor, so the lift is unique, which means the limit is trivially reflected.

For colimits, if M preserves a colimit, then we can similarly define an algebra structure as M(\operatorname *{colim} X_i) \cong \operatorname *{colim} M X_i \to \operatorname *{colim} X_i. The lift is also unique, which means it is reflected.

fr:title.text: Preservation, lifting, reflection and creation of limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Preservation, lifting, reflection and creation of limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider a functor F : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {D}.

fr:ul.fr:li: If a limit cone L in \mathcal {C} is mapped to a limit cone in \mathcal {D}, then the functor preserves the limit I.
If given a diagram D and a limit cone L over F \mathbin {\circ } D in \mathcal {D}, D can be extended to a limit cone in \mathcal {C} that maps to L, then the functor lifts the limit L to D.
If all the cones that maps to a limit cone L in \mathcal {D} are limit cones in \mathcal {C}, then the functor reflects the limit L.
If given a diagram D and a limit cone L over F \mathbin {\circ } D in \mathcal {D}, L is reflected and lifted to D, then the limit of D is created.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This can be easily generalized to cover a type of limits or all limits, and can be dualized to colimits. The definitions here are not agreed upon, and the literature may have slight variations. We consider univalent categories here, so that definitions are automatically adjusted to be equivalence-invariant.

A reflexive pair is the categorical translation of a reflexive relation. It is defined as a pair of arrows \partial _0, \partial _1 : X \rightrightarrows Y with a common section r : Y \to X, i.e. an arrow r such that \partial _0 \mathbin {\circ } r = \partial _1 \mathbin {\circ } r = \textrm {id}_Y. A coequalizer of a reflexive pair is called a reflexive coequalizer.

Let G : \mathcal {D} \to \mathcal {C} be a functor with a left adjoint F. M = G \mathbin {\circ } F is the corresponding monad on \mathcal {C}. This gives a comparison functor K : \mathcal {A} \to \mathcal {C}^M.

fr:ol.fr:li: If \mathcal {D} has all coequalizers (we can weaken this to reflexive coequalizers), then K has a left adjoint.
If moreover G preserves these reflexive coequalizers, the unit \textrm {Id} \to K \mathbin {\circ } L is an isomorphism.
Finally, if G reflects isomorphisms, then the counit L \mathbin {\circ } K \to \textrm {Id} is also an isomorphism, making G monadic.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the final point, we would like the coequalizer of FG\epsilon , \epsilon : FGFGX \rightrightarrows FGX to be isomorphic to X. If we apply G to the diagram, we get an isomorphism to GX by the previous point. So if G reflects isomorphisms, we’re done.
An absolute (co)limit is a (co)limit that is preserved by any functor whatsoever.

Given a coequalizer diagram X \rightrightarrows Y \to Z where \partial _0, \partial _1 : X \to Y are the two parallel arrows and the coequalizing arrow is e : Y \to Z, it is absolute, if and only if the following conditions hold.

fr:ul.fr:li: e is split epimorphic, i.e. there is an arrow r such that e \mathbin {\circ } r = \textrm {id}_Z.

There is a list of n endomorphisms on Y starting with r \mathbin {\circ } e and ending with \textrm {id}_Y, such that for each pair of adjacent morphisms, there is an arrow s such that \partial _0 \mathbin {\circ } s and \partial _1 \mathbin {\circ } s are equal to the two morphisms (in some order).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that for n = 0 this is the trivial coequalizer where \partial _0 = \partial _1 and e is an isomorphism. For n = 1 this results in the split coequalizer.

By the definition of an absolute (co)limit, the coequalizer is preserved by every functor. Consider the functor \hom (Z, -). We have \hom (Z, e) is a coequalizer map, and hence epimorphic. This means e itself is split epimorphic since \textrm {id}_Z is in the image, i.e. there is a morphism r : Z \to Y with e \mathbin {\circ } r = \textrm {id}_Z.

Next, we consider the functor \hom (Y, -). Since this gives a coequalizer of sets, the quotient \hom (Y, Y) \xrightarrow {e \mathbin {\circ } -} \hom (Y, Z) is given by the equivalence relation generated by \partial _0 \mathbin {\circ } f = \partial _1 \mathbin {\circ } f for every f : Y \to X. There is a pair of elements mapped to the same element under e \mathbin {\circ } - in this situation: one of them is obviously \textrm {id}_Y, and the other is r \mathbin {\circ } e, since e \mathbin {\circ } \textrm {id}_Y = e = e \mathbin {\circ } r \mathbin {\circ } e. Hence we get the chain of morphisms related in the way stated in the theorem.

Finally, we observe that these are enough to guarantee the given diagram is a coequalizer —— the diagram is a coequalizer simply by virtue of the shape of the diagram. Since any functor preserves the composition relation of morphisms, they must also give coequalizers, and therefore the coequalizer is absolute.
Given a pair of adjoint functors F \dashv G, G is monadic if the corresponding comparison functor to \mathcal {C}^{G \mathbin {\circ } F} is an equivalence in the bicategory of decompositions.

fr:title.text: The Kleisli category induces the initial decomposition of a monad

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Kleisli category induces the initial decomposition of a monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Kleisli category together with its canonical adjunction is the initial decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors.

fr:title.text: The Eilenberg–Moore category induces the terminal decomposition of a monad

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Eilenberg–Moore category induces the terminal decomposition of a monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Eilenberg–Moore category together with its canonical adjunction is the terminal decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors. Hence there is a unique morphism from any decomposition to it, named the comparison functor.
Given an adjunction F \dashv G with the corresponding monad G \mathbin {\circ } F, the comparison functor is defined as sending X to GFGX \to GX, given by the counit FGX \to X.

fr:title.text: Decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This bicategory has initial and terminal objects.

fr:title.text: The Kleisli category induces the initial decomposition of a monad

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Kleisli category induces the initial decomposition of a monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Kleisli category together with its canonical adjunction is the initial decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors.

fr:title.text: The Eilenberg–Moore category induces the terminal decomposition of a monad

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Eilenberg–Moore category induces the terminal decomposition of a monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Eilenberg–Moore category together with its canonical adjunction is the terminal decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors. Hence there is a unique morphism from any decomposition to it, named the comparison functor.
Given an adjunction F \dashv G with the corresponding monad G \mathbin {\circ } F, the comparison functor is defined as sending X to GFGX \to GX, given by the counit FGX \to X.
Given a pair of adjoint functors F \dashv G, G is monadic if the corresponding comparison functor to \mathcal {C}^{G \mathbin {\circ } F} is an equivalence in the bicategory of decompositions.

An object of the Kleisli category of a monad can be considered as a free algebra, but equipped with a canonical choice of generators. Hence although the Kleisli category is equivalent to the category of free algebras, the objects are essentially different. This manifests as the curious fact that the Kleisli category is not univalent, since an equality of Kleisli objects requires an isomorphism of the generators, but an isomorphism only requires the two free algebras to be isomorphic.

fr:title.text: The Kleisli category is equivalent to the category of free algebras

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Kleisli category is equivalent to the category of free algebras

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given category \mathcal {C}, the Kleisli category of a monad M : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {C} is equivalent to the full subcategory of the M-algebras spanned by the free algebras.
Consider the functor from the Kleisli category to the category of free algebras, sending X to the free algebra on X. This is fully faithful and surjective on objects.

fr:title.text: The Kleisli category of a monad

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Kleisli category of a monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a monad M : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {C} and two objects X, Y in \mathcal {C}, a Kleisli arrow from X to Y is simply any arrow X \to MY. This represents an algebra homomorphism from the free algebra generated by X to that of Y.

The identity Kleisli arrow is defined as \eta : X \to MX. The composition of f : X \to MY and g : Y \to MZ is given by X \xrightarrow {f} MY \xrightarrow {Mg} M^2 Z \xrightarrow {\mu } MZ. This forms a category whose objects are the objects of \mathcal {C}, as a formal symbol standing for the free algebra generated by those objects, and morphisms are Kleisli arrows. This is the Kleisli category \mathcal {C}_M.
Given a monad M : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {C}, an M-algebra is defined as an object X equipped with a morphism \alpha : MX \to X, such that the following two diagrams commute.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

\begin {tikzcd}%tex {M^2X} & MX & X & MX \\ MX & X && X \arrow["\alpha"', from=2-1, to=2-2] \arrow["\alpha", from=1-2, to=2-2] \arrow["\mu"', from=1-1, to=2-1] \arrow["M\alpha", from=1-1, to=1-2] \arrow["\operatorname{id}"', from=1-3, to=2-4] \arrow["\eta", from=1-3, to=1-4] \arrow["\alpha", from=1-4, to=2-4]\end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In an unbiased formulation, we require the natural transformation M^n \to M of the monad evaluated at the object X composed with \alpha : MX \to X to be equal to M^n X \xrightarrow {M^{n-1}\alpha } M^{n-1}X \to \cdots \xrightarrow {\alpha } X.
The algebras of a monad form a category \mathcal {C}^M, whose morphisms are commutative squares. This is also known as the Eilenberg–Moore category.

Given a monad M on a category \mathcal {C}, there is a canonical adjunction between the category of algebras \mathcal {C}^M and \mathcal {C}. The forgetful functor U_M takes an algebra and forgets the algebra structure. The free functor F_M takes an object X and produces an algebra on MX given by the monad multiplication map \mu : M^2 X \to MX, called the free algebra.

We just have to verify that the two conversions are mutual inverses. In one way, we need to verify \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M f \mathbin {\circ } \eta = f. This is true because by the naturality of \eta we get M f \mathbin {\circ } \eta = \eta \mathbin {\circ } f. Then by the definition of algebra \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } \eta = \textrm {id}, proving the equality. On the other hand, we need to show \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M(\varphi \mathbin {\circ } \eta ) = \varphi . This follows from the algebra identity \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M \alpha _Y = \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } \mu and the monad identity \mu \mathbin {\circ } M \eta = \textrm {id}.

A monad on a category \mathcal {C} is a functor M : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {C} equipped with natural transformations \eta : \textrm {Id} \to M and \mu : M \mathbin {\circ } M \to M satisfying identity and associativity laws. In an unbiased way, we have a family of natural transformations M^n \to M with associativity.
In short, it is a monoid in the category of endofunctors equipped with composition as the monoidal product.

fr:title.text: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an admissible discrete vector field on an algebraic cellular complex (C_k, d), we can generate a chain reduction. It will be computable when the cellular complex is effective.

The DVF partitions the chain groups into a direct sum C_k^{s} \oplus C_k^t \oplus C_k^c, corresponding to source, target and critical cells. We would like to create a reduction to the critical cells only. To do this, we invoke perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction and start with a simpler chain reduction.

Consider the algebraic cellular complex whose chain groups are C_k, but the differential d'(\sigma ) = \pm \tau iff \overrightharpoon {\tau \sigma } is in the vector field, and zero otherwise. The sign is determined as the sign of \tau in d(\sigma ). Hence d' : C_{k+1}^{t} \to C_k^s, and is zero otherwise. Therefore using the characterization of chain reduction as a direct sum with a split exact chain complex, we see that this complex can be reduced to the complex on C_k^p whose differential is identically zero.

Next, we try to perturb d' to d. We need h_{\rho } \mathbin {\circ } (d' - d) to be locally nilpotent, where \rho is the reduction constructed above. h_{\rho } can be viewed as the inverse of d', as it maps the source cell to the target cell. Expanding the definition, we see that this map transports cells down the discrete field line. Since the vector field is admissible, such a transportation eventually terminates and it becomes zero.

fr:title.text: Discrete field lines can branch and merge

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Discrete field lines can branch and merge

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Although we make an analogy between a discrete vector field and a vector field, the field lines of a DVF may branch out. For instance, take a triangle \tau with three edges \sigma _1, \sigma _2, \sigma _3. We can have a vector \overrightharpoon {\sigma _1 \tau } pointing into the triangle, and \sigma _2, \sigma _3 each having vectors pointing out. Similarly multiple field lines may join when they reach a lower-degree cell. Because of this, we need to take care in the phrasing of admissibility.

Given a discrete vector field, if is admissible if the lengths of the field lines starting from a cell are bounded. In other words, we can assign a natural number to every cell such that the field lines starting from this cell have length bounded by the number. The number can be different for each cell, and can be unbounded overall.

A discrete vector field (DVF) of degree p on an algebraic cellular complex is given by a collection of pairs of cells (\sigma , \tau ), where \sigma is a regular face of the degree p cell \tau , standing for a vector pointing from \sigma to \tau , which we will write as \overrightharpoon {\sigma \tau }. We require that every cell appears at most once in these vectors.

A DVF naturally partitions the cells into three kinds: the sources, the targets, and the rest of the cells are called critical cells. This name comes from the analogy to Morse theory. Indeed there is a notion of discrete Morse function.

Given a discrete vector field, the discrete version of field lines is defined as a sequence of cells alternating between degree p and (p-1) starting and ending with lower-degree cells, with a few requirements.

fr:ul.fr:li: When the degree increases, the two cells must occur as a vector in the DVF.
When the degree decreases, the degree (p-1) cell must be a (possible non-regular) face of the degree p cell.
Two degree (p-1) cells separated by a degree p cell must not be the same.

fr:title.text: Regular face in an algebraic cellular complex

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Regular face in an algebraic cellular complex

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an algebraic cellular complex and a cell \sigma , a regular face of \sigma is a cell whose coefficient in d\sigma is \pm 1.

We have an equivalence of categories \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C})/P \cong \mathsf {Psh}\left (\int _{\mathcal {C}} P\right ). In the special case that P = \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(U), we have \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C})/\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(U) \cong \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}/U).

Given a category \mathcal {C} with a Grothendieck coverage J and a sheaf F, there is a Grothendieck coverage J' on \int _{\mathcal {C}} F such that the equivalence in restricts to an equivalence \mathsf {Sh}(\mathcal {C}, J)/F \cong \mathsf {Sh}\left (\int _{\mathcal {C}} F, J'\right ).

Suppose we have a covering sieve S \hookrightarrow \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(U) in \mathcal {C}, then an element f \in \Gamma (U, F) uniquely corresponds to a matching family s \in \hom (S, F). In the category of elements \int _{\mathcal {C}} F, s corresponds to a sieve over f. This is the required Grothendieck coverage.

Another way to construct this is through the Lawvere–Tierney operator j. The subobject classifier of a slice category is simply \Omega \times F \to F. Hence we can let j act on the \Omega factor. This gives a Lawvere–Tierney operator on the slice category and it coincides with the Grothendieck coverage constructed above.

fr:title.text: Dense subobject of a Lawvere–Tierney operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dense subobject of a Lawvere–Tierney operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator j, a subobject F \hookrightarrow G is j-dense if G \to \Omega \xrightarrow {j} \Omega is the constant true. In terms of the corresponding J \hookrightarrow \Omega , we need the pullback of it with G \to \Omega to be \textrm {id} : G \to G.

Expressing the sheaf condition using Lawvere–Tierney operators, we only need to show for dense subobjects F \hookrightarrow G that \hom (G, X^Y) \to \hom (F, X^Y) is a bijection. This is equivalent to \hom (Y \times G, X) \to \hom (Y \times F, X). Note that the subobject Y \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times G corresponds to the characteristic function Y \times G \to G \to \Omega . Hence the denseness of F \hookrightarrow G implies the denseness of Y \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times G. Since X is a sheaf, we conclude that X^Y is also a sheaf.
Given a class of arrows S, an S-local object is an object X such that for every f : A \to B in S, the composition map \hom (B, X) \to \hom (A, X) is an isomorphism.

Knowing the correspondence of Grothendieck coverages on \mathcal {C} and Lawvere–Tierney operators on \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}), we naturally want to rewrite the sheaf condition to use Lawvere–Tierney operators instead of Grothendieck coverages.

Recall that the sheaf condition requires for every covering sieve S \hookrightarrow \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(U) that the composition \hom (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(U), X) \to \hom (S, X) is an isomorphism. We can reify this to a definition.
Given a class of arrows S, an S-local object is an object X such that for every f : A \to B in S, the composition map \hom (B, X) \to \hom (A, X) is an isomorphism.

fr:title.text: Dense subobject of a Lawvere–Tierney operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dense subobject of a Lawvere–Tierney operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator j, a subobject F \hookrightarrow G is j-dense if G \to \Omega \xrightarrow {j} \Omega is the constant true. In terms of the corresponding J \hookrightarrow \Omega , we need the pullback of it with G \to \Omega to be \textrm {id} : G \to G.

In terms of sieves, for every section s \in \Gamma (U, G), the sieve of arrows on U along whom the restriction of s is in F must be a covering sieve. We have arrived at the desired reformulation of the sheaf condition.
Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator j, a j-sheaf is defined as a j-local object, i.e. a local object under the j-dense monomorphisms.
Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator j, a j-sheaf is defined as a j-local object, i.e. a local object under the j-dense monomorphisms.
Consider a Lawvere–Tierney operator on a presheaf category. Then we may calculate the subobject classifier as in .

In the operator form j, it takes in a sieve S and outputs the sieve j(S) consisting of all the subobjects S can cover, or equivalently it outputs the largest sieve that covers the “same portion” of the object.

Given a category \mathcal {C}, a Lawvere–Tierney operator is a morphism j : \Omega \to \Omega where \Omega is the subobject classifier, such that j preserves finite intersections, and j \mathbin {\circ } j = j.

We can equivalently express it as an enriched monad on the propositions. This allows for a form more akin to functional programming: we have an operator j, equipped with maps \eta : \forall (p : \Omega ), p \to j(p) and \beta : \forall (p, q : \Omega ), j(p) \to (p \to j(q)) \to j(q). No laws are required since propositions have at most one element.

The subobject classifier \Omega of presheaves can be given by a quick calculation. \Gamma (U, \Omega ) \cong \hom (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(U), \Omega ) \cong \operatorname {Sub}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(U)) By definition, this is the set of sieves on U, and the functorial action is the pullback. For a monomorphism F \hookrightarrow G, an element s \in \Gamma (U, G) is sent to the sieve consisting of arrows f : V \to U such that the restriction along f is included in F.
Given a Grothendieck coverage, the inclusion of separated presheaves to presheaves has a left adjoint (-)^{\operatorname {sep}}.

We define \Gamma (U, P^{\operatorname {sep}}) to be a quotient of \Gamma (U, P). Two sections are considered the same if they are equal on a covering sieve. It is obvious that this is separated, and in a morphism P \to Q to a separated presheaf, if two sections of P are equal on a covering sieve, then their image will also be, and by separatedness they must be actually equal in Q.

fr:title.text: Sheaf condition in terms of plus construction

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sheaf condition in terms of plus construction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a presheaf P, the morphism P \to P^+ to its plus construction is a monomorphism iff P is separated, and it is an isomorphism iff P is a sheaf.
Sheafification is defined as the left adjoint of the inclusion from sheaves to the category of presheaves. Hence it freely constructs a sheaf from a presheaf.

We construct sheafification as an iterated plus construction. This produces a functor. By we have a natural bijection \hom (P^{++}, F) \cong \hom (P^+, F) \cong \hom (P, F). Hence it is indeed the left adjoint. Since the bijections are given by composition with P \to P^+ and P^+ \to P^{++}, we see that the unit of the adjunction is given by the composition P \to P^{++}.
Alternatively, using , we may compose two adjunctions to first separate the presheaf, and then perform the plus construction. By uniqueness of adjunction these two constructions are equivalent.
For any presheaf P and sheaf F, there is a natural bijection \hom (P, F) \cong \hom (P^+, F) given by composition with \eta _P : P \to P^+.
As a corollary of this and , when restricted to separated presheaves, it is left adjoint to the forgetful functor from sheaves to separated presheaves.

For every morphism P \to F, there is a unique way to extend the map to P^+ using the sheaf condition of F. A section of P^+ consists of a matching family s_f, and it is also the gluing of \eta _P(s_f).
Given a category \mathcal {C}, a Grothendieck coverage declares some sieves to be coverings, such that the following holds.

fr:ul.fr:li: The maximal sieve \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A) \subseteq \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A) is always a covering.
Covering sieves are upwards closed, i.e. if S \subseteq S' and S is a covering sieve, then so is S'.
If S is a covering sieve of A, and g : B \to A is a morphism, then the pullback g^* S is also a covering.
Suppose S is a sieve, then the collection of arrows g such that g^* S is a covering is a sieve itself. If this sieve is a covering, then S is also a covering.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Grothendieck coverage can be viewed as a coverage.

A coverage on an arbitrary category \mathcal {C} is given by a family of covers. A cover of some object A in \mathcal {C} is a family of maps with codomain A. Given a cover f_i : U_i \to A and a map g : B \to A, there is a cover of B such that its composition with g is a refinement of f_i, in the sense that every map in the cover factors through one of f_i.

Given a category \mathcal {C}, a sieve S and a presheaf P : \mathcal {C}^\textrm {op} \to \mathsf {Set}, a set of descent data or a compatible family is a morphism S \to P. Expanding this, it is a family of local sections s \in \Gamma (U, P) assigned for each morphism U \to A in the sieve S, such that the local sections are compatible on restriction. There is an obvious map from the sections \Gamma (A, P) to the descent data given by restriction.

More generally, given a general cover, a set of descent data is a family of sections s_i \in \Gamma (U_i, P) for each morphism f_i : U_i \to A in the cover, such that in any common restriction of U_i and U_j, the sections agree. This can be equivalently expressed as the descent data of the sieve generated by the cover.

fr:title.text: Iterated plus construction produces a sheaf

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Iterated plus construction produces a sheaf

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given any presheaf P, P^+ is a separated presheaf, and if P is already separated, P^+ is a sheaf. Therefore P^{++} is always a sheaf.

We first prove that P^+ is separated. Suppose there are two gluings of a set of descent data on a covering sieve S over A, then we have two sieves S_1, S_2 over A with compatible families s_{1, f}, s_{2, f}. Since they are gluings of the same descent data, the restriction along any morphism g : U \to A in S would be equal. Hence there is a common refinement of g^* S_1 and g^* S_2 where the two families become equal. Expanding this, there is a covering sieve on U such that g \mathbin {\circ } h \in S_1 \cap S_2 for every h in the sieve, and s_{1, g \mathbin {\circ } h} = s_{2, g \mathbin {\circ } h}. But then by the axioms of a Grothendieck coverage, g \mathbin {\circ } h for all h in the said sieve and g \in S also generates a covering sieve. Hence s_1 and s_2 are already equal on a covering subsieve, and so they are equal in \Gamma (A, P^+).

Let’s see why P^+ is not necessarily a sheaf. To be a sheaf, we need to find a gluing for each compatible family. A compatible family of local sections of P^+ is a family of covering sieves S_f over U for each morphism f : U \to A in S, and for each S_f a family of sections s_{f, g} \in \Gamma (V, P) where g : V \to U lies in S_f. By the axioms of a Grothendieck coverage, the union \bigcup _{f \in S} f \mathbin {\circ } S_f is a sieve, since S_f \subseteq f^* (f \mathbin {\circ } S_f). (Warning: f \mathbin {\circ } S_f is not a covering sieve itself.) So we are tempted to simply construct a glued section s' by s'_{f \mathbin {\circ } g} = s_{f, g}. Hence we need to prove s_{f, g} = s_{f', g'} if f \mathbin {\circ } g = f' \mathbin {\circ } g'.

Since the families s_{f} are compatible, given any g : V \to U we have s_{f, g \mathbin {\circ } r} = s_{f \mathbin {\circ } g, r} for a family of arrows r that generates a covering sieve on V. However we cannot necessarily take r = \textrm {id}, so this is not necessarily well-defined. Here is where the separatedness comes in. Notice that s_{f, g \mathbin {\circ } r} = s_{f \mathbin {\circ } g, r} forms a compatible family over V as r ranges over the covering sieve. And therefore s_{f, g} and s_{f \mathbin {\circ } g, \textrm {id}} are both a gluing of the family. By separatedness, they must be equal. Hence our problem is solved.

Given a Grothendieck coverage on \mathcal {C} and a presheaf P : \mathcal {C}^\textrm {op} \to \mathsf {Set}, the plus construction produces a new presheaf P^+ by taking a directed limit over all the descent data. More precisely, we assign \Gamma (A, P^+) = \operatorname *{colim}_{S \text { covers } A} \hom (S, P). This means the sections of P^+ are compatible families of sections of P, and two families are considered equal if they are equal on a common covering subsieve.
Given a map g : B \to A, we have a pullback \hom (S, P) \to \hom (g^*S, P). This induces the functorial action of P^+. There is an obvious natural transformation P \to P^+.

Given a sieve S over A and a morphism g : B \to A, the pullback g^* S is a sieve over B. h : C \to B is in this sieve iff g \mathbin {\circ } h is in S. There is a natural map g^* S \to S given by g \mathbin {\circ } -.

Given a category \mathcal {C} equipped with a coverage, we define a presheaf P : \mathcal {C}^\textrm {op} \to \mathsf {Set} to be a sheaf if it satisfies the sheaf condition: for every cover of A, the map from sections of A to descent data of the cover is a bijection. It is a separated presheaf if the map is an injection.

A sieve over an object A of an arbitrary category \mathcal {C} is a subfunctor of \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A). More explicitly, it selects some arrows with codomain A, such that the selected arrows absorbs composition (i.e. if f : B \to A is selected and g : C \to B, then g \mathbin {\circ } f is also selected).

Given a pair of chain reductions \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D and \rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D', we can construct a reduction from the mapping cone \operatorname {Cone}(f) of a chain map f : C \to C' to (the action of \rho on f).

fr:title.text: A space is noetherian iff hereditarily quasi-compact

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A space is noetherian iff hereditarily quasi-compact

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A space is noetherian iff it is hereditarily quasi-compact, that is, if all its opens are quasi-compact.

We first show the forward direction. By the definition of being noetherian, all its opens are automatically noetherian. So we just need to prove that noetherian spaces are quasi-compact. This is obvious, since taking unions of the open covers we have an ascending chain of opens, which must terminate.

For the other direction, given an ascending chain of opens, they form a cover of their union. Since the union is an open, it is quasi-compact by hypothesis, and therefore the cover has a finite subcover, proving that the chain stabilizes after finitely many terms.
The intersections of two affine subschemes \operatorname {Spec}(R_1), \operatorname {Spec}(R_2) \hookrightarrow X can be covered by affine schemes distinguished in both of them.

We just need to cover each point of the intersection. Suppose a point in the intersection is given by a prime ideal \mathfrak {p} of R_1. We can pick a distinguished open D(f) of \operatorname {Spec}(R_2) contained in the intersection and containing \mathfrak {p}, and a distinguished open D(g) of \operatorname {Spec}(R_1) contained in D(f) and containing \mathfrak {p}. Now we prove that D(g) is a distinguished open in \operatorname {Spec}(R_2).

It suffices to prove that D(g) is a distinguished open in \operatorname {Spec}(R_2 [f^{-1}]), since this would imply the existence of an element g'/f^{n} \in R_2[f^{-1}], and we can take D(g') \cap D(f) = D(g' f) in \operatorname {Spec}(R_2). Now there is an inclusion map \operatorname {Spec}(R_2[f^{-1}]) \to \operatorname {Spec}(R_1), which amounts to a ring homomorphism \varphi by . In this case, D(\varphi (g)) is the required distinguished open, since \varphi ^{-1}D(u) is equal to D(\varphi (u)) in \operatorname {Spec}(R_2 [f^{-1}]).

Suppose a property on affine subschemes \operatorname {Spec}(R) \hookrightarrow X is closed under taking distinguished subsets \operatorname {Spec}(R_f) \hookrightarrow X, and for \gcd \{f_i\} = 1, the property being true on \operatorname {Spec}(R_{f_i}) \hookrightarrow X implies it being true on \operatorname {Spec}(R) \hookrightarrow X. Then such a property is called affine local. We then say that X has such a property if some affine cover has such a property: the result doesn’t depend on the chosen cover.

If the property P only depends on \operatorname {Spec}(R) and not X (or the inclusion map), it can be simplified as a property on affine schemes. In this case, the above definition extends it to a property P' on schemes, which we will usually refer to as locally P. Suppose the scheme is furthermore quasi-compact, we say the scheme satisfies P.

We prove that if some affine cover \{\operatorname {Spec}(R_i) \hookrightarrow X\} has such a property, then all the affine subschemes has it, hence we can check on any affine cover. Given an affine subscheme \operatorname {Spec}(S) \hookrightarrow X, using Nike’s trick, we see that the intersection with \operatorname {Spec}(R_i) is covered by affine subschemes, which will all have the said property. Hence we get a cover of \operatorname {Spec}(S) \hookrightarrow X with the said property, and therefore itself also.
A space is irreducible iff finitely many non-empty opens always has non-empty intersection. In other words, iff it is non-empty and cannot be written as a union of two closed sets.

We have an adjunction of functors \mathsf {CRing}^\textrm {op} \xtofrom [\Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_{(-)})]{\operatorname {Spec}} \mathsf {Sch}, with \operatorname {Spec} being the right adjoint (or \operatorname {Spec} : \mathsf {CRing} \to \mathsf {Sch}^\textrm {op} being the left adjoint). In fact, we can replace \mathsf {Sch} with the category of locally ringed spaces \mathsf {LRS}, of whom \mathsf {Sch} is a full subcategory.

We need to give a natural bijection \hom (X, \operatorname {Spec}(R)) \cong \hom (R, \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X)). In other words, maps X \to \operatorname {Spec}(R) between locally ringed spaces are uniquely specified by the action of global sections.

Since X is glued from affine open subschemes, a map from X is equivalent to a map from each open subscheme \operatorname {Spec}(S_i) that agree on common restrictions (which again can be checked on an affine covering). Since the codomain is affine, these maps are equivalently ring homomorphisms R \to S_i by . The elements of \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X) are also given by a set of compatible elements from S_i. Hence these two sets are naturally bijective.

The opens of the projective spectrum \operatorname {Proj}(S) are in bijection with graded radical ideals with \mathfrak {r}_0 = 0. Hence we write D_+ (\mathfrak {r}) for this open. The proof is exactly the same as .

To define projective spaces, we start with an affine space, and restricts ourselves to regions invariant under dilation — or using the language of points, we consider lines through the origin as points. Hence we need to define how an element of a ring (which is geometrically a function on the affine space) behaves under dilation.

In polynomial rings, for example, the polynomial x^2 + 2y + 7 becomes \lambda ^2 x^2 + 2 \lambda y + 7 under a dilation by \lambda . Note how each term can be classified by the power of \lambda it obtains. Hence, what we need is a grading on the ring, which partitions R = \bigoplus _d R_d (as abelian groups). R_d is intuitively the elements that get the factor \lambda ^d upon dilation. The multiplication of a degree p element with a degree q element should produce a degree (p+q) element, since \lambda ^p \lambda ^q = \lambda ^{p+q}.

A D-graded ring is a sequence of abelian groups R_d, where d \in D are elements of a commutative monoid called the grading. We have a bilinear multiplication map R_p \otimes R_q \to R_{p+q} and a identity element 1 \in R_0 satisfying the associativity and identity laws.
Usually, the grading is one of \mathbb Z or \mathbb N. A bigraded ring is graded over D^2 instead of D, whatever the context implies the grading is.

The opens of a projective space should come from the non-vanishing region of a homogeneous function, i.e. elements with a single degree. This ensures that dilation doesn’t change the opens. However, we would have multiple ways to represent the entire space: in a two-dimensional affine space, D(x) \cup D(y) and D(1) are both invariant under dilation, but the former excludes the origin, while the latter does not. In a projective setting, we don’t care about the origin at all, and considering that all homogeneous polynomials of positive degree vanish at the origin, we should make that mandatory. Hence, we only consider the opens corresponding to positively graded elements, which we write as D_+ (f). We can construct a space similar to the localic spectrum of a commutative ring.

fr:title.text: Projective spectrum of a graded ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Projective spectrum of a graded ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a \mathbb N-graded ring S_\bullet , we construct a locale analogous to the \operatorname {Spec} construction for affine schemes. We start with symbols of distinguished opens D_+ (f) for each positively graded element f, and impose the same relations: D_+ sends finite products to finite intersections, and for elements of the same grade, D_+ (\sum _i f_i) \subseteq \bigcup _i D_+(f_i).

As for the structure sheaf, we need to decide what the sections over D_+ (f) are. They should be functions defined on the affine space D(f) \subseteq \operatorname {Spec}(S), but invariant under dilation. Note that it is stronger than requiring vanishing region be invariant. We actually need the grade 0 elements here. Recalling from structure sheaf of a ring spectrum that \Gamma (D(f), \mathscr {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}(S)}) = S[f^{-1}] (which can be given a canonical grading since f is a graded element), we can make the following definition.

Fix a graded ring S. For a positively graded element f, we have a graded ring localization S[f^{-1}]_\bullet . Let \Gamma (D_+(f), \mathscr {O}) be the zeroth degree component S[f^{-1}]_0. This defines a sheaf over the projective spectrum, and moreover gives a scheme \operatorname {Proj}(S).

We claim that \operatorname {Proj}(S) can alternatively be given by gluing affine schemes. We assign D_+ (f) the affine scheme \operatorname {Spec}(S[f^{-1}]_0) (which is possible because the open subspace D_+ (f) is homeomorphic to \operatorname {Spec}(S[f^{-1}]_0) as a space). Given two positively graded elements f and g, we have an isomorphism between \operatorname {Proj}(S) restricted to D_+ (f g) and \operatorname {Spec}(S[f^{-1}]_0) restricted to D(g^{\deg f}/f^{\deg g}), given by the obvious ring isomorphism. We can verify that this satisfies the cocycle condition, and hence defines a scheme.

A D-graded ring is a sequence of abelian groups R_d, where d \in D are elements of a commutative monoid called the grading. We have a bilinear multiplication map R_p \otimes R_q \to R_{p+q} and a identity element 1 \in R_0 satisfying the associativity and identity laws.
Usually, the grading is one of \mathbb Z or \mathbb N. A bigraded ring is graded over D^2 instead of D, whatever the context implies the grading is.
Given a \mathbb N-graded ring S, its irrelevant ideal \mathord {\odot } is defined by the subset S_+ of all positively graded elements.

The points of the projective scheme \operatorname {Proj}(S) are given by prime ideals not dividing the irrelevant ideal \mathord {\odot }. This is in bijection with ideals with \mathfrak {p}_0 = 0 (equivalently \mathord {\odot } \nmid \mathfrak {p}), and the condition for prime ideals holds for positively graded elements, i.e. \mathfrak {p} \mid x y \iff (\mathfrak {p} \mid x \lor \mathfrak {p} \mid y) for positively graded x and y.

To specify a point P, we need to specify which opens D_+(f) it belongs to, where f ranges over positively graded elements. Equivalently, we specify the closeds V_+(f). Since V_+(f) \cap V_+(g) \subseteq V_+(f + g), if P \in V_+(f) and P \in V_+(g) then P \in V_+(f + g). Similarly since V_+(f) \subseteq V_+(f g), P \in V_+(f) implies P \in V_+(f g). Collecting all the elements whose distinguished closed contains P, we get an ideal \mathfrak {a} whose zeroth degree vanishes.

We have V_+(f g) = V_+(f) \cup V_+(g), so if \mathfrak {a} \mid f g, then either \mathfrak {a} \mid f or \mathfrak {a} \mid g. This is almost the condition for prime ideals, but recall that f and g must have positive grading, so we actually get the ideals in the theorem statement. Conversely, being such an ideal is sufficient condition for the specification of the point to be valid, by calculation with .

Next, we prove these ideals are in bijection with prime ideals not dividing \mathord {\odot }. One direction of the correspondence is obvious: we take a prime ideal \mathfrak {p} and remove the zeroth degree, which amounts to taking \operatorname {lcm}(\mathfrak {p}, \mathord {\odot }).

We prove injectivity. Suppose primes \mathfrak {p} and \mathfrak {q} satisfy \operatorname {lcm}(\mathfrak {p}, \mathord {\odot }) = \operatorname {lcm}(\mathfrak {q}, \mathord {\odot }), then \mathfrak {p} \mid \operatorname {lcm}(\mathfrak {q}, \mathord {\odot }) \mid \mathfrak {q} \cdot \mathord {\odot }, so either \mathfrak {p} \mid \mathord {\odot } which is forbidden, or \mathfrak {p} \mid \mathfrak {q}. Conversely we must have \mathfrak {q} \mid \mathfrak {p}, hence \mathfrak {p} = \mathfrak {q}.

We prove surjectivity. Given an ideal \mathfrak {a}, we need to supplement it with a zeroth degree component \mathfrak {a}_0 so that together they make a prime ideal not divided by \mathord {\odot }. We define \mathfrak {a}_0 \mid c iff there exists some positively graded \mathfrak {a} \nmid f such that \mathfrak {a} \mid cf. The verification is routine element chasing.

fr:title.text: Projective spectrum of a graded ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Projective spectrum of a graded ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a \mathbb N-graded ring S_\bullet , we construct a locale analogous to the \operatorname {Spec} construction for affine schemes. We start with symbols of distinguished opens D_+ (f) for each positively graded element f, and impose the same relations: D_+ sends finite products to finite intersections, and for elements of the same grade, D_+ (\sum _i f_i) \subseteq \bigcup _i D_+(f_i).

Fix a graded ring S. For a positively graded element f, we have a graded ring localization S[f^{-1}]_\bullet . Let \Gamma (D_+(f), \mathscr {O}) be the zeroth degree component S[f^{-1}]_0. This defines a sheaf over the projective spectrum, and moreover gives a scheme \operatorname {Proj}(S).

We claim that \operatorname {Proj}(S) can alternatively be given by gluing affine schemes. We assign D_+ (f) the affine scheme \operatorname {Spec}(S[f^{-1}]_0) (which is possible because the open subspace D_+ (f) is homeomorphic to \operatorname {Spec}(S[f^{-1}]_0) as a space). Given two positively graded elements f and g, we have an isomorphism between \operatorname {Proj}(S) restricted to D_+ (f g) and \operatorname {Spec}(S[f^{-1}]_0) restricted to D(g^{\deg f}/f^{\deg g}), given by the obvious ring isomorphism. We can verify that this satisfies the cocycle condition, and hence defines a scheme.

fr:title.text: Action of morphisms on stalks of locally ringed spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Action of morphisms on stalks of locally ringed spaces

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a morphism of ringed spaces \varphi : X \to Y, if it is local, a germ is invertible iff its pullback under \varphi is invertible. If the space X has enough points, then the inverse implication is also true.

Note that the stalk (\varphi ^{-1}\mathscr {O}_{Y})_x = \mathscr {O}_{Y, \varphi (x)}. A germ being invertible implies for some neighborhood U of x, it comes from an invertible section f \in \Gamma (U, \varphi ^{-1}\mathscr {O}_Y), so the image in \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O}_X) is also invertible, and hence the image germ. The locality condition gives the converse.
On the other hand, if the space has enough points, then being invertible at each stalk implies being invertible. This is enough to guarantee logical equivalence.

Morphism of affine schemes are in natural bijection with ring homomorphisms in the opposite direction. In other words, there is a fully faithful embedding \mathsf {CRing}^\textrm {op} \to \mathsf {Sch}.

Given two rings R, S, a ring homomorphism \varphi : S \to R naturally induces a map of distinguished opens f \mapsto \varphi (f). This is a continuous map \operatorname {Spec}(R) \to \operatorname {Spec}(S), because \varphi preserves \operatorname {lcm} and \gcd on radical ideals. For the structure sheaf, we can use the distinguished basis, thus we need to supply a ring homomorphism \Gamma (D(s), \mathscr {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}(S)}) \to \Gamma (D(r), \mathscr {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}(R)}) whenever D(r) \subseteq \varphi ^{-1}D(s) = D(\varphi (s)). This is just a homomorphism S[s^{-1}] \to R[r^{-1}], which is obvious because \varphi (s) must be invertible in R[r^{-1}].

We need to prove our map is local. Using the characterization on stalks, we just need to verify that S_{\varphi ^{-1}(\mathfrak {p})} \to R_{\mathfrak {p}} reflects invertibility. This is true by construction. Hence we have a map \hom _{\mathsf {CRing}}(S, R) \to \hom _{\mathsf {Sch}}(\operatorname {Spec}(R), \operatorname {Spec}(S)).

In general, a pullback is any contravariant functorial action. In other words, we have a functor F : \mathcal {C}^\textrm {op} \to \mathcal {D}, and pulling back along a morphism f in \mathcal {C} means the action of F(f).

In differential geometry, we have a set of k-forms \Omega ^k(M), which forms a functor \mathsf {Mfd}^\textrm {op} \to \mathsf {Set}. Pullbacks of differential forms is then the functorial action. In the special case of k = 0, this corresponds to composition, which is sometimes also referred to as pullbacks.
The categorical pullback can also be construed as a contravariant action, which forms the functor from \mathcal {C}^\textrm {op} to the 2-category \mathsf {Cat} given by taking slices.

Given a sheaf \mathscr {O} of rings, we can define a subsheaf \mathscr {O}^\times consisting of the invertible elements, i.e. \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O}^\times ) = \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O})^\times . This is the subsheaf of units.
This can be equivalently expressed as a pullback of \mathscr {O} \times \mathscr {O} \xrightarrow {(f,g) \mapsto f g} \mathscr {O} and 1 \xrightarrow {1} \mathscr {O}.
An affine scheme is a locally ringed space of the form \operatorname {Spec}(R) for some commutative ring R.
The locality requirement for a ringed space is to guarantee that the sections behave like functions valued in some field.

It is impossible in general to discuss the vanishing region of a section f \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O}). For instance, the germs of continuous functions are non-zero on their support, which is the closure of the non-vanishing region. In algebraic geometry, such an overspill destroys most valuable information. We can talk about the maximal region on which the section is invertible, but this is different from being non-zero if sections don’t behave like functions. Similarly, it is also impossible to discuss the value of a section at some point in general. In locally ringed space, we have .

Given two ringed spaces X, Y, a morphism \varphi : X \to Y is given by a continuous map of the underlying spaces, and a sheaf morphism \varphi ^{-1} \mathscr {O}_Y \to \mathscr {O}_X, equivalently \mathscr {O}_Y \to \varphi _* \mathscr {O}_X.
A scheme is a locally ringed space with an open covering on which the space is isomorphic to affine schemes.

fr:title.text: Value of section at a point

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Value of section at a point

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a locally ringed space and a section f \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O}), the germ of f at a point is an element of a local ring. The image of this element in the residue field, i.e. the quotient by the unique maximal ideal is called the value of this section at this point.
Given a ringed space, i.e. a space X with a sheaf of rings \mathscr {O}, it is said to be locally ringed iff the following conditions hold.

fr:ul.fr:li: If \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O}) = 0, then U is empty.
Suppose f + g \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O}) is invertible, then we can cover U with two open sets such that f and g are invertible when restricted respectively.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This can be unified as one condition: If a finite sum in \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O}) is invertible, then each summand is invertible when restricted to an open, which jointly covers U.
A ringed space is a space equipped with a sheaf of rings, called the structure sheaf.

The proofs in and do not make use of the multiplication on the numerators. Therefore they immediately generalizes to modules. In particular, we have a sheaf corresponding to an R-module M, whose sections over D(f) form the R[f^{-1}]-module M[f^{-1}]. The stalk on \left [\mathfrak {p}\right ] is isomorphic to M_{\left [\mathfrak {p}\right ]}.

fr:title.text: Stalk of the structure sheaf on {Spec}(R)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Stalk of the structure sheaf on \operatorname {Spec}(R)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a point \left [\mathfrak {p}\right ] \in \operatorname {Spec}(R), the stalk at the point is the localization R_{\mathfrak {p}}. In particular, the ring spectrum is a locally ringed space by .

We take a directed limit. The elements are from some R[f^{-1}] with \mathfrak {p} \nmid f, i.e. the elements can be written as g/f^n. Two elements are equal iff their common restriction to some D(f) is equal, i.e. g_1/f_1^n = g_2/f_2^m iff (g_1 f_2^m - g_2 f_1^n) f^k = 0. These are exactly the definition of the localization away from \mathfrak {p}.

fr:title.text: Stalks of locally ringed topological space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Stalks of locally ringed topological space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a ringed topological space, it is locally ringed iff every stalk is a local ring.

Recall the axiom for a local ring: if any sum is invertible, then one of the summand is invertible. When applied to the direct limit in each stalk, this immediately expands to the definition of a locally ringed space.

In particular, a crucial property is used in the reverse implication, i.e. if one open contains all the points of another, then the former covers the latter. This is equivalent to the condition of having enough points.

fr:title.text: Irreducible closeds in a ring spectrum

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Irreducible closeds in a ring spectrum

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A closed V(\mathfrak {r}) in \operatorname {Spec}(R) is irreducible iff \mathfrak {r} is prime, and it is an irreducible component iff \mathfrak {r} is a minimal prime ideal, i.e. prime ideals that divide no other prime ideals.
An irreducible closed is an irreducible component if it is contained in no other irreducible closed. We immediately get the definition of minimal prime ideals translating to the algebraic realm.

The spectrum of a noetherian ring is always noetherian: the closeds corresponds to radical ideals. The converse does not hold. Consider a polynomial ring with infinitely many indeterminates x_1, x_2, \dots quotiented by the relations x_k^k = 0. The ideals in the quotient ring correspond to ideals in the polynomial ring dividing x_k^k for every k. So there are only two radical ideals: the trivial one, and the one that divides all indeterminates, but not constants. Hence the spectrum must be a noetherian space, but the ring is obviously not noetherian since it is not finitely generated itself.

fr:title.text: Structure sheaf of a ring spectrum

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Structure sheaf of a ring spectrum

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a commutative ring R, we define a sheaf \mathscr {O} of rings on \operatorname {Spec}(R) called the structure sheaf. Let \Gamma (D(f), \mathscr {O}) = R[f^{-1}]. Suppose D(f) \subseteq D(g) we define the restriction morphism to be the localization map R[g^{-1}] \to R[f^{-1}], since by the latter is a further localization of the former. This turns \operatorname {Spec}(R) into a ringed space.

We just need to verify the sheaf axioms on the bases, i.e. given a family of elements f_i \in R such that \bigcup _i D(f_i) = D(f), we need to show that R[f^{-1}] \to \prod _{i \in I} R[f_i^{-1}] \rightrightarrows \prod _{i \ne j} R[(f_i f_j)^{-1}] is an equalizer. Notice that R[f_i^{-1}] \cong R[f^{-1}][f_i^{-1}]. So we may reassign S = R[f^{-1}]. This simplifies the problem to S \to \prod _{i \in I} S[f_i^{-1}] \rightrightarrows \prod _{i \ne j} S[(f_i f_j)^{-1}], where D(f_i) covers the whole space \operatorname {Spec}(S).

Suppose there are elements g_i/f_i^d \in S[f_i^{-1}], where we are allowed to use a single exponent d by finiteness. The compatibility requirement is (g_i f_j^d - g_j f_i^d) (f_i f_j)^{N} = 0. If there is a solution f to the gluing problem, it would need to satisfy (f f_i^d - g_i) f_i^M = 0. Since D(f_i) = D(f_i^R) covers \operatorname {Spec}(S), we have a linear combination 1 = \sum _i c_i f_i^R for large enough R. Hence f = \sum _{i \in I} c_i f f_i^R = \sum c_i g_i f_i^{R-d}. This uniquely determines f. And indeed, this solution satisfies our requirements, because when restricted to D(f_j), we have \begin {aligned} f f_j^d \cdot f_j^R &= \sum c_i g_i f_i^{R-d} f_j^{R+d} \\ &= \sum c_i g_j f_i^{R} f_j^{R} \\ &= g_j f_j^R \cdot \sum c_i f_i^R = g_j f_j^R. \end {aligned} This reasoning is valid as long as R > N + 2d.

If there are infinitely many opens, we first use quasi-compactness to select a finite number D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k) that covers the whole space. The uniqueness of gluing solutions in the finite case implies that of the infinite case. For existence, first take the solution f for D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k). Then consider the solution on D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k), D(g) for every g. This solution must be equal to f by uniqueness. Therefore f restrict to the correct function on each D(g), showing that f is the required solution.
I try to adhere to several principles when composing trees.

fr:ul.fr:li: If a definition or a lemma would present itself during a proof attempt, then do not introduce it until that part of the proof. The nature of forests makes this kind of organization more viable, as each definition is a tree by itself.
If a part of a proof has an easy constructive phrasing, use it and avoid classical reasoning. But if it requires some complication, then the classical way is used.

Avoid abstraction leaks. Even if A is defined as B, do not use them interchangeably. For instance, an ideal is defined as a subset of a ring satisfying certain conditions. But we will insist on writing ideals as numbers, for example saying \mathfrak {a} \mid x instead of x \in \mathfrak {a}. This is not too heretic, since algebraic number theory already uses this kind of notation. Similarly, although prime ideals correspond to points in \operatorname {Spec}(A), we do not identify them.
Apply unbiased terminology and negative thinking.

fr:title.text: {Spec}{R} is disconnected iff R is a product of non-zero rings

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: \operatorname {Spec}{R} is disconnected iff R is a product of non-zero rings

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a commutative ring R, \operatorname {Spec}{R} is disconnected iff R \cong R_1 \times R_2, where R_1, R_2 are non-zero commutative rings.

In one direction, if \operatorname {Spec}{R} is disconnected, we have two opens D(\mathfrak {a}) and D(\mathfrak {b}) whose intersection is empty and union is the entire space. In other words radical ideals \mathfrak {a}, \mathfrak {b} such that \sqrt {\gcd (\mathfrak {a}, \mathfrak {b})} = 1 (equivalent to \gcd (\mathfrak {a}, \mathfrak {b}) = 1) and \operatorname {lcm}(\mathfrak {a}, \mathfrak {b}) = 0. We have \mathfrak {a} \mid a and \mathfrak {b} \mid b such that a + b = 1. But \operatorname {lcm}(\mathfrak {a}, \mathfrak {b}) \mid a b, therefore a b = 0. This implies a(1-a) = 0, or a^2 = a. The same goes for b.

Let R_1 be the subset of R consisting of multiples of a. It contains an identity a, since a \cdot a x = a x by idempotence. Hence this subset forms a ring with the same addition and multiplication but a different identity. The same goes for R_2, the multiples of b. There is an obvious map R_1 \times R_2 \to R, given by (ax, by) \mapsto ax + by. This is an injection since z \mapsto a z recovers the first argument, and z \mapsto b z recovers the second. It is also a surjection because z = a z + b z is the image of (az, bz). Hence we found an isomorphism.
In the other direction, suppose R \cong R_1 \times R_2, then D((1,0)) and D((0,1)) separates the spectrum into two disjoint parts.
If a commutative ring R is noetherian, then R[x] is also noetherian.

Being noetherian is equivalent to having all ideals finitely generated. Suppose we have an ideal \mathfrak {a}R \subseteq R. We recursively produce a list of generators. Suppose we have already selected f_1, \dots , f_n. If this doesn’t generate \mathfrak {a}R, then we select another one of the lowest degree. We prove that this procedure terminates.

Consider the initial coefficient c_i of f_i. The ideal \mathfrak {c}_k generated by the first k elements must eventually stabilize. Let’s say c_{n+1} = \sum _{i=1}^n b_i c_i. Then we can subtract f_{n+1} by suitable multiples of f_1, \dots , f_n to cancel the leading term. This must not belong to ideal generated by f_1, \dots , f_n, which contradicts our choice of generators, being of the lowest degree.
The space \operatorname {Spec}(R) is always quasi-compact.

Since quasi-compectness can be tested on a basis, we just have to show that if \bigcup _i D(f_i) = \top , then there is a finite union equal to \top . Algebraically this means \sqrt {\gcd \{f_i\}} = 1, equivalently \gcd \{f_i\} = 1. So we have a linear combination \sum _k a_k f_k = 1. Crucially, this can only be a finite combination. Hence we can take the non-zero terms, whose corresponding opens already cover the whole space.

fr:title.text: A closed in a noetherian space is uniquely a finite union of irreducible closeds

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A closed in a noetherian space is uniquely a finite union of irreducible closeds

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If X is a noetherian space, then a closed Z \subseteq X can be written uniquely as the union of finitely many irreducible closeds.

We first deal with existence. By noetherianness, we perform well-founded induction. Suppose all the closed subsets of Z can be written as a finite union. If Z is irreducible then we’re done. Otherwise Z = Z_1 \cup Z_2 is a non-trivial union of two closeds. By the induction hypothesis Z_1 and Z_2 can be written as a finite union of irreducible closeds, which we can combine to get the desired union.

We then prove uniqueness. Suppose Z_1 \cup \cdots \cup Z_n = Z'_1 \cup \cdots \cup Z'_m. Consider the intersection with Z_1. The left hand side collapses to Z_1. The right hand side becomes \bigcup _{i=1}^m (Z'_i \cap Z_1). Since Z_1 is irreducible, Z'_i \cap Z_1 must be either Z_1 or empty. In the former case, since Z'_i is also irreducible, Z'_i = Z_1. Therefore each Z_j appears in the right hand side, and vice versa. Therefore the two sides are the same up to reordering and repetition.

The opens in the locale \operatorname {Spec}(R) bijectively corresponds to radical ideals of R, whose divisibility relation agree with the inverse inclusion relation of opens. Intersections correspond to lowest common multiple, and unions correspond to the radical of the greatest common divisor. In other words, the locale is isomorphic to the locale corresponding to the topological spectrum of a commutative ring by .

We can first put the opens in disjunctive normal form U = \bigcup _{i \in I} \bigcap _{j=1}^{n_i} D(f_{i, j}). By the definition we can reduce the intersections into products. Write f_i = \prod _j f_{i, j}, we have U = \bigcup _i D(f_i). Given this form, we can try to saturate the union, by throwing in everything that doesn’t enlarge U. In other words, we only consider the unions such that no other generator D(f) can be added, i.e. D(f) \nsubseteq U. This would uniquely determine U.

Such a saturated set would have to be closed under addition since D(f+g) \subseteq D(f) \cup D(g), and for the nullary case it must include D(0) = \bot . It also has to absorb multiplication, because D(f \cdot g) \subseteq D(f). This means we are dealing with ideals. Henceforth, we write D(\mathfrak {a}) for the union \bigcup _{\mathfrak {a} \mid f} D(f).

There is one last requirement we haven’t dealt with, i.e. D(f \cdot g) is the greatest lower bound of D(f) and D(g), instead of simply a lower bound. For example, this gives the equality D(f^n) = D(f), so we need to restrict our attention to radical ideals. It then suffices to prove that the radical ideal generated by f \cdot g is equal to the lowest common multiple of the radical ideals generated by f and g, which is true.
We define a basis of opens on \operatorname {Spec}(R) by D(f) for every element f \in R. These are called distinguished opens.

Given a commutative ring R, the ideals of R/\mathfrak {a} bijectively corresponds to the ideals in R that divides \mathfrak {a}. The ideals of R[S^{-1}] are generated by images of ideals in R under the localization map, written as \mathfrak {b}[S^{-1}], isomorphic to \mathfrak {b} \otimes _R R[S^{-1}].
The prime ideals in R that doesn’t intersect S bijectively correspond to prime ideals in R[S^{-1}] via the localization map.

fr:title.text: Localic spectrum of a commutative ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Localic spectrum of a commutative ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: To define functions on an “algebraic space”, we need to define the possible domains. The correct structure formed by the domains is a locale. Intuitively, the only algebraic way for a function to become partially defined is by having zero in the denominator f/g, so the domain should be the non-vanishing part of g, which we denote as D(g).

fr:title.text: Rational functions not definable via a single expression

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Rational functions not definable via a single expression

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can sometimes define two functions that agree on their common domain, which suggests we should be able to piece them together into a larger function. But this may not always be expressible with one single expression.

For example, on the space given by xy = zw, we can define a funtion given by x/w, which is equal to z/y. They are only jointly undefined on w = z = 0, but there is no single expression that achieves this.
Recognizing this, we can try to freely generate a locale using D(g) as generators. We would like some obvious relations corresponding to each algebraic operation in the ring.

fr:title.text: Localic spectrum of a commutative ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Localic spectrum of a commutative ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can actually produce a characterization of these generated opens. The following theorem is best read by skipping the statement and jump right into the proof, allowing the correct statement to gradually reveal itself.
