The opens in the locale \operatorname {Spec}(R) bijectively corresponds to radical ideals of R, whose divisibility relation agree with the inverse inclusion relation of opens. Intersections correspond to lowest common multiple, and unions correspond to the radical of the greatest common divisor. In other words, the locale is isomorphic to the locale corresponding to the topological spectrum of a commutative ring by .

We can first put the opens in disjunctive normal form U = \bigcup _{i \in I} \bigcap _{j=1}^{n_i} D(f_{i, j}). By the definition we can reduce the intersections into products. Write f_i = \prod _j f_{i, j}, we have U = \bigcup _i D(f_i). Given this form, we can try to saturate the union, by throwing in everything that doesn’t enlarge U. In other words, we only consider the unions such that no other generator D(f) can be added, i.e. D(f) \nsubseteq U. This would uniquely determine U.

Such a saturated set would have to be closed under addition since D(f+g) \subseteq D(f) \cup D(g), and for the nullary case it must include D(0) = \bot . It also has to absorb multiplication, because D(f \cdot g) \subseteq D(f). This means we are dealing with ideals. Henceforth, we write D(\mathfrak {a}) for the union \bigcup _{\mathfrak {a} \mid f} D(f).

There is one last requirement we haven’t dealt with, i.e. D(f \cdot g) is the greatest lower bound of D(f) and D(g), instead of simply a lower bound. For example, this gives the equality D(f^n) = D(f), so we need to restrict our attention to radical ideals. It then suffices to prove that the radical ideal generated by f \cdot g is equal to the lowest common multiple of the radical ideals generated by f and g, which is true.

fr:title.text: Localic spectrum of a commutative ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Localic spectrum of a commutative ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A space is noetherian if every descending chain of closeds, or equivalently every ascending chain of opens stabilizes. In other words, the partial order of closeds is well-founded.

fr:title.text: Rational functions not definable via a single expression

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Rational functions not definable via a single expression

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can sometimes define two functions that agree on their common domain, which suggests we should be able to piece them together into a larger function. But this may not always be expressible with one single expression.

For example, on the space given by xy = zw, we can define a funtion given by x/w, which is equal to z/y. They are only jointly undefined on w = z = 0, but there is no single expression that achieves this.

fr:title.text: Terminology of compactness in algebraic geometry

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Terminology of compactness in algebraic geometry

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The word compactness historically required the space to be Hausdorff. And the modern meaning of compactness was called quasi-compact. In algebraic geometry, most spaces are never Hausdorff, and the topological compactness condition does not lead to similar behavior. There is another notion more suitable as an analog of topological compactness. Therefore, we choose to always use the word “quasi-compact”.

fr:title.text: The radical ideal is the lcm of prime ideal divisors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The radical ideal is the lcm of prime ideal divisors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any ideal \mathfrak {a} of a commutative ring, the radical \sqrt {\mathfrak {a}} is the lowest common multiple of the prime ideals \mathfrak {p} \mid \mathfrak {a}.

On one hand, if \sqrt {\mathfrak {a}} \mid f, then \mathfrak {a} \mid f^n for some natural number n. This means for all \mathfrak {p} \mid \mathfrak {a}, we have \mathfrak {p} \mid f^n, which by being a prime ideal implies \mathfrak {p} \mid f.

On the other hand, suppose \mathfrak {a} \nmid f^n for any n, we construct a prime ideal divisor of \mathfrak {a} that is not a divisor of f. Consider the set of all ideals not a divisor of f^n for any n. This is partially ordered by divisibility and non-empty. Any chain of divisibility has its greatest common divisor \mathfrak {d} still in this set, since \mathfrak {d} divides exactly the elements divided by some ideal in the chain. By Zorn’s lemma, the set contains some \mathfrak {q} not divided by any other ideal in the set. This ideal must be prime: take \mathfrak {q} \nmid x, y such that \mathfrak {q} \mid x y, then \mathfrak {q}' = \gcd (\mathfrak {q}, x y) is a proper divisor of \mathfrak {q}, and by construction it cannot be in the previously constructed set. Hence there is some n such that x y \mid f^n, so \mathfrak {q} \mid x y \mid f^n, contradiction.

fr:title.text: Radical ideals bijectively correspond to open sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Radical ideals bijectively correspond to open sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In an arbitrary topological spectrum of a commutative ring, we have D(\mathfrak {a}) = D(\sqrt {\mathfrak {a}}). There is a containment of opens D(\mathfrak {a}) \subseteq D(\mathfrak {b}) — equivalently V(\mathfrak {b}) \subseteq V(\mathfrak {a}) — iff \sqrt {\mathfrak {b}} \mid \sqrt {\mathfrak {a}}, and the points contained in an open set completely determines the radical ideal.

Since \mathfrak {p} \mid \mathfrak {a} implies \sqrt {\mathfrak {p}} \mid \sqrt {\mathfrak {a}}, but \mathfrak {p} = \sqrt {\mathfrak {p}}, we see that D(\mathfrak {a}) = D(\sqrt {\mathfrak {a}}). We just have to prove the forward implication of the last statement. Suppose for all prime ideals \mathfrak {p} we have \mathfrak {p} \mid \mathfrak {b} \implies \mathfrak {p} \mid \mathfrak {a}. We need to prove that \sqrt {\mathfrak {a}} \mid f \implies \sqrt {\mathfrak {b}} \mid f.

Given \sqrt {\mathfrak {a}} \mid f, we have \mathfrak {p} \mid f for all prime ideals \mathfrak {p} \mid \sqrt {\mathfrak {a}} (which is equivalent to \mathfrak {p} \mid \mathfrak {a}). So we know that for all \mathfrak {p} \mid \mathfrak {b}, \mathfrak {p} \mid f. This is now purely a condition on \mathfrak {b}. The next lemma finishes the proof.

fr:title.text: The radical ideal is the lcm of prime ideal divisors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The radical ideal is the lcm of prime ideal divisors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any ideal \mathfrak {a} of a commutative ring, the radical \sqrt {\mathfrak {a}} is the lowest common multiple of the prime ideals \mathfrak {p} \mid \mathfrak {a}.

On one hand, if \sqrt {\mathfrak {a}} \mid f, then \mathfrak {a} \mid f^n for some natural number n. This means for all \mathfrak {p} \mid \mathfrak {a}, we have \mathfrak {p} \mid f^n, which by being a prime ideal implies \mathfrak {p} \mid f.

On the other hand, suppose \mathfrak {a} \nmid f^n for any n, we construct a prime ideal divisor of \mathfrak {a} that is not a divisor of f. Consider the set of all ideals not a divisor of f^n for any n. This is partially ordered by divisibility and non-empty. Any chain of divisibility has its greatest common divisor \mathfrak {d} still in this set, since \mathfrak {d} divides exactly the elements divided by some ideal in the chain. By Zorn’s lemma, the set contains some \mathfrak {q} not divided by any other ideal in the set. This ideal must be prime: take \mathfrak {q} \nmid x, y such that \mathfrak {q} \mid x y, then \mathfrak {q}' = \gcd (\mathfrak {q}, x y) is a proper divisor of \mathfrak {q}, and by construction it cannot be in the previously constructed set. Hence there is some n such that x y \mid f^n, so \mathfrak {q} \mid x y \mid f^n, contradiction.

fr:title.text: Topological spectrum of a commutative ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Topological spectrum of a commutative ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The topological spectrum of a commutative ring R, denoted \operatorname {Spec}(R), is a topological space whose points are given by prime ideals of R. We denote the point corresponding to \mathfrak {p} as \left [\mathfrak {p}\right ]. We define an open D(\mathfrak {a}) for each ideal \mathfrak {a} which contains the point \left [\mathfrak {p}\right ] when \mathfrak {p} \nmid \mathfrak {a}. The corresponding closed is written as V(\mathfrak {a}).
We abuse the notation and write D(f) for the case where \mathfrak {a} is generated by f. Similar notations apply to V.

Given a mathematical object X canonically associated with an effective chain complex C_\bullet (X) (e.g. the normalized chain complex of a simplicial set), it is said to be equipped with the structure of effective homology, if we have a strong homology equivalence C_\bullet (X) \mathbin {\Leftarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Leftrightarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Rightarrow } E_\bullet , such that E_\bullet is effective of finite type.

This is a set of notes on effective homology and algebraic topology. Main references are Constructive Homological Algebra and Applications and Discrete Vector Fields and Fundamental Algebraic Topology. We assume basic familiarity with the classical aspects of the theory, although there will also be links within this forest to the relevant concepts.

fr:ul.fr:li: W-bar construction, simplicial principal bundles, twisted products by Simplicial objects in algebraic topology
classifying space, loop space
composition of strong homology equivalence, tensor product, cone, bicomplex
simplicial group, Kan complex
organize into notes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A strong homology equivalence between chain complexes C and D is a span of chain reductions, i.e. a third chain complex X with X \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow C and X \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D. We denote a strong homology equivalence with C \mathbin {\Leftarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Leftrightarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Rightarrow } D.

fr:title.text: Perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D and a perturbation \delta _C for C, we assume that h_{\rho } \mathbin {\circ } \delta _C is pointwise nilpotent, i.e. \forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb {N}, \; (h_{\rho }\delta _C)^n (c) = 0. We can construct a new chain reduction \rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D', where C' is C perturbed by \delta _C.
Note that this situation is much harder compared to , as it is generally impossible without the added condition.

For this construction using the third equivalent definition of a chain reduction in , i.e. a homotopy operator on C such that h \mathbin {\circ } h = 0 and h \mathbin {\circ } d_C \mathbin {\circ } h = h.

From the informal discussion above, we can conjecture the formula h' = \sum _{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h. This reveals the reason for our pointwise nilpotency condition. With a little bit of care manipulating the infinite sum, we can prove that h' \mathbin {\circ } h' = 0 from h \mathbin {\circ } h = 0, and the second equation follows from a nice telescopic sum \begin {aligned} h' \mathbin {\circ } (d_C + \delta _C) \mathbin {\circ } h' &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta _C)^i h (d_C + \delta _C) (h \delta _C)^j h \\ &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left [(h \delta _C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^{i + j} h\right ] \\ &= \sum _{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left [(h \delta _C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^k h\right ] \\ &= \sum _k (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h = h'. \end {aligned}

We can reconstruct the other two components of the reduction \iota _{\rho '} and \pi _{\rho '} through . In particular, D' is given by a perturbation of D. We only write down the results below for easy reference. \begin {aligned} \pi _{\rho '} &= \sum _{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k \pi _{\rho } (\delta _C h_{\rho })^k \\ \iota _{\rho '} &= \sum _{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k (h_{\rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{\rho } \\ \delta _D &= \sum _{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k \pi _{\rho } \delta _C (h_{\rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{\rho }. \end {aligned}
The following data are equivalent.

fr:ul.fr:li: A chain reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D.
A splitting C \cong D \oplus E, where E is a split exact.
A chain homotopy h : C \to C satisfying h \mathbin {\circ } h = 0 and h \mathbin {\circ } d_C \mathbin {\circ } h = h.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Substituting the requirement that h is a homotopy \textrm {id} \to g \mathbin {\circ } f, we get the equation d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } r_k + r_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_k = \textrm {id}, where d is the boundary operator on E_\bullet . In other words, r is a null-homotopy of E_\bullet , rendering it split exact. Conversely, given C \cong D \oplus E, we can reconstruct f and g as the projection and inclusion maps, with h obtained out of r in the manner depicted above.

Finally, restricting h onto D_k we see that it must be zero, since h(\textrm {id} - p) = h - h \mathbin {\circ } d \mathbin {\circ } h = 0. This means that all the information of h can be reconstructed from the splitting, and thus all three sets of data are equivalent.

fr:title.text: Perturbation of the smaller chain complex in a chain reduction

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Perturbation of the smaller chain complex in a chain reduction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D and a perturbation \delta _D for D, we can construct a perturbation \delta _C for C, such that the same \rho can serve as a reduction of the perturbed chain complexes.

Let the reduction \rho be made out of the three maps \pi _{\rho } : C \to D, \iota _{\rho } : D \to C and h_{\rho } : C \to C. Then since C splits as the direct sum of D and an acyclic complex, we can simply copy over the perturbation, and leave the acyclic part untouched. This gives us the definition \delta _C = \iota _{\rho } \mathbin {\circ } \delta _D \mathbin {\circ } \pi _{\rho }. A quick computation shows that \rho is still a reduction of the perturbed chain complexes.

fr:title.text: Terminology of effective algebraic cellular complex

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Terminology of effective algebraic cellular complex

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The terminology chosen here differs from that in Kenzo. What we call effective is named locally effective; and what we call effective of finite type is named effective instead.

fr:title.text: Geometric interpretation of algebraic cellular complex

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Geometric interpretation of algebraic cellular complex

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An ACC can be viewed as the algebraic distillation of a chain complex. The generators in dimension n are regarded as n-cells. However, we only record a formal sum of the boundaries, and forget the exact configuration. Hence, ACC is a suitable middle ground for both geometric transformations and algebraic operations.
For ACCs, the effect of a perturbation is to “reconnect” the cells. But it may not create or delete cells, since the abelian groups are unchanged.
A perturbation of a chain complex with boundary operator d is an operator \delta of degree (-1) such that d + \delta also forms a boundary operator.

Given an algebraic cellular complex, suppose we can encode the basis sets C_\bullet such that they have decidable equality, and the maps C_k \to \mathbb {Z}[C_{k-1}] are computable, then we say the ACC is effective. Suppose further that C_\bullet are (computably) finite sets, then we say it is effective of finite type.

fr:title.text: An additive functor is exact iff it preserves quasi-isomorphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: An additive functor is exact iff it preserves quasi-isomorphisms

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an additive functor F : \mathcal {A} \to \mathcal {B} between abelian categories, it is exact iff it sends quasi-isomorphisms to quasi-isomorphisms.
Suppose an additive functor preserves quasi-isomorphisms. Since a chain complex is exact iff it is quasi-isomorphic to the zero complex, the functor must preserve exactness.

On the other hand, exact functors commute with homology functors. Therefore if f : C_\bullet \to D_\bullet is a quasi-isomorphism, H_n (f) are all isomorphisms. Therefore H_n (F(f)) = F(H_n(f)) is the functorial action on an isomorphism, which must also produce an isomorphism.

Given two chain complexes C_\bullet and D_\bullet with two chain maps f, g : C \to D between them, a chain homotopy from f to g is given by a family of maps h_n : C_n \to D_{n+1}, such that d_{n+1} \mathbin {\circ } h_n + h_{n-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_n = f_n - g_n. Note that the two d’s denote the boundary map of different chain complexes.
The chain homotopy can be written as h : f \to g or as h : C \to D. This causes no confusion, and the latter is convenient in situations where the maps f, g matter less than their difference f - g.

Given two chain complexes C, D, a chain reduction consists of a chain map \pi : C \to D, a chain map \iota : D \to C and a chain homotopy h : \textrm {id} \to g \mathbin {\circ } f, such that \pi \mathbin {\circ } \iota = \textrm {id}, and \pi \mathbin {\circ } h = h \mathbin {\circ } \iota = h \mathbin {\circ } h = 0. Here the compositions are understood to have the appropriate subscript so the degrees match.
We write the reduction as \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D. The three components are denoted \pi _{\rho } : C \to D, \iota _{\rho } : D \to C and h_{\rho } : C \to C, respectively.

For a chain reduction C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D, D is embedded as a subcomplex of C. It is cleanly separated, indicating that it is split. The other part of C is split exact, and so its homology component is drawn as empty, with the components separated.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs} \usetikzlibrary{decorations.pathreplacing}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An algebraic cellular complex (or ACC) is a chain complex of free abelian groups. The generators are called cells, and the boundary maps can be expressed using the generators as a basis, yielding the incidence matrices.

More precisely, we may define an ACC as a sequence of sets C_\bullet , with a sequence of functions d : C_k \to \mathbb {Z}[C_{k-1}], such that d^2 = 0 is satisfied. When a generator has non-zero coefficient in some d\sigma , the generator is called a face of \sigma .
Note that the generators of these chain groups are canonically chosen as part of the data. So a more accurate definition is a chain complex in the Kleisli category of abelian groups.
We can visualize a filtered object F_1 A \subseteq F_2 A \subseteq F_3 A \subseteq A as nested rectangles. The graded components of this filtration are the individual rectangular regions.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs} \usetikzlibrary{decorations.pathreplacing}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Combining and , we arrive at the following picture. Each family of colors corresponds to the filtration F_\bullet C_n in one dimension, and the different shades corresponds to the degree in the filtration.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs} \usetikzlibrary{decorations.pathreplacing}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that we arranged so that only the higher degree (i.e. the lighter color) components may touch the lower degree components in the next dimension. So the intersection is a triangle shape instead of a complete diamond grid. This corresponds to the requirement that the boundary map sends F_i C_j to F_i C_{j+1}.

Given a short exact sequence of chain complexes 0 \to A_\bullet \to B_\bullet \to C_\bullet \to 0, there is a long exact sequence of homology groups \cdots \to H_{n+1}(C) \xrightarrow {\partial } H_n(A) \to H_n (B) \to H_n (C) \xrightarrow {\partial } H_{n-1} (A) \to \cdots The map \partial here is, after unpacking some quotients, simply the boundary map B_n \to B_{n-1}.
There are multiple ways to prove this claim. We can first prove it in categories of modules, and use the Freyd–Mitchell embedding. We can also use pseudo-elements to perform diagram chases.

fr:title.text: Using the Freyd–Mitchell embedding to prove theorems

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Using the Freyd–Mitchell embedding to prove theorems

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We use the snake lemma as an example to demonstrate how the embedding theorem works in practice. The main technique is to avoid dealing with large categories.

Suppose we have already proved the theorem in module categories. Given a snake lemma diagram in an arbitrary (locally small) abelian category \mathcal {C}, we take the smallest full subcategory closed under finite limits and colimits. This results in a small category \mathcal {D}, which we can embed in a module category R\text {-}\mathsf {Mod}.

Now, the snake lemma in module categories implies that we have the required maps that forms an exact sequence. Since \mathcal {D} is a full abelian subcategory of R\text {-}\mathsf {Mod}, these morphisms are contained in \mathcal {D}, and the sequence is still exact. And since \mathcal {D} is a full abelian subcategory of \mathcal {C}, the sequence is again exact in \mathcal {C}.

Abelian categories are one step further from additive categories. Similar to the situation of abelian groups or modules, every morphism f : X \to Y has four key components, the image, the kernel, the coimage X / \ker f, and the cokernel Y / \operatorname {im} f. The image is always identical with the coimage, representing the core part of the homomorphism. The kernel perfectly measures the failure of injectivity, and the cokernel perfectly measures the failure of surjectivity. This is in stark constrast with general maps, where the failure of injectivity may be heterogeneous, and thus cannot be simply characterized.

Since many operations on abelian groups and R-modules can be performed on chain complexes, we wish to axiomatize an abstract notion to encapsulate them all. This motivates the definition of additive and abelian categories. We can use the three examples mentioned above as the source for intuitions for abelian categories.

First, we wish to let the morphisms form abelian groups. This turns out to have a surprising impact on the structure of categories, the most important of which is the coincidence of finite products and coproducts.

Given a category \mathcal {C}, an \mathsf {Ab}-enrichment is given by abelian group structures on every hom-set, such that composition is linear in each argument. In other words, we have a homomorphism \hom (Y, Z) \otimes \hom (X, Y) \to \hom (X, Z).

Let \mathcal {C} be \mathsf {Ab}-enriched. The finite products and coproducts, if they exist, are isomorphic via a canonical map. If they all exist, then this category is called an additive category. In particular, the nullary product and coproduct coincide, and we call the object zero object, denoted 0.

When there are finitely many objects involved, we can construct an inverse. Consider the morphisms \prod _i X_i \xrightarrow {\pi _j} X_j \xrightarrow {\iota _j} \coprod _i X_i. We claim the sum of these morphisms is the desired inverse. To verify this, we compose them. Using bilinearity, we are reduced to showing that the coproduct and product of the identity map is the identity, which is true.

Due to this coincidence creating gadgets with two universal properties, the structure of additive categories are uniquely determined. This also means that we only need very mild conditions on functors to preserve the structures of an additive category.

fr:title.text: Being an additive category is a property

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Being an additive category is a property

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a category, if it can be endowed with an \mathsf {Ab}-enrichment that makes it an additive category, then it only has one possible enrichment. In particular, there is at most one way to turn a category into an additive category.
Notice that having finite products and coproducts is a property, and the canonical morphism between them being an isomorphism is also a property. These do not mention the enrichment structure.

With these properties satisfied, the addition structure on the \hom -sets are fixed. We claim that the additive neutral element is given by the composition X \to 0 \to Y, and given two parallel morphisms f, g : X \to Y, the following composition X \xrightarrow {\Delta } X \oplus X \xrightarrow {f \oplus g} Y \oplus Y \xrightarrow {\nabla } Y. is equal to the addition f + g. For disambiguation, we temporarily denote these constructions as 0' and f +' g. By interpreting \oplus as a product or a coproduct at appropriate times, it is easy to see that 0' is indeed the neutral element for +'.

Recall that arrows X \oplus X \to Y \oplus Y is given by a 2 \times 2 matrix, and this correspondence is an abelian group isomorphism by general enriched category theory. f \oplus g comes from a diagonal matrix with f, g as entries, so this operation is linear, which entails +' is also linear. By the Eckmann–Hilton argument, the two addition operations must coincide.
Given two additive categories and a functor F : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {D} between them, the following are equivalent. In this case, we call the functor additive.

fr:ul.fr:li: The functor preserves finite products.
The functor preserves finite coproducts.
The functor is a homomorphism on the abelian groups \hom _{\mathcal {C}}(X, Y), i.e. it is an \mathsf {Ab}-enriched functor.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the equivalence of the first two claims, we have a composition F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y), where the middle morphism comes from the canonical isomorphism X + Y \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y). The first two claim is equivalent to the right and left arrows being iso, respectively. Recall that a morphism from a coproduct to a product is determined by a matrix of morphisms. With this fact and the functoriality of F, we can compute that the composition is the canonical isomorphism from F(X) + F(Y) to F(X) \times F(Y). Therefore the leftmost arrow being iso is equivalent to the rightmost arrow being iso.

Since the abelian group structure on morphisms is uniquely determined from the finite products and coproducts in an additive category, a functor satisfying the first two conditions automatically satisfies the third. Conversely, we need to prove the canonical maps F(1) \to 1 and F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y) are isomorphisms. For the first one, since 1 is also the initial object, any morphism into it is automatically iso. For the second one, we again look at the diagram which composes to an isomorphism: F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y). Using the bilinearity of composition and that F preserves addition on morphisms, we can verify that this provides a two-sided inverse.
In an adjunction F \dashv G, both functors are automatically additive.
Since the left adjoint preserves colimits, it preserves finite coproducts. Therefore by it is an additive functor. Dually, the right adjoint preserves limits, and is also additive.
Kernels and cokernels are also greatly simplified in additive categories.

fr:title.text: Equalizers can be reduced to kernels in {Ab}-enriched categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equalizers can be reduced to kernels in \mathsf {Ab}-enriched categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can express equalizers with kernels (which are equalizers with the zero morphism).
We simply need to note that an equalizer for f and g is equivalent to an equalizer for (f-g) and 0, by bilinearity of composition.

Abelian categories are one step further from additive categories. Similar to the situation of abelian groups or modules, every morphism f : X \to Y has four key components, the image, the kernel, the coimage X / \ker f, and the cokernel Y / \operatorname {im} f. The image is always identical with the coimage, representing the core part of the homomorphism. The kernel perfectly measures the failure of injectivity, and the cokernel perfectly measures the failure of surjectivity. This is in stark constrast with general maps, where the failure of injectivity may be heterogeneous, and thus cannot be simply characterized.
Given an additive category, it is an abelian category if the following condition holds.

fr:ul.fr:li: Every morphism has a kernel and a cokernel.
Every monomorphism is the kernel of its cokernel.
Every epimorphism is the cokernel of its kernel.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The definition of abelian categories may look intimidating, but thinking of it as R-modules is a very effective way to reduce mental load. In fact, the Freyd–Mitchell embedding theorem justifies this to some extent, allowing us to use familiar language such as taking and manipulating elements.

Although practically every important functor between additive categories is additive, the same cannot be said for abelian categories. Functors preserving the structure of abelian categories are called exact, but many functors fail to satisfy this for various reasons. One of the main endeavours of homological algebra is to characterize the failures of exactness, and study their consequences. This leads to intricate and beautiful structures emerging.
An additive functor F : \mathcal {A} \to \mathcal {B} between abelian categories is left exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions.

fr:ul.fr:li: It preserves kernels.
It preserves finite limits.
It preserves the exactness of sequences 0 \to A \to B \to C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Dually, an additive functor is right exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions.

fr:ul.fr:li: It preserves cokernels.
It preserves finite colimits.
It preserves the exactness of sequences A \to B \to C \to 0.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If a functor is both left exact and right exact, it is simply called an exact functor, which is equivalent to it preserving the exactness of sequences A \to B \to C.
Since additive functors already preserves finite products, and kernels are equivalent to general equalizers using the additive structure, the first two conditions are equivalent.
The sequence A \rightarrowtail B \to C being exact is equivalent to A being a kernel of B \to C. So the third condition is equivalent to the first. This completes the equivalence proof.

fr:title.text: Equalizers can be reduced to kernels in {Ab}-enriched categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equalizers can be reduced to kernels in \mathsf {Ab}-enriched categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can express equalizers with kernels (which are equalizers with the zero morphism).
We simply need to note that an equalizer for f and g is equivalent to an equalizer for (f-g) and 0, by bilinearity of composition.

fr:title.text: Kernel, image, cokernel and coimage of chain complexes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kernel, image, cokernel and coimage of chain complexes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a chain map f_\bullet : C_\bullet \to D_\bullet , we can take the kernel, image, cokernel and coimage in each dimension, to obtain new chain complexes. It is a matter of unpacking and repacking quotients to verify that the relevant squares commute, rendering the following diagram of chain complexes.

The sequence A \rightarrowtail B \to C being exact is equivalent to A being a kernel of B \to C. So the third condition is equivalent to the first. This completes the equivalence proof.

fr:title.text: Monomorphisms can be expressed using finite limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monomorphisms can be expressed using finite limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a morphism f : X \to Y in an arbitrary category, we can express the condition of being monic using finite limits.

On the other hand, if the diagram is a pullback, then for every pair of morphisms g, h : Z \rightrightarrows X, we can draw the diagram above, and obtain the dashed arrow k : Z \to X. The diagram commuting implies g = \textrm {id} \mathbin {\circ } k = h.

Given a category \mathcal {C}, an \mathsf {Ab}-enrichment is given by abelian group structures on every hom-set, such that composition is linear in each argument. In other words, we have a homomorphism \hom (Y, Z) \otimes \hom (X, Y) \to \hom (X, Z).
Any small abelian category can be realized as a full abelian subcategory of a category of left R-modules for some ring R.
(TODO)
It is fruitful to manipulate chain complexes as a whole. This allows us to neatly package some common algebraic operations.

fr:title.text: Direct sum and product of chain complexes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum and product of chain complexes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a family of chain complexes C_{\alpha , \bullet }, we can take the direct sum in each dimension, giving D_\bullet = \bigoplus _\alpha C_{\alpha , \bullet }, which is another chain complex. Dually, we can take the direct product \prod _\alpha C_{\alpha , \bullet }.

As another example, the consideration of quotienting out a subspace Y \subseteq X naturally leads us to relative homology. We construct a chain complex by taking a quotient in each dimension: 0 \to C_\bullet (Y) \hookrightarrow C_\bullet (X) \to C_\bullet (X, Y) \to 0. These maps commute with the boundary maps, so it can be regarded as an exact sequence of chain complexes. Thus we are led to the following definitions.

A bicomplex is a chain complex of chain complexes. More specifically, we have a grid of objects A_{m, n}, vertical maps d : A_{m, n} \to A_{m, n-1} and horizontal maps \delta : A_{m, n} \to A_{m-1, n}. Every square in the grid commutes, and d^2 = \delta ^2 = 0.

Each column A_{m, \bullet } in the bicomplex is a chain complex, and \delta are chain maps between the column complexes. Similarly, each row forms a chain complex, and d are chain maps between the row complexes.
An exact sequence of chain complexes C_{m, \bullet } is a bicomplex such that the rows are exact.

fr:title.text: Kernel, image, cokernel and coimage of chain complexes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kernel, image, cokernel and coimage of chain complexes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a chain map f_\bullet : C_\bullet \to D_\bullet , we can take the kernel, image, cokernel and coimage in each dimension, to obtain new chain complexes. It is a matter of unpacking and repacking quotients to verify that the relevant squares commute, rendering the following diagram of chain complexes.

An additive functor F : \mathcal {A} \to \mathcal {B} between abelian categories is left exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions.

fr:ul.fr:li: It preserves kernels.
It preserves finite limits.
It preserves the exactness of sequences 0 \to A \to B \to C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Dually, an additive functor is right exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions.

fr:ul.fr:li: It preserves cokernels.
It preserves finite colimits.
It preserves the exactness of sequences A \to B \to C \to 0.

Since additive functors already preserves finite products, and kernels are equivalent to general equalizers using the additive structure, the first two conditions are equivalent.
The sequence A \rightarrowtail B \to C being exact is equivalent to A being a kernel of B \to C. So the third condition is equivalent to the first. This completes the equivalence proof.

Since \hom (P, -) preserves limits, by it is left exact. Similarly \hom (-, I) is right exact. Therefore we naturally want to find out when \hom (P, -) is right exact. We only need to guarantee that \hom (P, -) preserves epimorphisms. This can be unpackaged to the following definition.

In an abelian category, an object P is projective iff for every morphism P \to B can be lifted through an epimorphism A \twoheadrightarrow B, i.e. there exists a (non-unique) morphism P \to A making the triangle commute.

Projective objects are defined to capture a key property of free objects. For an arbitrary abelian group P, lifting a map P \to B through an epimorphism requires us to pick a lifting for every generator, such that the relations between the generators still hold after lifting. If such a thing can always be done, then we may say that the relations, or tangling between generators are practically non-existent. A projective object can thus be reguarded as generated by some elements with zero or undetectable “tangling”.
As an example, consider the projective objects in the category of modules. We can give a nice characterization of projective modules.

fr:title.text: Projective modules are direct summands of free modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Projective modules are direct summands of free modules

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the abelian category of modules over a ring R, the projective object modules are exactly the modules that appear as a direct summand of some free module P \oplus Q = R^{\oplus n}.
A free module evidently projective. If P is a direct summand of a projective module Q, then we can extend any map P \to B to Q by zero. Then the projectivity of Q implies that of P.

On the other hand, suppose P is projective, then we have an epimorphism R^{\oplus |P|} \twoheadrightarrow P. The identity map P \to P lifts against this epimorphism to a splitting of it, hence P is its direct summand.
Dually, we have the definition of injective objects, which make \hom (-, I) exact.
In an abelian category, an object I is injective iff every morphism B \to I can be extended along monomorphisms B \rightarrowtail A. Equivalently, it is a projective object in the dual category.
As an example, we characterize injective abelian groups. Similar characterizations can be done for modules over principal ideal domains.

fr:title.text: Abelian groups are injective iff divisible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Abelian groups are injective iff divisible

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An abelian group G is injective iff it is divisible, i.e. for element g \in G and positive integer n, there exists a (non-unique) solution of nx = g.

In one direction, suppose the group is injective, then the map \mathbb {Z} \to G defined by k \mapsto k g can be extended along the monomorphism (n \times -) : \mathbb {Z} \to \mathbb {Z}. This provides the division.

On the other hand, suppose divisibility holds. Given a morphism f : A \to G and an injection A \hookrightarrow B, we extend f to B by Zorn's lemma. Consider the poset of homomorphisms extending f to some subgroup of B. Given a chain in this poset, we can take the union to create an upper bound. And it is non-empty since f is an element. Hence it has a maximal element \phi . Suppose it is defined on B' \subsetneq B, then there is an element b \in B not in B'. Suppose n b \notin B' for all non-zero integers n, then we can define a larger homomorphism on B + \mathbb {Z} b, contradicting the maximality. Suppose there is some n b \in B', then by divisibility we can assign \phi (b) a division of \phi (n b) by n. This too contradicts maximality.
Given an additive category, it is an abelian category if the following condition holds.

fr:ul.fr:li: Every morphism has a kernel and a cokernel.
Every monomorphism is the kernel of its cokernel.
Every epimorphism is the cokernel of its kernel.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Being an additive category is a property

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a category, if it can be endowed with an \mathsf {Ab}-enrichment that makes it an additive category, then it only has one possible enrichment. In particular, there is at most one way to turn a category into an additive category.
Notice that having finite products and coproducts is a property, and the canonical morphism between them being an isomorphism is also a property. These do not mention the enrichment structure.

With these properties satisfied, the addition structure on the \hom -sets are fixed. We claim that the additive neutral element is given by the composition X \to 0 \to Y, and given two parallel morphisms f, g : X \to Y, the following composition X \xrightarrow {\Delta } X \oplus X \xrightarrow {f \oplus g} Y \oplus Y \xrightarrow {\nabla } Y. is equal to the addition f + g. For disambiguation, we temporarily denote these constructions as 0' and f +' g. By interpreting \oplus as a product or a coproduct at appropriate times, it is easy to see that 0' is indeed the neutral element for +'.

Recall that arrows X \oplus X \to Y \oplus Y is given by a 2 \times 2 matrix, and this correspondence is an abelian group isomorphism by general enriched category theory. f \oplus g comes from a diagonal matrix with f, g as entries, so this operation is linear, which entails +' is also linear. By the Eckmann–Hilton argument, the two addition operations must coincide.

A bicomplex is a chain complex of chain complexes. More specifically, we have a grid of objects A_{m, n}, vertical maps d : A_{m, n} \to A_{m, n-1} and horizontal maps \delta : A_{m, n} \to A_{m-1, n}. Every square in the grid commutes, and d^2 = \delta ^2 = 0.

Each column A_{m, \bullet } in the bicomplex is a chain complex, and \delta are chain maps between the column complexes. Similarly, each row forms a chain complex, and d are chain maps between the row complexes.

fr:title.text: Direct sum and product of chain complexes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum and product of chain complexes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a family of chain complexes C_{\alpha , \bullet }, we can take the direct sum in each dimension, giving D_\bullet = \bigoplus _\alpha C_{\alpha , \bullet }, which is another chain complex. Dually, we can take the direct product \prod _\alpha C_{\alpha , \bullet }.
An exact sequence of chain complexes C_{m, \bullet } is a bicomplex such that the rows are exact.
It is fruitful to manipulate chain complexes as a whole. This allows us to neatly package some common algebraic operations.

fr:title.text: Direct sum and product of chain complexes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum and product of chain complexes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a family of chain complexes C_{\alpha , \bullet }, we can take the direct sum in each dimension, giving D_\bullet = \bigoplus _\alpha C_{\alpha , \bullet }, which is another chain complex. Dually, we can take the direct product \prod _\alpha C_{\alpha , \bullet }.

As another example, the consideration of quotienting out a subspace Y \subseteq X naturally leads us to relative homology. We construct a chain complex by taking a quotient in each dimension: 0 \to C_\bullet (Y) \hookrightarrow C_\bullet (X) \to C_\bullet (X, Y) \to 0. These maps commute with the boundary maps, so it can be regarded as an exact sequence of chain complexes. Thus we are led to the following definitions.

A bicomplex is a chain complex of chain complexes. More specifically, we have a grid of objects A_{m, n}, vertical maps d : A_{m, n} \to A_{m, n-1} and horizontal maps \delta : A_{m, n} \to A_{m-1, n}. Every square in the grid commutes, and d^2 = \delta ^2 = 0.

Each column A_{m, \bullet } in the bicomplex is a chain complex, and \delta are chain maps between the column complexes. Similarly, each row forms a chain complex, and d are chain maps between the row complexes.
An exact sequence of chain complexes C_{m, \bullet } is a bicomplex such that the rows are exact.

fr:title.text: Kernel, image, cokernel and coimage of chain complexes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kernel, image, cokernel and coimage of chain complexes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a chain map f_\bullet : C_\bullet \to D_\bullet , we can take the kernel, image, cokernel and coimage in each dimension, to obtain new chain complexes. It is a matter of unpacking and repacking quotients to verify that the relevant squares commute, rendering the following diagram of chain complexes.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A short exact sequence is an exact sequence with all but three consecutive terms being zero. It is often written as 0 \to A \to B \to C \to 0. The short exact sequence describes how B is made up of a subobject A and a quotient C.

Some sources require a bicomplex to have anti-commuting squares. In this way, the total complex has the simpler differential \partial = d + \delta . These two definitions are convertible by flipping the signs of the horizontal boundary maps in every other row.

Given a bicomplex C_{\bullet , \bullet }, we can collapse it into a chain complex in two ways. In either way, C_{p, q} is contained in the total complex at degree (m+n). We can use the direct sum to combine them: \operatorname {Tot}^\oplus (C)_n = \bigoplus _{n = p+q} C_{p, q}, or the direct product: \operatorname {Tot}^\Pi (C)_n = \prod _{n=p+q} C_{p,q}.

The total differential acts on elements in C_{p, q} by \partial (x) = d(x) + (-1)^q \delta (x), where d is the vertical map, and \delta the horizontal map. The sign here is to ensure that \partial ^2 = 0.
If all the homology groups vanish, then the chain complex is said fo be acyclic or exact. Equivalently, every cycle is a boundary.

Chain complexes arose from combinatorial topology, in the form of a sequence of abelian groups C_n freely generated by cells of dimension n (i.e. encoding the formal sums of cells), and a boundary operator d_n : C_n \to C_{n-1}. The critical feature of the operator is d_{n-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_n = 0, simply written as d^2 = 0, reflecting a deep geometric phenomenon that the boundary of a shape doesn’t have any boundary itself.
A chain complex of abelian groups is given by a sequence of abelian groups G_\bullet together with homomorphisms d_n : G_n \to G_{n-1}, such that d_{n-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_n = 0.
This is eligible to immediate generalization.
A chain complex of R-modules is given by a sequence of modules M_\bullet together with R-linear maps d_n : R_n \to R_{n-1}, such that d_{n-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_n = 0.

Homology can be defined using this algebraic information, without any further reference to topology. Homological algebra is then the algebraic part of reasoning utilized in algebraic topology, repackaged as a stand-alone branch of mathematics. We recall some basics of what we’ve got from algebraic topology.

Given a chain complex, the cycles Z_n of dimension n are given by the kernel of d_n : C_n \to C_{n-1}. The boundaries B_n are given by the image of d_{n+1} : C_{n+1} \to C_n. The equation d^2 = 0 is equivalent to 0 \subseteq B_n \subseteq Z_n \subseteq C_n. We can define quotient groups to measure the gaps in the inclusion chain. By the homomorphism theorem, the quotient C_n / Z_n is isomorphic to the image of d_n, which is the next boundary B_{n-1}. On the other hand, the homology groups H_n(C) are defined as the quotient Z_n/B_n.

Since the boundary subgroup in one dimension can also be considered as a quotient in a lower dimension, it may be beneficial to identify the two in a visualization. This leads to the following picture. Regions appearing to the right are to be considered as quotients, and those to the left as subobjects. Further development of this visualization scheme can be seen here.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs} \usetikzlibrary{decorations.pathreplacing}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We chose to draw circles to emphasize the individual chain groups. In more complicated situations, it is more convenient to draw a chain of rectangles, with each chain group spanning three rectangular regions. We would then need other means to convey the confines of each object.
Given two chain complexes C_\bullet , D_\bullet , the natural notion of morphisms between them is chain maps, i.e. a sequence of maps f_n : C_n \to D_n such that all the squares commute.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

\begin {tikzcd} \cdots & {C_{n+1}} & {C_n} & {C_{n-1}} & \cdots \\ \cdots & {D_{n+1}} & {D_n} & {D_{n-1}} & \cdots \arrow ["d", from=1-3, to=1-4] \arrow ["{f_n}"', from=1-3, to=2-3] \arrow ["{f_{n-1}}"', from=1-4, to=2-4] \arrow ["d"', from=2-3, to=2-4] \arrow ["d"', from=2-2, to=2-3] \arrow ["d", from=1-2, to=1-3] \arrow [from=1-1, to=1-2] \arrow [from=2-1, to=2-2] \arrow [from=1-4, to=1-5] \arrow [from=2-4, to=2-5] \arrow ["{f_{n+1}}"', from=1-2, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd}

fr:title.text: Chain maps induce maps on homology

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Chain maps induce maps on homology

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A chain map f : C \to D induces a family of homomorphisms f_* : H_n (C) \to H_n (D) on the homology groups. The identity map induces the identity morphism, and a composition of maps f \mathbin {\circ } g induces composition homomorphism (f \mathbin {\circ } g)_* = f_* \mathbin {\circ } g_*.
Since f commutes with the boundary maps, it maps the boundaries in C_n to the boundaries in D_n. Therefore the map is well-defined after passing to the quotient.
A chain map is a quasi-isomorphism if it induces isomorphisms on the homology groups.
If all the homology groups vanish, then the chain complex is said fo be acyclic or exact. Equivalently, every cycle is a boundary.

A short exact sequence is an exact sequence with all but three consecutive terms being zero. It is often written as 0 \to A \to B \to C \to 0. The short exact sequence describes how B is made up of a subobject A and a quotient C.

Although the definition of exactness and acyclicity are the same, they have different attitudes. Acyclicity reguards the chain complex as a geometric object, concerning cycles and boundaries. On the other hand, exactness takes a purely algebraic perspective, describing how the algebraic pieces fit together.
Given two chain complexes C_\bullet , D_\bullet , the natural notion of morphisms between them is chain maps, i.e. a sequence of maps f_n : C_n \to D_n such that all the squares commute.

\begin {tikzcd} \cdots & {C_{n+1}} & {C_n} & {C_{n-1}} & \cdots \\ \cdots & {D_{n+1}} & {D_n} & {D_{n-1}} & \cdots \arrow ["d", from=1-3, to=1-4] \arrow ["{f_n}"', from=1-3, to=2-3] \arrow ["{f_{n-1}}"', from=1-4, to=2-4] \arrow ["d"', from=2-3, to=2-4] \arrow ["d"', from=2-2, to=2-3] \arrow ["d", from=1-2, to=1-3] \arrow [from=1-1, to=1-2] \arrow [from=2-1, to=2-2] \arrow [from=1-4, to=1-5] \arrow [from=2-4, to=2-5] \arrow ["{f_{n+1}}"', from=1-2, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since the boundary subgroup in one dimension can also be considered as a quotient in a lower dimension, it may be beneficial to identify the two in a visualization. This leads to the following picture. Regions appearing to the right are to be considered as quotients, and those to the left as subobjects. Further development of this visualization scheme can be seen here.

fr:title.text: Direct sum and product of chain complexes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum and product of chain complexes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kernel, image, cokernel and coimage of chain complexes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a chain map f_\bullet : C_\bullet \to D_\bullet , we can take the kernel, image, cokernel and coimage in each dimension, to obtain new chain complexes. It is a matter of unpacking and repacking quotients to verify that the relevant squares commute, rendering the following diagram of chain complexes.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since many operations on abelian groups and R-modules can be performed on chain complexes, we wish to axiomatize an abstract notion to encapsulate them all. This motivates the definition of additive and abelian categories. We can use the three examples mentioned above as the source for intuitions for abelian categories.

First, we wish to let the morphisms form abelian groups. This turns out to have a surprising impact on the structure of categories, the most important of which is the coincidence of finite products and coproducts.

Given a category \mathcal {C}, an \mathsf {Ab}-enrichment is given by abelian group structures on every hom-set, such that composition is linear in each argument. In other words, we have a homomorphism \hom (Y, Z) \otimes \hom (X, Y) \to \hom (X, Z).

Let \mathcal {C} be \mathsf {Ab}-enriched. The finite products and coproducts, if they exist, are isomorphic via a canonical map. If they all exist, then this category is called an additive category. In particular, the nullary product and coproduct coincide, and we call the object zero object, denoted 0.

When there are finitely many objects involved, we can construct an inverse. Consider the morphisms \prod _i X_i \xrightarrow {\pi _j} X_j \xrightarrow {\iota _j} \coprod _i X_i. We claim the sum of these morphisms is the desired inverse. To verify this, we compose them. Using bilinearity, we are reduced to showing that the coproduct and product of the identity map is the identity, which is true.

Due to this coincidence creating gadgets with two universal properties, the structure of additive categories are uniquely determined. This also means that we only need very mild conditions on functors to preserve the structures of an additive category.

fr:title.text: Being an additive category is a property

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Being an additive category is a property

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a category, if it can be endowed with an \mathsf {Ab}-enrichment that makes it an additive category, then it only has one possible enrichment. In particular, there is at most one way to turn a category into an additive category.
Notice that having finite products and coproducts is a property, and the canonical morphism between them being an isomorphism is also a property. These do not mention the enrichment structure.

With these properties satisfied, the addition structure on the \hom -sets are fixed. We claim that the additive neutral element is given by the composition X \to 0 \to Y, and given two parallel morphisms f, g : X \to Y, the following composition X \xrightarrow {\Delta } X \oplus X \xrightarrow {f \oplus g} Y \oplus Y \xrightarrow {\nabla } Y. is equal to the addition f + g. For disambiguation, we temporarily denote these constructions as 0' and f +' g. By interpreting \oplus as a product or a coproduct at appropriate times, it is easy to see that 0' is indeed the neutral element for +'.

Recall that arrows X \oplus X \to Y \oplus Y is given by a 2 \times 2 matrix, and this correspondence is an abelian group isomorphism by general enriched category theory. f \oplus g comes from a diagonal matrix with f, g as entries, so this operation is linear, which entails +' is also linear. By the Eckmann–Hilton argument, the two addition operations must coincide.
Given two additive categories and a functor F : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {D} between them, the following are equivalent. In this case, we call the functor additive.

fr:ul.fr:li: The functor preserves finite products.
The functor preserves finite coproducts.
The functor is a homomorphism on the abelian groups \hom _{\mathcal {C}}(X, Y), i.e. it is an \mathsf {Ab}-enriched functor.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the equivalence of the first two claims, we have a composition F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y), where the middle morphism comes from the canonical isomorphism X + Y \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y). The first two claim is equivalent to the right and left arrows being iso, respectively. Recall that a morphism from a coproduct to a product is determined by a matrix of morphisms. With this fact and the functoriality of F, we can compute that the composition is the canonical isomorphism from F(X) + F(Y) to F(X) \times F(Y). Therefore the leftmost arrow being iso is equivalent to the rightmost arrow being iso.

Since the abelian group structure on morphisms is uniquely determined from the finite products and coproducts in an additive category, a functor satisfying the first two conditions automatically satisfies the third. Conversely, we need to prove the canonical maps F(1) \to 1 and F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y) are isomorphisms. For the first one, since 1 is also the initial object, any morphism into it is automatically iso. For the second one, we again look at the diagram which composes to an isomorphism: F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y). Using the bilinearity of composition and that F preserves addition on morphisms, we can verify that this provides a two-sided inverse.
In an adjunction F \dashv G, both functors are automatically additive.
Since the left adjoint preserves colimits, it preserves finite coproducts. Therefore by it is an additive functor. Dually, the right adjoint preserves limits, and is also additive.
Kernels and cokernels are also greatly simplified in additive categories.

fr:title.text: Equalizers can be reduced to kernels in {Ab}-enriched categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equalizers can be reduced to kernels in \mathsf {Ab}-enriched categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can express equalizers with kernels (which are equalizers with the zero morphism).
We simply need to note that an equalizer for f and g is equivalent to an equalizer for (f-g) and 0, by bilinearity of composition.

Abelian categories are one step further from additive categories. Similar to the situation of abelian groups or modules, every morphism f : X \to Y has four key components, the image, the kernel, the coimage X / \ker f, and the cokernel Y / \operatorname {im} f. The image is always identical with the coimage, representing the core part of the homomorphism. The kernel perfectly measures the failure of injectivity, and the cokernel perfectly measures the failure of surjectivity. This is in stark constrast with general maps, where the failure of injectivity may be heterogeneous, and thus cannot be simply characterized.
Given an additive category, it is an abelian category if the following condition holds.

fr:ul.fr:li: Every morphism has a kernel and a cokernel.
Every monomorphism is the kernel of its cokernel.
Every epimorphism is the cokernel of its kernel.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The definition of abelian categories may look intimidating, but thinking of it as R-modules is a very effective way to reduce mental load. In fact, the Freyd–Mitchell embedding theorem justifies this to some extent, allowing us to use familiar language such as taking and manipulating elements.

Although practically every important functor between additive categories is additive, the same cannot be said for abelian categories. Functors preserving the structure of abelian categories are called exact, but many functors fail to satisfy this for various reasons. One of the main endeavours of homological algebra is to characterize the failures of exactness, and study their consequences. This leads to intricate and beautiful structures emerging.
An additive functor F : \mathcal {A} \to \mathcal {B} between abelian categories is left exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions.

fr:ul.fr:li: It preserves kernels.
It preserves finite limits.
It preserves the exactness of sequences 0 \to A \to B \to C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Dually, an additive functor is right exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions.

fr:ul.fr:li: It preserves cokernels.
It preserves finite colimits.
It preserves the exactness of sequences A \to B \to C \to 0.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If a functor is both left exact and right exact, it is simply called an exact functor, which is equivalent to it preserving the exactness of sequences A \to B \to C.
Since additive functors already preserves finite products, and kernels are equivalent to general equalizers using the additive structure, the first two conditions are equivalent.
The sequence A \rightarrowtail B \to C being exact is equivalent to A being a kernel of B \to C. So the third condition is equivalent to the first. This completes the equivalence proof.

Since \hom (P, -) preserves limits, by it is left exact. Similarly \hom (-, I) is right exact. Therefore we naturally want to find out when \hom (P, -) is right exact. We only need to guarantee that \hom (P, -) preserves epimorphisms. This can be unpackaged to the following definition.

In an abelian category, an object P is projective iff for every morphism P \to B can be lifted through an epimorphism A \twoheadrightarrow B, i.e. there exists a (non-unique) morphism P \to A making the triangle commute.

Projective objects are defined to capture a key property of free objects. For an arbitrary abelian group P, lifting a map P \to B through an epimorphism requires us to pick a lifting for every generator, such that the relations between the generators still hold after lifting. If such a thing can always be done, then we may say that the relations, or tangling between generators are practically non-existent. A projective object can thus be reguarded as generated by some elements with zero or undetectable “tangling”.
As an example, consider the projective objects in the category of modules. We can give a nice characterization of projective modules.

fr:title.text: Projective modules are direct summands of free modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Projective modules are direct summands of free modules

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the abelian category of modules over a ring R, the projective object modules are exactly the modules that appear as a direct summand of some free module P \oplus Q = R^{\oplus n}.
A free module evidently projective. If P is a direct summand of a projective module Q, then we can extend any map P \to B to Q by zero. Then the projectivity of Q implies that of P.

On the other hand, suppose P is projective, then we have an epimorphism R^{\oplus |P|} \twoheadrightarrow P. The identity map P \to P lifts against this epimorphism to a splitting of it, hence P is its direct summand.
Dually, we have the definition of injective objects, which make \hom (-, I) exact.
In an abelian category, an object I is injective iff every morphism B \to I can be extended along monomorphisms B \rightarrowtail A. Equivalently, it is a projective object in the dual category.
As an example, we characterize injective abelian groups. Similar characterizations can be done for modules over principal ideal domains.

fr:title.text: Abelian groups are injective iff divisible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Abelian groups are injective iff divisible

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An abelian group G is injective iff it is divisible, i.e. for element g \in G and positive integer n, there exists a (non-unique) solution of nx = g.

In one direction, suppose the group is injective, then the map \mathbb {Z} \to G defined by k \mapsto k g can be extended along the monomorphism (n \times -) : \mathbb {Z} \to \mathbb {Z}. This provides the division.

On the other hand, suppose divisibility holds. Given a morphism f : A \to G and an injection A \hookrightarrow B, we extend f to B by Zorn's lemma. Consider the poset of homomorphisms extending f to some subgroup of B. Given a chain in this poset, we can take the union to create an upper bound. And it is non-empty since f is an element. Hence it has a maximal element \phi . Suppose it is defined on B' \subsetneq B, then there is an element b \in B not in B'. Suppose n b \notin B' for all non-zero integers n, then we can define a larger homomorphism on B + \mathbb {Z} b, contradicting the maximality. Suppose there is some n b \in B', then by divisibility we can assign \phi (b) a division of \phi (n b) by n. This too contradicts maximality.
This is my forest. Forests are a way of organizing notes, and here is a list of other websites organized as forests. Some of the contents here:

fr:ul.fr:li: Algebraic geometry (Under namespace algm, not organized)
On ghost and phantom maps

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: On a computer, you can press Ctrl–K to search for trees. You can also visit my contributor page to see a list of my trees.
I try to adhere to several principles when composing trees.

fr:ul.fr:li: If a definition or a lemma would present itself during a proof attempt, then do not introduce it until that part of the proof. The nature of forests makes this kind of organization more viable, as each definition is a tree by itself.
If a part of a proof has an easy constructive phrasing, use it and avoid classical reasoning. But if it requires some complication, then the classical way is used.

Avoid abstraction leaks. Even if A is defined as B, do not use them interchangeably. For instance, an ideal is defined as a subset of a ring satisfying certain conditions. But we will insist on writing ideals as numbers, for example saying \mathfrak {a} \mid x instead of x \in \mathfrak {a}. This is not too heretic, since algebraic number theory already uses this kind of notation. Similarly, although prime ideals correspond to points in \operatorname {Spec}(A), we do not identify them.
Apply unbiased terminology and negative thinking.
